name: Presidente. –
text: Good morning. Ladies and gentlemen, allow me to greet the previous Presidents of Parliament who are here with us today, in particular President Enrique Barόn Crespo, who was in office on the day of the fall of the Berlin Wall.  Thirty years ago, Germany and Europe lived one of the most important and significant pages in their recent history.  After decades of suffering, the tearful wound of the division of Germany and Europe found its recomposition through the fall of its most obvious and odious symbol. At last, the Wall fell under the pressure of thousands of women and men, anxious to regain their freedom and dignity, after years of oppression and deprivation of their fundamental rights.  I would like to remind you that the success of that night was the result of the determination of millions of Eastern European citizens who peacefully, without any violence, but only through the force of their own reasons, were able to free themselves from the yoke to which they had been subjected for decades.  It is also to the courage of those European citizens that I would like to pay tribute today.  Witnessing those moments was the amazement and joy of hundreds of thousands of German citizens on both side and, alongside them, thousands of young people who had come from all over Europe to share the overwhelming enthusiasm of those hours.  I, in those days, was among those young people, together with many perhaps of you, and I remember the irrepressible happiness, the hugs, the tears, the incredulous gaze of the Vopos who saw their world crumble at the same speed with which the Wall unraed under the blows of the pickaxes.  I also well remember the awareness, well rooted in all of us, of living a unique and unrepeatable moment in history that finally closed a dark page, made up of oppression, mourning, the annulment of freedom and personality, and opened another charge of optimism, of hope.  Today, thirty years after the fall of the Wall, we can say that that enthusiasm and hope have not been betrayed: if the Europe in which we live today is a better place, we owe it to the European Union and to the achievements it has been able to achieve.  I want to make it clear that European democracy, the values and principles on which it is based are unfortunately not irreversible. That is why we need the commitment and determination of all of us to defend them. This is a fight that we have to fight every day, non-stop.  As a witness to those extraordinary days in Berlin, I cannot but look with great concern at the return to Europe of ghosts that we believed dead, buried under the weight of history.  It is with disbelief, but also with immense anger, that we find ourselves seeing how the demon of anti-Semitism is once again entering our Europe today. The unfortunately numerous episodes of recent history come to mind and I am thinking, and we think, of what happened in Halle only a few weeks ago, of the desecration of the Jewish cemetery in Randers in Denmark, of the threats to which Senator Liliana Segre was subjected in Italy.  The resurgence of anti-Semitism is the result of the resurgence of nationalism, xenophobia, racism and the rejection of everything that is different from us. These phenomena are also the breeding ground for terrorism, which threatens Europe and the whole world with acts of violence. Just today marks the anniversary of the tragic events of the Bataclan, a history that belongs to us, the history we lived together, and our moved memory was with the 130 victims who lost their lives that night and their families.  The threat to our values also comes from outside. We are forced to confront interference on a daily basis which seeks to undermine our achievements and the security of European citizens in different forms. We have to be united. Yes united, to respond to these attacks, to strengthen our union, to secure our borders.  It is against these threats that we must fight with great determination and unity if we are to honour the promises made that evening in Berlin, when the Wall was crumbled. I am convinced that this is a battle that we can only win if we are together. And we must do so, by opposing with all our might those who mystify the facts of history, who give simple answers to complex problems, who confuse the legitimate pride that each of us feels for our country, for our country and for our own culture, with hatred and contempt for others.  It's not an easy battle. We often wonder how it is possible today for a European citizen to forget the lesson of the history of our continent and our fathers. A story full of glorious pages, but also of suffering and horrors, like those I mentioned a moment ago.  The answer I find is that of the the need to insist on knowledge and remembrance and I am referring, in particular, to the youngest who have not lived that story, but have learned it perhaps on books or on the internet or on the Internet. It is to them that I wish to address them with particular affection at this time, because it is in them that we place our hopes. Today I want, we want to make our contribution to this challenge here. We are doing so, in the presence of the President of the Bundestag, Wolfgang Schäuble, which we have the honour of having today precisely to remember what happened in Berlin thirty years ago. You have the floor, Mr President.  The word to her after listening to a piece of music that will be the introduction to this ceremony. There will be with us a young Belgian musician, Liav Kerbel, who will play a sarabande by Johan Sebastian Bach. Cellist's entrance.  A video shown on screens shows Mstislav Rostropovich playing Johann Sebastian's Sarabande at the Berlin Wall on November 11, 1989. The video ends when the musician starts playing. name: Wolfgang Schäuble
text: President of the German Bundestag. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Nothing has to stay as it is – on 9 November 1989, I realised what that meant. The will of my compatriots in the GDR was stronger than the Berlin Wall. Across Central and Eastern Europe, 30 years ago, citizens took their own hands. The transformative force that unfolded achieved what seemed incontrovertible for decades: the fall of the Berlin Wall, the tearing down of the Iron Curtain across Europe. Anyone who has witnessed this moment will never forget it. And anyone who sees the images of that time still feels the force of the feelings associated with them, this moment of happiness – a historical moment that stands for itself. "We are flying into history" – that is what the pilot of an American plane told his passengers before landing in Berlin that evening on 9 November. He couldn't keep the incredible news of the open felling trees to himself, and he had an idea of their dimension. The Germans in the GDR, the people of all Central and Eastern Europe, freed themselves from communist rule, from the claim to power of the Soviet Union. Nations found their way back – to actually be people's republics, because in them really determined the citizens. Democracy and the rule of law prevailed, human and civil rights were enshrined, the market economy replaced the planned economy – and although there was no master plan for it, the process of European unification brought together 500 million people in East and West together in peaceful development – for the good. Historically, this is unprecedented. So we keep an awareness of what is possible when people stand up for something together. Especially in a Parliament which serves the necessary dispute, but which should always also have the Common, the common good in mind. That is why, by your invitation – and I am happy to follow it – to speak to you about the fall of the Berlin Wall and the happy historic turning point for the whole of Europe, I am honoured – and gladly accepted it – about the courage of those who have not seen it. who then demonstrated in many places in the GDR, who exerted high personal risk on the frozen state and party leadership, who demanded reforms and freedoms – or who left everything behind for their freedom and fled in their thousands to the West and, last but not least, managed to keep this revolution peaceful in Germany, just as in most other neighbouring states, whether we remember it as a velvet or a singing revolution. The fact that it happened like this is something that you can only marvel at again and again. And it's really a reason to celebrate! During the Cold War, on the western side of the Iron Curtain, the sympathies of dissidents and opponents – Charter 77, Solidarity, and the other civil rights movements, in which the few brave first joined together. Their example encouraged others until it became the mass protests that swept away the old regimes in 1989-90. The West inaimably played a part in the fact that this could succeed – not least through the NATO double decision, which drove the weakened Soviet Union to divert and negotiate. The courage of the people of the East and this firm attitude of the West: both contributed to the fact that the Cold War was overcome 30 years ago. The opening of the wall came as a surprise, but it did not come without harbingers: the election of a Pole as Pope and his powerful visit to his homeland, the powerful Polish trade union movement, the luminous candle demonstration in Bratislava, the 650 km long human chain through the Baltics and last but not least the great humanitarian gesture of the Hungarians at Sopron in the summer of 1989, when they opened the border on their own – these and other signals point to change. Father Imre Kozma of the Hungarian Malteser Relief Service looked after refugees from the GDR at the time and summed up in words how people's attitudes changed in these eventful months: "Those who have learned to fear were suddenly no longer afraid." Not even in the GDR. Incidentally, when the government in the GDR reacted to the mass protests on 9 November with the sudden opening of the border, hardly anyone was as close to the action as some Members of the European Parliament. The Committee on Legal Affairs – that is, the body responsible for citizens' rights of this Parliament! – met from 8 to 10 November 1989 in Berlin in the Reichstag building, directly on the Wall. Parliamentarians dealt with familiar-sounding issues: the legal protection of computer programs and the use of genetically modified microorganisms. They were as unprepared for an event that would change the world, nor were we all prepared. The Parliamentary Committee reacted, as has just Parliamentary committees react: it adopted an opinion. The announcement says soberly that we welcome the events in Berlin. What a contrast to the euphoria of the people! In the night and in the following days, hundreds of thousands of people cheered and marveled at the Berlin border crossings, the checkpoints between the GDR and the Federal Republic. Wild strangers lay in their arms 28 years after the construction of the wall, which was in fact a death strip. At least 140 people lost their lives here. We do not forget them! And we do not forget the suffering of their families and not the many other victims of decades of dictatorships in Eastern Europe. The fact that the members of the european parliament's committee were visibly restraining their joy may also have had to do with the fact that no one knew at the time whether the wall would finally be history. In our heads – our heads – were the images of the violent suppression of the protests: in 1953 in the GDR, in 1956 in Hungary and in 1968 in Czechoslovakia. Remembered were the tanks that were on display when martial law was imposed in Poland in 1981, and the violent end of the student protests in beijing's Tiananmen Square in the summer of 1989. Against this background, European events are once again shining in a particularly bright light. The courage that the people had taken, their vociferous demand for reforms, a voice or a change of power had shaken the foundations of the communist regimes. They knew the consequences of showing weakness. Some still believed that they had to prove strength through particular hardness. Others were no longer able to do so. As different as the civic movements were, and between them were the criticism of the ruling state party, its multi-voiced demands, and its expectations of political change – what united them all was the goal of overcoming the lack of freedom: to shake off permanent control, to get rid of arbitrary rule, to break the boundaries, to leave behind the impartialness of the trapped. Who among the young people in Europe can even imagine today that real freedom for generations was an unfulfillable dream? Today, as citizens of the European Union, in a large democratic area of justice, we are free to decide how we live, where we live, study, work, trade. Everyone is free to express their opinion, no matter how absurd. In a free, democratic Europe, one's own right to stand in the independent courts – united! A dream that has become a reality. We Germans know that without European unification, without the desire of Europeans to grow together in East and West, there would be no German unity. One was the prerequisite for the other, both are two sides of the same coin. The four victorious powers made the state unity of Germany possible by giving us what we could not claim: their trust. Just like our immediate neighbours and the members of the European Community, despite the wounds left on the continent by the Second World War unleashed by Germany. We Germans will never forget this proof of reconciliation! Thanks to the political change of 1989/90, the process of European unification has gained considerable momentum over the past 30 years – from the common internal market and the long-planned economic and monetary union to the euto- until the enlargement of the European Union to include the re-established democracies of Central and Eastern Europe. We share the same values that we have long hoped will be an undisputed victory. This has proved to be an illusion. Instead, our democracies are globally exposed to competition with authoritarian systems that promote themselves with a high promise of efficiency and prosperity, but without granting their citizens what we in the West take for granted: freedom and social justice, progress and sustainability, democracy, the rule of law, universal human rights – all that makes Europe worth living and, for many people around the world, a place of longing, which, incidentally, is still a place of longing for authoritarian rulers all over the world. Sometimes it feels as if we ourselves have the greatest doubt about it. Many people – especially those who once demanded freedom and a say on the streets – are not satisfied, not because they did not value freedom or democracy, but rather because the transitions from tyranny to democratic compromise are always chaotic, such as the British historian Timothy Garton Ash once remarked. Upheavals are associated with pain. What does the West have to offer us? This question was posed by the Polish poet Czeslaw Miosz long before the fall of the Iron Curtain. "Freedom from something is a lot, but it's too little, it's much less than freedom to something," he wrote at the time. What is freedom to something? We must constantly renegotiate the answer to this question – especially since freedom as a value is not alone. Since the French Revolution, we have known about the triad: freedom demands equality and fraternity. That, too, is a European heritage! It meets the needs of the people of Europe. They do not live in a single space – they form a community with many different historical characteristics and national identities. In the West, few have any idea of what it means to have been exposed to dictatorship and foreign rule, sometimes even twice. What do we know about the faults in which people in all the states of the former Eastern Bloc had to prove themselves in the years of upheaval afterwards? For most people, the freedom gained in changing the system was associated with a deep incision, even with impositions. Where we talk intensively about immigration problems throughout Europe for good reason, people in the eastern parts of our continent are often much more concerned with the experience of emigration and its far-reaching consequences. Conversely, many sometimes lack an understanding of how diverse the originally old core Europe and the states that are rallying around it are. The West is more than just wealthy and saturated, spoiled for peace and accustomed to the seemingly self-evident democracy. The transition to a common Europe in East and West remains a major task for all of us, especially in view of the simultaneous rapid changes brought about by globalisation and digitalisation, global migration and climate change, and the dissolving of international liabilities. All of this causes new insecurity, including fear, for many people. However, the freedom that prevails in Europe today after the century of terrible wars and the loss of humanity in the dictatorships is not an imposition! At best, they are side effects, it is actually the freedom of others that causes discomfort and rejection. Liberal Europe is enormously diverse. But we still lack a common public, and there is a lack of platforms to talk across borders about what is common or divisive. Only through the exchange can we arrive at a real pan-European perspective. We can all learn from each other – especially since, by the way, East Germans and Eastern Europeans have something ahead of the people of the West, because they have 30 years of experience with processes of change. This is a valuable experience, especially since we realize that the impositions of globalisation and digitalisation do not stop at anyone. At the political level, we can only really make progress if we perceive and acknowledge each other's perspectives more strongly than before, not in order to make them uncritical, but to better understand each other – and to be able to take community decisions. We always tend to see our own attitude as the only right one. This is shaping many conflicts in Europe. Not only, but also between East and West, sometimes divides seem to deepen again. Therefore, let us not and never jeopardise the greatest achievement of the turn of the epoch of 1989 – that is the overcoming of the division of our continent! In this fundamentally changing world, we will all only play a role if we act together, if we adopt common positions that are shared or at least supported by the people of the Member States. We will only be able to set the tone and stand up for our values if we do justice to them ourselves. And we will only be taken seriously if we substantially step up our joint efforts to provide effective stability to the conflict-prone regions within Europe and in our closer neighbourhood. Freedom can only be defended by those who know and live them – and who not only summon swears them on holidays. Democracy is as important for the stability of society as prosperity and prosperity. Our values tame the delimited processes and provide balance in global competition. But even in our 21st century, they are by no means self-evident and certainly not unchallenged. Jacques Delors has left a warning legacy on this. In the light of the experiences of the violent 20th century, he feared the flare-up of a new Nationalism and an increasing individualism at the same time. Both, he saw it, threaten intra-European solidarity and social cohesion in the Member States of the Union, but above all the 'open universalism' and the capacity for tolerance that characterises our community of values – precisely the heritage of Europe. We should remember his words, Jacques Delors', 'if the EU fails, this legacy is in danger of being lost'. I think the warning remains up-to-date! (Applause) What Delors probably could not have imagined, certainly not wanting: the EU is losing one of its largest members in a torturous process. And our continent is experiencing the return of war and violent border shifts on the eastern border. Moreover, even security partners within NATO are behaving in a way that no critic of the alliance ever thought possible. The rules-based international order is under pressure – and in an increasingly intertwined world, where truth no longer counts and national egoisms are lived out, but where the most pressing questions – world food, migration, climate change, and security – can only be answered globally. This is the point of political reason: more cooperation is needed. This applies to the EU's external relations, but it also applies to intra-European coexistence. Europe can only act if the Member States cooperate. Cohesion is a prerequisite for Europe to become 'world-politically capable', as Jean-Claude Juncker has called it. We must overcome small-mindedness, self-centeredness and fear. The fall of the Berlin Wall and the 30 years that have passed since then show that nothing has to remain as it is. The most massive walls can fall, change is possible if we take them into our hands. It is up to us. Then Europe can learn from the grandiose change of the world of 1989/90: we are free to act courageously. (Members rose from their seats and applauded the speaker)

name: Presidente. –
text: Thank you, Mr Schäuble. I welcome the presence in this House of many visitors, the presence of the Finnish Presidency and also the President-in-Office of the Council, Charles Michel. I welcome the Commissioners-in-Office and also the President-designate, Mrs Ursula von der Leyen. Let us begin with the chairmen of the political groups, the floor to Manfred Weber, for the People's Party, please.

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the I was 17 years old. A young person who is allowed to experience a lot of new things every day. But when I saw the tears in the eyes of my parents, my acquaintances and my friends, and when I saw the pictures in the TV shows first of the Prague embassy at the time and then of the fall of the Wall, I felt that we were feeling: here we are experiencing history. It was wonderful when the first compatriots arrived with me – in my homeland in Lower Bavaria – with the so-called Trabbis. We intuitively sensed that what belongs together comes together here. As a German, I was deeply impressed when I saw the people of Leipzig, Dresden and East Berlin taking to the streets. I am deeply grateful to them for their courage, for their desire for unity in freedom, for their sense of citizenship. They created values that still shape us to this day. The citizens are the heroes of unity. Her voice was heard because strong allies did not let her down. One of my first key political experiences was when Ronald Reagan stood in front of the Brandenburg Gate two years before the fall of the Iron Curtain and asked Gorbachev to tear down the wall. The European Community, NATO and all its members have always been united on one point: the division of Europe must be overcome. The support that the Americans and Europeans had for the Germans 30 years ago was a real gift.  This advance of confidence was far from self-evident after two destructive world wars. We should always remember this confidence of our allies when, today – including in Germany – we sometimes discuss the future of Europe in a small and critical way. The friends of Germany did not paint the failure on the wall. They saw the future, they trusted, they were real statesmen and stateswomen in many areas. Dear Wolfgang Schäuble! The way in which you negotiated the German Unification Treaty has been historic and, more importantly, successful. My political generation owes an enormous amount to them, Theo Waigel and Helmut Kohl. Even then, there were many concerns. I read them in the newspapers, heard them at university, in the shop, while shopping. Not everyone was enthusiastic about the developments at the time. But you were not impressed by it, you showed leadership. Your actions, your foresight were formative. Thank you for that. We can also need this leadership today. No one doubts today: German and European unity are inextricably linked. Helmut Kohl was always a German patriot. But he never left any doubt: a united democratic Europe is our common mission. He was literally committed to the European project to the last gear. What an ardent European, what a great statesman Helmut Kohl was, everyone experienced at the end of his work when we said goodbye to him in the Strasbourg Chamber. The father of German unity said goodbye in the European Parliament. Helmut Kohl knew that the fall of the Berlin Wall was not a national, singular event, nor a national feat. We Germans owe unity in freedom to the courage of thousands of friends in Eastern Europe. Politicians such as Lech Wasa, Véclav Havel, and Jozsef Antall also fought not only for the freedom of their own country, but for the whole of Europe. We should uphold the spirit of peaceful revolution, the spirit of peaceful awakening, also in our generation. Today, a lot of small-scale people dominate everyday political life. Today, however, we are faced with major challenges. We can learn from the fall of the Wall: we can only create something great if we stand together in Europe. Europe is the key to a better future, a livable future, and for that it is necessary to work today on european awareness.  I love my homeland of Bavaria, I like to be German, and I am a European in my heart. We must not allow nationalists and populists to destroy this unity of identity. I like being European. Let us renew european cohesion as we lived it 30 years ago.

name: Iratxe García Pérez
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe and the rest of humanity will never forget 9 November 1989. It was a moment of illusion, the illusion of hope. What happened that night changed the lives of European peoples forever; the images of the euphoric crowd above the wall, the queues of people and the cars crossing back and forth were an explosion of happiness.  The bipolar world in which Europe had lived for decades, which seemed eternal and immovable, had already collapsed, at a time of meaning, because it commemorated two of the darkest episodes in our history: on the one hand, the anniversary of Broken Crystal Night when, on November 9, 1938, the Nazis committed the first great slaughter against the Jews; and, on the other hand, in 1989 it was half a century from the beginning of World War II.  The fall of the Berlin Wall marked the triumph of liberal democracies in the face of the Soviet blockade, inaugurating a stage of hope in which We Europeans believe that nothing could stop the expansion of human rights, free elections and the rule of law. Within weeks, Romania, Bulgaria and Czechoslovakia, among others, got rid of their dictatorships to adopt the Western parliamentary democracy model.  But thirty years later, new walls separate Europeans. Now these walls are ideological—between nationalists and Europeanists—they are territorial—between the great cities and the rural world—or classes—between rich and impoverished workers. While support for democracy is widespread in much of the world and, of course, in Europe, populists are gaining ground, and this forces us to make a deep reflection to avoid returning to dark stages of our history.  1989 was a moment of hope and victory for the West and for the values we stand for. Getting it wasn't easy. Our biggest mistake is forgetting what it means to defend freedom.  Thirty years later, it is easy to forget that German reunification was riddled with uncertainties and misgivings. Some thought it would be such an immense economic and social effort for Germany that it would wipe out the European locomotive and, as a consequence, the European Community. Others warned of the danger of resurrecting an old enemy buried since World War II.  No one like Helmut Kohl knew how to pick up the feelings of European partners. In his memoirs, he recalled the lack of support and confessed: "Among our European allies, there was only one who strongly supported us from the outing point: the Spanish President, Felipe González, who did not hesitate for a moment about what position he should take."  If in 1989 it was possible, we must now also be able to respond to the uncertainties that threaten our model of coexistence. The European Union is, above all, peace, freedom, progress. Let us walk with these values and make our Union the most advanced model of integration and social justice, and may this anniversary serve to restore hope.  In 1989 I was also a young woman, more than Mr. Weber. I was fifteen years old—almost as young as my country's democracy—but I was already beginning to build my political conscience and I was aware that this was an important day for Europe's history. But I could never imagine that today I would have the honour and pride of representing the Social Democratic family in this European Parliament. For me it is a pride, but above all a great responsibility, to take the witness of the men and women who built such an important moment for our political project and to guarantee peace, freedom and justice.

name: Dacian Cioloş
text: on behalf of the Renew group. – Mr President, in November 1989 I was 20 years old. I was in my first year of college and i was living one of the toughest communist regimes in Central and Eastern Europe – Ceaușescu's. About the fall of the Berlin Wall we heard only a few days after this happened, speaking on Radio Free Europe, the radio that allowed us to connect illegally, at that time, to the rest of the world.  On 9 November 1989, a wall separating Europe in two was destroyed, and with it began, at least in Europe, the end of a regime that survived only by limiting the freedoms and rights of citizens by the state.  The fall of the Berlin Wall had a domino effect. Only a month and a half later, Ceaușescu's communist national regime was over. Like other young people of my age, like other Romanians, like other central Europeans, we were thirsty for freedom, democracy and Europe, for on the streets of Timişoara, where movements began in Romania, or in Bucharest, demonstrators were already invoking Europe. The aim of the vast majority of those who were in the streets was to return to the values of European democracy and civilization, as the Timişoara Proclamation says.  If thirty years ago a wave of democratisation was felt in Europe, but also in other parts of the world, for more than ten years freedom and democracy have been losing ground worldwide. More than half of the world's citizens live in political regimes devoid of or partly devoid of fundamental freedoms, and in Europe the temptation to build walls again continues to threaten us. And those of my generation who lived with the wall and without the wall. We can't help but see this similarity.  Brexit, for example, means new barriers to trade and freedom of movement. I hope that British citizens who have always fought for a free Europe will think twice before building new frontiers. The reaction of some when it comes to Europe's migration challenges is to call on new walls. The walls have no place on this continent, we do not want to build a fortress Europe. Rather, we need to build bridges and close partnerships with the countries in Europe's neighbourhood.  Colleagues, walls are not only physical, they are also barriers imposed by fear to political freedom and prosperity. Political parties and leaders with authoritarian tendencies in Europe, who want their country or Europe to flirt again with the dictatorship of the past, must be stopped. European democracy and freedom must be defended by those who have no hesitation today in taking advantage of the benefits of membership of the European Union, but who reject its values. Thirty years after the fall of Berlin we have a responsibility to defend the ideals and values in whose name this wall has been destroyed: freedom, democracy, prosperity and the European Union.  In the coming months we will have to launch a European-wide conference on our common future, involving all the citizens of the European Union, in order to lay the foundations for a new European project that inspires confidence for years to come, because I, as a Romanian, cannot conceive of being Romanian without being European in the same sense, and I am convinced that all , regardless of the ideologies we have, we feel this. And then why not express these things naturally and convey this feeling, the European project that we support?

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, thirty years ago, the Wall did not just fall, it was brought down by very courageous people, people who took a very high and very concrete personal risk. They fought for fair and free elections, for the freedom of expression, for an end to being caged-in and under constant observation – all those things that we take for granted right now. But back then, those demands could get you into prison, they could get you tortured, lose your job and lose your social connections. But despite all of those risks, people took to the streets, organised already long before 1989, and never gave up. It is this courage that changed the world and it is this courage that’s still changing the world today. Also today, we need to be vigilant, not to forget the lessons from 1989. Democracy needs to be gained every day again and again, in every action that we do here in this House but also everywhere in Europe. Unfortunately, there are governments right now who are trying to dismantle democracy, bit by bit. This is a disgrace, especially given the sacrifices that the citizens in countries like Hungary made to free their country. Those who shut down universities, those who arrest civil society and build walls against refugees, they are betraying the demonstrators from 1989. (Applause) Freedom is something that needs to be expanded every day as well and too many people are still not free in this world, not free for who they are, whom they love or where they’re from. We are all citizens of this world, born free and born equal. Discrimination and hatred should not prevail. Freedom of expression is also being curbed when hatred and threats are being issued and used against people active in politics, active in their communities. When people there are faced with threats on an everyday level, then this is a problem for freedom of expression, as well as democracy. Constant observation is also becoming a trend again, but we should never forget what history teaches us – surveillance, a control state, does not lead to freedom or security. It ends both. We don’t know what the future will bring, and any law we do here always needs to work also when governments don’t mean well. Things have changed a lot over the past years, over the past 30 years especially. If you look at the border zone now that once divided Germany, where hundreds of people lost their lives trying to cross looking for freedom, often also being assisted by other people who helped them, this area is now a major production area, safeguarding climate and biodiversity for the future generations and becoming a symbol of hope. The borders that divided Europe have now become places where people meet, get to know each other. But let’s not forget, there are many walls still up today that need to be torn down. There are many people today, as back then, who are looking for freedom. Let us not turn our back on them. Let us not forget what it means to look for freedom, to not have it and then to gain it. Without the courageous people thirty years ago, I wouldn’t be here and many colleagues would not be either. Europe as we know it, only exists because the wall that divided us all finally was torn down. But 9 November 1989 is not a date where we should hold commemoratory speeches and just congratulate each other on how well it all worked back then. I believe it is an anniversary to remind us to be courageous, to tear down the walls that divide us and to be the change that we want to see in the world.

name: Jörg Meuthen
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, President of the Bundestag, Dr Schäuble, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the President of the Bundestag, Mr Schäuble, for the work he has done on this report. Thirty years ago, in one of the happiest hours in German history, the wall fell. Our compatriots in the former GDR took to the streets in a totalitarian and brutal system. They demonstrated that they risked their health, even their lives. This heroic and consistently peaceful operation eventually brought down the wall and imploded a socialist regime of injustice.  So far, so pleasing, really, so beautiful! But what was supposedly swept away by the peaceful revolution at that time is now back. Socialism and communism were not finally defeated at that time, as hoped. He is alive, he is just getting up in front of all of us. Today, even the Successors of the SED are deeply hypocritical lyrical, as are the Socialist Greens and the Social Democrats. At that time they all wanted to prevent German reunification at all costs!  Berlin itself is now governed by a deep-red Senate that seeks expropriations and destroys the price mechanism to prepare for just that. The Socialists and Communists sit in the German Bundestag, and they grin a blatant grin here in the plenary of the European Parliament, where they implement their freedom-destroying agenda every day: a planned economy instead of a market economy, correctness dictates instead of true freedom of expression. Is the lesson of history still not learned? Every kind of socialism always and without exception brings poverty, impoverishment, terrible injustice and violence. All of this, unfortunately, is undefeated. One last thing: if you look at the festivities of these days, you might think that people today were celebrating the European Union and not the atm in gaining German unity. The peaceful revolutionaries of 1989, however, did not chant "EU, united fatherland", but shouted "Germany, united fatherland". They fought for freedom, for identity, for democracy and – yes – for Germany's national sovereignty. They did not fight for socialism through the back door, nor did they fight for the European Union. Meanwhile, here you are working to overcome the nation states in favour of an identityless nothingness called the United States of Europe. You will see sooner or later that the freedom-loving citizens of Europe will also bring down this absurd tower in Babel, because that is why people did not take to the streets in 1989 and risked their heads and necks and their lives. If we do not return to a Europe of sovereign fatherlands, in which nations continue to exist peacefully and cooperate meaningfully with each other, the EU as a whole will one day implode, and Brexit will only have been the first beginning of this implosion. Do not underestimate the will to freedom! This is primordial European. Those who sin against it will not have lasting success.

name: Ryszard Antoni Legutko
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, communism was the most murderous system in the history of mankind. More murderous, perhaps, than German national socialism. As somebody who, for many years, lived in a communist country, I feel it is my duty to repeat this truth over and over again. I’m afraid that what I’m going to say will be rather bitter and out of tune with what has been said before. The division between those who supported communism and those that opposed it, at that time, was far from clear. Let me remind you that in the 1970s and 1990s, the Soviet Union became a vital part of the international order. It was accepted as such. The West European governments conducted realpolitik towards the Soviet regime and accommodated its aspirations. For the same reason, those governments looked at the anti-communist movements within the Soviet bloc with suspicion, treating them as trouble- makers, courageous, politically naive yet jeopardising the international order. These movements disturbed the détente, they disturbed the Ost politik. They stood in the way of the policy of the majority of West European governments which were, or had been for a long time, openly pro-Soviet. The involvement of the Western elites in the legitimisation of communism had serious consequences. The communists continued their careers afterwards, after the system fell, and some of them joined the European Parliament, joined the European institutions, some are still here. They rebranded themselves as Social Democrats, jumped from the bandwagon called the Soviet system to another bandwagon, which is called the European Union and they were greeted heartily. Overnight, the apparatchiks, the Partiegenossen became enthusiastically European. Super-duper European. The communist system should have discredited the political Left in Europe. Unfortunately, it didn’t. In fact, the Left acquired a dominant position in Europe after the demise of the Soviet Union. The Christian Democratic, Conservative, Republican parties have capitulated to the Left agenda, which I find rather pathetic, and as a result, the spirit of communism lives on in Europe. It has been recycled, it has been garnished, has been updated, has been slightly civilised, remodelled, but it is there alright. The Left always had totalitarian temptations and no wonder they continue the policies which I remember very well from my young days living in a communist society. Today we are more and more in the grip of one correct ideology, with political correctness running wild. We had a sample of it here, right here at this session. We tend to create a new form of de facto one party system which is called political mainstream. Again, we had a sample of it this afternoon. We have militant, aggressive, secularist and barbaric social engineering. Again, these were the trademarks of the communist system. We have a neo-Marxists very much alive and kicking today. So all this considered, ladies and gentlemen, the anniversary is fine. We all remember those great days, but it is not the time for sentimental ruminations and it is not time for political self righteousness. it is time for a revision, and I mean it.

name: Martin Schirdewan
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Unfortunately, as far as the debate is at hand, it has to be said that not all the speakers have fulfilled the great task. But I would like to thank those who have expressed their views in a differentiated way. "It's like someone has opened the windows. After all these years of stagnation. The intellectual, economic, political," Stefan Heym said at the large demonstration on Berlin's Alexanderplatz on November 4, 1989. With the wall that fell five days later, the Iron Curtain fell piece by piece, separating Eastern and Western Europe economically, militarily and not least ideologically. It is crucial to the merit of the East Germans, who for months demonstrated for democracy and freedoms that we can have this debate here today – 30 years later – in the European Parliament. Thank you for that, too. Mr President, I myself was born in East Berlin and i experienced the Wall as a child. This also gives me the opportunity to tell a more nuanced story than the previous two speakers. According to the german government's latest report on the state of German unity, the vast majority of East Germans are dissatisfied with the way German unity and the post-reunification period have gone – Mr Schäuble, you pointed this out. And why? I would like to give you an example, ladies and gentlemen. Today, East Germans still have to work more hours per week and at the same time earn less than their West German counterparts. East Germany has the largest low-wage sector in the whole of the European Union, measured by national values, of course. In other words, 30 years after the political change, we need a social change, not only for Germany, but for the whole of the European Union. But it is not only social and economic development that still draws boundaries that should have disappeared long ago. It is also the mistakes that have been made in the way we deal with East and West – by which I mean not only East Germany and West Germany, but also between East and Western Europe – in recent years. I will give you another example, that of the writer Stefan Heym, who I quoted at the beginning. He comes from a Jewish-German family. He fled the Nazis to the United States as an anti-fascist and returned to Germany as a soldier in the US Army to liberate Germany from Nazism. In 1952, when he is a US citizen, he decided – and he is already an internationally recognized writer – to settle in the GDR. In 1994 – a few years later, that is, after the fall of the Berlin Wall – he was elected to the Bundestag as a non-party member on my party's list and became president of the old age there, and unfortunately, my dear fellow Members, the conservative group left the Chamber closed when he was elected. Mr Schäuble, you will remember that. I think this is a major historical mistake. I think it was a cultural breach.  These are the stories of victories and defeats. These are life stories that must be told and heard today, also in order to stop the attempts of the extreme right to capture the history of German unity, the history of the fall of the Berlin Wall, the history of European unification, as we have unfortunately had to experience again today.  The people of Hungary, Poland, Czechoslovakia and, not least, the GDR wanted a future in an open, peaceful, liberal Europe. They, on the other hand, represent a Europe of the past, nationalism and new walls. Anyone who wants to build walls on the external borders of the European Union again today, who is pursuing a policy that leads to people fleeing, instead of seeking help, has understood nothing, but nothing at all about the fall of the Berlin Wall and European unification.

name: Mislav Kolakušić (NI).
text: – Dear Chairman, the demolition of the Berlin Wall is one of the greatest events in Europe's modern history. The brave German citizens of East Germany, in that regime that was extremely oppressive, were not afraid to take to the streets and bring down the Berlin Wall united.  The demolition of the Berlin Wall made it possible to create a new, modern Europe. It has enabled many other states and peoples to become free and independent in their own states. Unfortunately, the independence of the Republic of Croatia was paid for with more than twenty thousand citizens killed. However, a great opportunity has been created to create a modern Europe in which we can all live with dignity. The European Union is a condition for creating a modern democratic Europe. However, we must be aware that even thirty years after the Berlin Wall was demolished, there are some new walls between member states.  On the borders of Croatia there is barbed wire installed by the other two members of the European Union, Slovenia and Hungary. That's something for every conviction. We have to protect the borders together. In addition to that barbed wire, we have another wall, and that is the Schengen wall. All Member States must be within the Schengen area. Otherwise, we cannot be considered equal and equal members of the European Union.  I therefore invite you to accelerate the entry of all countries into the European Union and to become equal in this regard.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. When I was born, it would have been a bold dream for us to decide on our common future in a European Parliament with Members from East and West. In my year of birth, the wall was built, which for me, as for many Europeans, is closely linked to personal history. When I was a young soldier, the Cold War was so icy that I was trained to fight against those with whom I am now united in a Union. In the year when the wall fell, our son Mark was born, and when Europe finally became one again with the eastward enlargement in 2004, our son Max was born. Our children, like a whole generation of young people, have the privilege of knowing Europe exclusively as a continent of peace, freedom and unity, and we owe this to the peaceful revolution of 1989. It is the most formative political event of our lives for me and all those who have been lucky enough to experience it. It is also the victory of European values, because the longing of the people for freedom was greater than the fear, their desire for democracy more powerful than the ideology and its cohesion more powerful than the regimes in East Germany, Central and Eastern Europe. It was the civil courage of these people that rewrote the history of our continent, and their civil courage was truly European. The spark of freedom was also ignited by the neighbours at that time: at the Polish Solidarity as well as at the Pan-European picnic on the Hungarian-Austrian border and at the Baltic Way. What belongs together is growing together, as Willy Brandt said, and he meant not only Germany, but the whole of Europe. We also owe this united Europe to the courageous actions of neighbours and partners who opened up to a reunited Germany in the heart of the continent. That was not self-evident at the time. This was not only a bold step for US President George Bush and ex-Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, but was also important for France and Great Britain. It meant embedding Germany in Europe and daring a whole new dimension of Europe: a Europe that reunites its two halves, uniting Western, Central and Eastern Europe into a single continent. That is exactly what we have seen over the last 30 years. I remember well that before the fall of the Berlin Wall I could feel and see if I was in the west or in the east, and that was not only due to the special scent of the Trabbis and the GDR cigarettes. On the other hand, if I travel with my children in Eastern or Western Europe today, there are still cultural differences, because diversity is Europe's wealth, but you cannot see where people come from. They are interested in the same issues and have the same concerns and hopes and dreams. There is no longer the old and the new Europe in the traditional sense. Nor is it the case that the East has been added to the West. No, we have grown together into our Europe! One of the greatest successes after the fall of the Iron Curtain was, as Mr Havel aptly described it, that East and West are no longer moral names, but have become purely geographical terms. Democracy, freedom and human rights are the foundations of our Europe. The rule of law must govern in Europe. This was, is and remains the main mission of the peaceful revolution in 1989. Freedom and equal rights for all – unity and justice and freedom, I would say. It is the responsibility of all of us to respect and defend these values. They are the true achievement of Europe. Only in this way could Europe, united in solidarity, become a continental success. Our successful internal market creates jobs, guarantees access to education and health insurance and creates opportunities for everyone. We must therefore resolutely oppose all those who, in the so-called national interest, conjure up East Algie or WestAlgia or other unprecedented pasts in order to play East and West against each other in Germany as well as in Europe. There are still challenges in growing together. We are all aware of this. But that does not change the fact that the EU is the best that could happen to East and West. It must be clear to us that anyone who plays with Europe is playing the future. And anyone who really wants to act in the interests of their country is counting on Europe. Only together can we play our weight on the world stage and help shape the rules of the game. If we want to continue the mission of the people of 1989 today, then we must also show European courage, and that also means courage for Europe. This is because the challenges of We can only master the future – from climate change to the digital revolution – with united forces. At the award of the Nobel Prize in 1971, Willy Brandt said that peace was not a primal state, but that it had to be made again and again by men; Social justice is crucial for lasting peace. Because, according to Brandt, material hardship is concrete non-freedom. Our common European task remains to overcome this. Working on this is Europe's destiny. Dear Wolfgang Schäuble, thank you very much for showing us what we are fighting for. And dear Mr Meuthen, thank you very much for showing us what we are fighting against. (Applause)

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, it is a great honour to address this Chamber on the occasion of the 30th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall.  I do this not only in the capacity of the minister holding the rotating Presidency of the Council, but above all, I do it as a European citizen.  This task makes me very humble because, although I was very young, I very well remember the difficult times when Europe was divided. In the middle of Europe, Germany was split in two and the great city of Berlin was divided by the wall. The wall that, for decades, separated family members from one another. The wall that meant the final stop for fundamental rights and freedoms. The wall that ruthlessly ended the lives of many of those trying to get to the other side.  All of this happened in the heart of Europe. For younger generations, this may now seem someunwhat unreal and even very distant, but you do not have to look at European maps further back than the 1980s to understand that it was not so long ago when Europe looked very different to how it looks today. But, over time, the will of the people seeking freedom, seeking human rights and seeking prosperity, prevailed.  It all became real in Berlin. It literally tore down the wall. This was the wind of change that swept across Europe and resulted in the collapse of the Iron Curtain. In Europe this paved the way for the deepening of European integration and similarly it paved the way for the enlargement of the European Union, of our precious Union. Ladies and gentlemen! Despite this great change, which was achieved 30 years ago by the courageous and decisive action of the peoples on the then east side of the Iron Curtain, we are facing challenges in Europe. Some of the achievements in the European Union are perhaps too self-evident. Around the world, we are seeing tendencies to build new walls rather than tear them down.  We are seeing signs that genuine international cooperation is being called into question. In such a turbulent and unpredictable period, it is good to return to the basics and recall the fundamental values that led to a great change 30 years ago. That is why I am proud to say here in the European Parliament that democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights must be defended time and again, because they are the cornerstones of the European Union. I would like to make it quite clear that authoritarianism, totalitarianism or nationalism must never be our answer. Our choice should always be freedom. Our choice should always be democracy, and our choice should always be human rights.  Mr Schäuble, you said that we share the same values. That's right. But not only us, but the whole world. These values are the values of the whole world, recognized by the United Nations.  Ladies and gentlemen! "Now what belongs together is growing together." When the Berlin Wall fell, these were the wise words of the former Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany, Willy Brandt, who was also formerly the mayor of West Berlin and had seen the European division in a very concrete way. I firmly believe that the message of unity is also the key to the success of the European Union. We can only be strong together, and we need a United Europe, not a Europe that divides.  The fall of the Berlin Wall holds the promise of a united Europe.

text: I have received a request from the GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats to wind up the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Bolivia with the tabling of motions for resolutions, which would be put to the vote at the next part-session.

name: Leopoldo López Gil
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, there was no coup d'eer. There's no coup d'eer. Evo Morales is solely responsible for the situation in Bolivia. In 2016 Morales lost a referendum to support his re-election. He skipped the Constitution, which wouldn't let him run for new elections. He obstructed the rule of law in his country. He organized the OAS-supervised elections in 2005, and asked the OAS for oversight. On 10 November, the OAS issued the findings of its audit of the electoral process. He declared that process invalid for fraud. We must call things by name to prevent realities from being distorted. Allegations that there were only failures in the electoral system constitute a lack of respect for Bolivian society. We are faced with a planned action with the sole objective of remaining in power against sovereign will. The efforts of Bolivian society and the international community calling for verifiable new elections have triumphed. Bolivia needs a constitutional exit from its crisis. For this you need guarantees. It is required, if the conditions are appropriate, for the European Union to assist and collaborate by sending an election observation mission, as established by Mrs Mogherini.

text: – Mr President, I would be against it, given the nature of what it will end up being like. I also was in La Paz for the election. This is a coup d’état. It’s an abuse of human rights. This House is forever talking about all three, and interference in elections, but when it happens in this case, they actually like it. This House needs to make up its mind what it likes and what it doesn’t. We will oppose the resolution.

name: Christine Anderson
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, I would like to thank the I am asking for the agenda to be extended to include the following item: violence against women – the situation in women's shelters. Unfortunately, women are increasingly victims of domestic violence and victims of sexual exploitation by cross-border trafficking in human beings. In their desperate situation, they seek shelter in women's shelters. However, it is not uncommon for them to experience that they cannot find the protection they had hoped for and desperately needed due to exhausted reception capacities. We are literally leaving these women in the rain. We must not only monitor their fates in committees – as, for example, in the hearing of the LIBE and FEMM committees, where I learned of a young Eastern European woman who was lured to Italy under false pretenses, forcibly prostituted there, found only temporary protection in a women's shelter before she was finally forced into homelessness.
