name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you for this opportunity to exchange views on the important issue of children’s rights.  This subject is very close to my heart. Thus I note with great pleasure the attention the European Parliament is giving to the 30th anniversary of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. In Finland we will celebrate this special day with different events, among which children will take over the government and work together with Ministers, including myself, on 20 November. The European Union recognises every child as a right holder and seeks to promote the protection of the rights of the child throughout the world.  Children’s rights are enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and they are the subject of particular attention when the application of the Charter is reviewed by the Council every year.  The Presidency conclusions of October 2018 addressed the rights of categories of children who are extremely vulnerable, such as Roma children and children in migration. Funding from the Rights, Equality and Citizenship Programme, and the Justice Programme, allows Member States’ institutions, as well as actors from civil society, to bring forward important projects related to children’s rights. We are confident that this focus will be maintained also for the programmes to be agreed in the framework of the next multiannual financial framework.  At the same time, the European Union is committed to mainstreaming human rights, including children’s rights, across all policy sectors in the context of its external action, as reaffirmed in the global strategy. In all policies affecting children, the main principle should be to ensure the best interests of the child.  The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, of which we celebrate the 30th anniversary, is the most widely ratified human rights treaty in history. All EU Member States are party to it. The Convention and its three optional protocols constitute the primary international standards in the promotion and protection of the rights of the child. The EU will continue to support and encourage partner countries to ratify and implement these instruments. The Convention on the Rights of the Child has been instrumental in improving children’s lives across the world ever since its adoption. Many challenges still remain.  Millions of children are on the move, uprooted from their homes as migrants, refugees, internally displaced, separated from their parents and care givers, raised in institutions or used as soldiers in armed conflict. They are trapped in forced labour and thus denied their rights to education and play.  Violence, abuse, poverty and discrimination, which children are exposed to, this particularly vulnerable group, also continue to persist. Determined to respond to all these challenges and to reconfirm its commitment to the rights of all children, in 2017 the EU updated its guidelines for the promotion and protection of the rights of the child.  The guidelines are grounded in a rights-based approach and their guiding principle is to leave no child behind, in line with the 2030 agenda on sustainable development.  The Council considers it important that these guidelines promote a systems—strengthening approach by identifying all the necessary measures, structures and actors which need to be in place to protect all the rights of all children, including, and especially, those in the most vulnerable and marginalised situations. In its conclusions of 2017 the Council reaffirmed the importance of promoting gender equality between all boys and girls by paying particular attention to addressing gender—based discrimination and violence, including sexual violence and ensuring the empowerment of girls, because it is often girls who are left furthest behind.  The EU is committed to fighting all forms of harmful practices to which girls are especially exposed, for instance child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation.  The 30th anniversary of the United Nations Convention is an opportunity to celebrate the progress achieved, but also to look at what still needs to be done. It is time to get ready for the newly emerging challenges, such as the threat of bullying, online as well as offline, and the protection of children in situations of conflict and displacement due to the climate crisis.  In multilateral fora, the EU has been very active on children’s rights and is determined to keep the issue prominently on the international agenda. The European Union has had longstanding cooperation with a group of Latin—American and Caribbean countries. An example of this is the annual resolutions presented at the United Nations Human Rights Council and the United Nations General Assembly’s Third Committee. This year, during the March session of the Human Rights Council, the theme of the resolution was empowering children with disabilities for the enjoyment of their human rights, including through inclusive education. The topic of the resolution recently presented at the United Nations General Assembly Third Committee is children without parental care. Honourable President, honourable Members, as set out in the Convention on the Rights of the Child, children’s rights are universal. Universal is also the experience of being a child. In the words of Antoine De Saint—Exupéry, all grown—ups were once children. Those who are children today are also the leaders of tomorrow. If their full potential is realised, they can be the greatest agents of change and sustainable development in their communities and globally.  The European Union will continue to stand up for the rights of every child to reach their full potential, in line with the Convention and its optional protocols.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, this year we mark the 30th anniversary of the adoption of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. We often speak about its revolutionary character, as it contributed to change in the way the world looked at children. They are not only seen as a group of people who need protection. They are also seen as rights-holders who can play an active role in society. We see this very strongly in the climate change protests and the marches all around the world. Children are making their voices heard and are demanding that world leaders act to tackle climate change. And in the EU we have made the protection and promotion of children’s rights a priority over the past years. All EU Member States are party to the Convention. The rights of the child are enshrined in the European Charter for Fundamental Rights, which binds the EU institutions in our work, and Member States when they are implementing EU law. We have a strong body of law in several areas of EU competence, which ensures the protection of children’s rights. For example, we have the Directive on Combating the Sexual Abuse and Sexual Exploitation of Children, the whole body of law in the area of asylum and we have the Victims’ Rights Directive and the Directive on procedural safeguards for children who are suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings. In addition to EU law, we have progressed significantly in putting children higher on the political agenda at EU level. We also have funding available for the protection of children’s rights under our Rights, Equality and Citizenship Programme, in addition to all EU funds, which can contribute to this objective, if confirmed. We published a communication on the protection of children in migration in 2017 and we monitor regularly how the Member States and EU agencies implement the actions proposed in it. However, we still have 25 million children living in poverty in the European Union. We have children who are victims of abuse, exploitation and trafficking in human beings. We have children who suffer from mental health problems, who are victims of bullies and who commit suicide. We still have a long way to go to make sure that all children, regardless of their origin, socio-economic background and migration status, can fully enjoy their rights. I very much welcome the attention that the European Parliament has consistently put on children’s rights. We have worked hand in hand for this objective over the past five years, and as you know, the incoming Commission is committed to continue working on the protection of children’s rights. Dubravka Šuica, the Vice-President-designate for Democracy and Demography, has been entrusted with the preparation of a new comprehensive strategy for the rights of the child and with the delivery of a child guarantee. I look forward to collaborating with her on this important matter.

name: Ewa Kopacz
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child has profoundly changed the view of our societies as children as true holders of rights. The Convention has contributed both to highlighting the exceptional importance of the rights of the child and to ensuring that Member States and their governments recognise their responsibilities in this area. Knowing precisely that children's rights are human rights, we have special obligations. We have a duty to promote and protect the rights of the child, both in our internal and external policies. First, children have the right to childhood, to physical and mental development in a safe and healthy environment. They have the right to education and services to help them become independent, happy and healthy adults. Children have the right to family life. Finally, they have the right to protection against all forms of violence, discrimination and exploitation.  Approaching the 30th anniversary of the Convention and appreciating all the progress made to uphold these rights, it is also time to reflect on what has not yet been achieved. According to Eurostat, children are still the age group most at risk of poverty or social exclusion. Violence against children remains a real threat, both offline and online, both in the social and family environment.  More needs to be done to ensure that judicial systems meet the specific needs of children and defend their interests in dealing with the law, treat them individually rather than objectically. Finally, as parliamentarians, we have a duty to our citizens, especially the youngest ones, to cooperate with the Commission and the Council, as well as with international organisations, as well as with the children themselves, because the voice of children should be heard.

name: Claude Moraes
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child is the most widely ratified of international human rights treaties and, as has been said by the Commission and the Council, this is an extremely important anniversary. It is self-evident. We have 100 million children in the European Union, 20% of the population. In developing countries it is over 40%. But today, what we are talking about is the clear advance we have made since the Convention, but also the huge challenges we have. I heard the Commissioner talking about the strong body of law that we currently have, and I believe that what we should be doing today, in honour of this anniversary and all of the many people from across society who have worked in this area, is to understand that this strong body of law on sexual abuse and exploitation, victims’ rights, procedural safeguards – I would add the Child Guarantee to fight child poverty – all of these things must come alive and they must mean something to the millions of children who face challenges. I would say, in the final seconds of my contribution, that just one example of this is that, globally, at least 30 million children have migrated across borders or have been forcibly displaced. One-third of the refugees and migrants who have arrived in Europe are children, some of them unaccompanied. We need to understand that the guidelines which were grounded in a rights-based approach must also address how they are being treated. There are 4 000 unaccompanied children in Greece right now, enduring unsafe and inhumane and degrading treatment. This is something that is a challenge for the whole of the European Union, both for our children, who are doing well in the European Union, but those who are not doing well. This is truly an internationalist anniversary and an internationalist convention and we should do everything to honour it in the European Union.

name: Hilde Vautmans
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Madam Minister, Commissioner, children are our highest asset. If you touch the kids, you touch our being. Today is a happy day: on 20 November we celebrate the 30th anniversary of the Convention on the Rights of the Child, which has now been signed by 190 countries. So we should be celebrating. I also think that we have achieved a great deal. But I would also like to point out today that we are still failing, because unfortunately we cannot yet say that the rights of the child are universal. Just look at the figures: one in three children under the age of five is malnourished, despite the right to food; almost one in five children lives in areas affected by violence and conflict, despite the right to a safe home; 262 million children do not go to school, despite the right to education. Every day, children are sexually exploited, despite the right to protection from exploitation. Children worldwide make up more than half of the refugees. Mrs Jourová, you know that I am making a point of this: more than 10 000 unaccompanied child asylum seekers are currently missing in Europe! Yesterday, a conference in this context was called a baffling figure. When we ask what happened to these children, Europol says (in 2019!): they are in another country without us knowing, or they are being sexually exploited, or they have ended up in child labour, or, finally, they are being killed for their organs. Let us use this 30th anniversary of the Convention on the Rights of the Child to step up our commitment and to tackle these issues of asylum and migration. Children are children, wherever they are.

name: Saskia Bricmont
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, thirty years after its adoption, the International Convention on the Rights of the Child is a more widely ratified international text, since only two countries - the United States and Somalia - have not done so. This text is based on four fundamental principles: non-discrimination, the best interests of the child, the right to live, survive and develop, and respect for the views of the child. Thirty years to build a world fit for children. Have we done that? There is no denying the halving of child mortality for children under five, as well as the number of children without access to adequate food, and this is also due to the fieldwork that has been carried out and which should be welcomed. But, on the test of the facts, this binding text becomes a pipe dream, as has been pointed out. Violations of children's rights are legion in Europe as in the world: hotspots, detention of migrant children, 30,000 children from migration missing in Europe, non-compliance with the right to private and family life for LGBT children and families, responsibility for European children of foreign fighters, the deaths of one in four children due to environmental risks, the risk of poverty for one in four children, child labour - 150 million children are affected. In short, a world where discrimination related to LGBT gender, race, disability and other aspects prevents effective equality. Respecting the rights of the child enshrined in the Convention means enabling children to become critical, active, creative, responsible and supportive citizens. We see it every day, all climate mobilizations, like Girls speak out, show that they want to get involved. Let us also open the doors of this assembly to them!

name: Jaak Madison
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and for the real, i would like to thank the – Mr President, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Van Rompuy, for his excellent work Thank you very much to the European Parliament. I think that the 30th anniversary of the adoption of the Convention on the Rights of the Child is a sign, which must certainly be emphasised. And the points that most countries around the world agreed on must also be emphasised. Most countries have also ratified it, or made a commitment to it. The first point says very clearly "for the purposes of the present Convention, a child means every human being" or every human being must be protected, including the lives of children. The European Court of Justice ruled a few years ago that human life begins from conception. This means that unborn children also have the right to life. There are now many countries in the European Union where, for example, 200 to 400 unborn children are taken from their lives compared to 1 000 live births, meaning that around one in three children do not have the right to life, which is certainly not in line with this convention and is certainly not in line with the European values that we are trying to defend here. The second and third points are interlinking, especially as regards children used in the human business. When we talk about surrogacy, which is common in so many countries that have ratified this convention, such as Georgia, Russia, Ukraine, the United States, children are being used for commercial purposes to sell to those who want to buy this child. Whether it's families who otherwise don't have children, or same-sex people who are just trying to satisfy their own shortcomings or their sense of misfortune. In Georgia, for example, there is a nice page like surrogacyforgay.com, and unfortunately these children do not have the right to choose the family they are sold to, and they also have no right to a mother-father, which should be the human right of every child. Thank you very much!

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab More than 40 years ago, Poland initiated the Convention on the Rights of the Child and submitted its first version internationally. Although the Convention is the most widely ratified human rights document in the world, unfortunately its provisions are repeatedly violated. The most important right of the child is, ladies and women, the right to life, only when it is guaranteed can we take care of fundamental rights such as the right to security, education, civil or social rights. That right to life is guaranteed by Article 6, which provides that a child, because of his or her physical or mental immaturity, requires special care and care, in particular legal protection both before and after birth. Ladies and gentlemen, in this context, I ask you to reflect: is the issue of the right of the child to life raised at all in the European Parliament? Unfortunately, under the term reproductive law, abortion is promoted, which is a violation of the child's right to life and is contrary to the provisions of the Convention, which you are praising today.

name: Anne-Sophie Pelletier
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, all children are vulnerable and on the 30th anniversary of the Convention on the Rights of the Child, I would like to think of the most vulnerable: intersex children undergoing genital mutilation, whose parents should be given informed information; young girls who experience particular violence solely because of their gender; unaccompanied minors, abandoned on the street or parked in survivor camps; children locked up in detention centres, who no longer look at their notebooks but look at planes; and, finally, children with disabilities, who are deprived of education for lack of personalised support. In this regard, Victor Hugo said that a child you teach is an adult you earn. So, ladies and gentlemen, even though there are few of us in this Parliament this afternoon, and I regret it, I ask you to think of these children and to think of all the children whose rights are being violated.

name: Laura Ferrara (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and Adolescents is considered to be the most widely ratified Human Rights Treaty in history and has contributed, by inspiring laws and policies, to improving the lives of children.  However, the Convention cannot yet be said to be fully implemented. Throughout the world, children and adolescents in different contexts suffer serious violations of their rights, for example through sexual and labour exploitation, or are involved in armed conflicts and migratory flows, and are forced not to attend or leave school, become victims of violence, abuse, age and gender discrimination. The situation worsens if you belong to particularly vulnerable social groups, as in the case of refugees and the disabled, and new threats also come from the web.  Intolerable situations are also occurring in the European Union, with millions of children living in low-income families, where living conditions are unacceptable. One in four European children is at risk of poverty or social exclusion.  The European Union is called upon to act with one voice in countering this reality. Significant investment is needed to adopt a 'child guarantee' system, enabling every child in poverty to access basic social services, such as health care, adequate nutrition, decent housing and free education.  Investing in children, inside and outside Europe, means investing in the future of the world. No one should be left behind and the fight against child poverty must become a battle of civilisation for the affirmation of the fundamental rights of every child.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, with the Treaty on Accession to the European Union, Article 3 commits us to protecting the rights of the child and promoting the rights of the child.  If we know some facts, for example that many rights are still not respected around the world today, according to UNICEF data, if it is true that 262 million children and young people are still not enrolled in schools today, if the fact that 650 million girls and women are married before the age of 18 is correct, if the fact is correct or estimate that in 2040 one in four children will live in areas with extremely limited water resources , then there is no other way than to approach this topic seriously. So not just talk, but do something.  On the occasion of the 30th anniversary of the Convention on the Rights of the Child, we have a unique opportunity to place children's rights, the Convention and its importance for global development and coexistence in a high place of the international agenda, but also of the European agenda. As Ms. Commissioner Jourova said, my task will be to take into account, among others, the rights of the child in the European Commission, in particular this Convention and the Children's Guarantee for Children.  It was this Parliament that initiated this idea and we will perfect it in the Commission together with our colleagues, but we also still have a long-term strategy for children and I hope that we will work on this intensively and that we will finally move from these words to actions and that we will implement all that we have adopted so far, but also this existing United Nations Convention , which is very important, and thus enable our children not only a happy childhood, but also a happy future. And since the Conference on the Future of Europe is also one topic, then there is really a lot to do.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, the thirtieth anniversary of which is being celebrated in a few days' time, contains specific legal obligations for the signatory countries to promote, protect and respect children's rights, but it is still not fully implemented today.  In fact, there are still too many children in the world who are victims of physical and psychological violence, abuse and exploitation, and modern technologies amplify the threats to children. Not only in the poorest countries, not only on Europe's doorstep, but on European territory itself, almost 25 million children are at risk of poverty or social exclusion and 30 000 migrant children have disappeared once they arrive on European territory.  A strong Union must concern itself first and foremost with the most vulnerable, and these are children in our society. More needs therefore to be done at European level to give concrete form to the Convention. It is essential to implement the 'child guarantee', part of the social pillar of the Union, in order to eradicate child poverty and marginalisation, which deprive children of care and educational and cultural opportunities.  We need to think about the creation of a European Centre for the Protection of Minors, in order to coordinate the fight against the most serious transnational crimes to which they are subjected, and I believe that the time is ripe to set up a Special Representative of the European Union for the Rights of the Child, in order to ensure that in all the policies of the Union and the Member States, as laid down in Article 24 of the Nice Charter, we will be able to make sure that, in all the policies of the Union and the Member States, as laid down in Article 24 of the Nice Charter, we are able to take account of the fact that the european Union has a special representative for the rights of the child. , the best interests of the child are always considered pre-e.

name: Laurence Farreng (Renew).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Madam Minister, today I would like to warn you in particular about children's exposure to climate change, a major angle to be taken into account in protecting children's rights. According to Unicef, 99% of climate change-related deaths occur in developing countries and children account for 80% of these deaths. According to Unicef, destabilization of our climate could cause an additional 250,000 child deaths by 2100. It's intolerable. Everywhere, children are most affected by pollution because their bodies are more vulnerable. That is why Europe must put the child at the heart of its environmental strategies. We must take active action against climate change and guarantee children, all children, a right to essential resources: clean air, clean water, adequate, balanced and pollution-free food. We must make children the first actors of change, listening to them and recognizing their word, integrating them into decisions. Finally, we must invest heavily in education, a key factor in the fight against climate change, and adopt new practices.

name: Diana Riba i Giner (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, the Convention on the Rights of the Child stipulates that when children are separated from their parents, they have the right to maintain regular contact. This is especially important in minors whose parents are in prison in pre-trial custody or sentenced. According to Fair Trials, there are more than 120,000 people in pre-trial detention in the European Union. The same organisation has denounced the clear abuse by several Member States of this precautionary measure. Pre-trial detention should be the last coercive spring for the effects it already has on people who suffer from it. But, moreover, it has very difficult consequences on a forgotten collective: minors. Children of imprisoned parents who, according to the Council of Europe report, are estimated to amount to two million children. They hold the law and the future of our societies. For this reason, I call on the European Commission to take into account the right of minors in a future legislative proposal of minimum standards for prisons and conditions of detention.

name: Lucia Vuolo (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the right to life, protection and development: these are the cornerstones of the Convention on the Rights of the Child.  From here I want to address not children, but those parents who think that a smartphone is the solution to every problem. I ask you to return to being fathers and mothers: it is in the family that the child grows and it is in this context that the child learns from the gestures of the parents and not from a game.  In the age of cyberdependence and child baiting through playful platforms, we also think about how to give exclusive and built support to parents. If the autonomy of individual states remains autonomous, it would be interesting to work on European programmes aimed at parents and not just adolescents, or we encourage national legislation to be more friendly than fathers and mothers.  The constant presence of a father and a mother is the first piece of a good and correct education of our children. Nothing but smartphones!

name: Lucia Ďuriš Nicholsonová (ECR).
text: – Madam President, we have had the Convention on the Rights of the Child in force for more than thirty years. Both the European Commission and the European Parliament have adopted a number of resolutions and recommendations during that time. We are building a social Europe, and yet the most vulnerable are disappearing somewhere. Children. In the European Union, one quarter of children are at risk of poverty or social exclusion. In five Member States of the European Union, 90% of children from Roma settlements are directly at risk of poverty and are being included in special schools in a discriminatory way. Children with disabilities in many Member States are not allowed to attend school at all because inclusive education does not work. A paediatric cancer patient in Slovakia does not have the same access to treatment as a paediatric cancer patient, for example in Germany. In some Member States, paediatric autistic people wait up to nine months for diagnosis and have almost no access to therapy. Why do we have a convention if a woman, a single mother, with a sick child, often falls into a state of material need. And he's working out if they're going to have anything to eat tomorrow. We are not doing enough and we need to improve. We need to start measuring the results of social measures in the individual Member States of the European Union, and then, on data rather than words, to start building a Europe in which children have real, not just paper rights.

name: Miroslav Radačovský (NI).
text: – Madam President, as a former judge dealing in practice with the rights of minor children and the duties of parents, but also of the state towards them, I will start a little unconventionally. Every man has the right to live in partnership with a man or a woman. Every woman has the right to live in partnership with a man or a woman. It depends on their decision. However, and this is very important, every child has the right to a father and a mother. Every child has a natural right to live in a family of a man and a woman. We have a duty to do everything we can to ensure that this inconseparable right, expressed in the Convention for the Protection of the Rights of the Child, expressed in the laws of national parliaments, is never and never withdrawn.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE).
text: – Dear Madam President, Dear Colleagues, The UN Convention on the Rights of the Child recognises that children should have an equal chance of access to education. In fact, we can only help children trapped outside of education if, following a strategic decision, education is at the heart of development policy. It is a sad fact that, despite international conventions, according to Unesco, 30 million school-age children still do not go to school, only in the sub-Saharan region. That's 25 percent. It is in our common interest to do something so that these children can learn. Without education, Madam President, there is no chance, no chance of meaningfully reducing or combating poverty. Quality education underpins democracy, peace and economic growth. We must real admit that, without expanding access to education, we are completely underdogs to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals by 2030. We can only act effectively for children's rights by helping them in a family environment and strengthening the family environment. Helping children with education also gives their families a chance to improve their circumstances. If we really want a 21st century sustainable development policy, we need to reduce the numbers I have mentioned by developing a development policy around education. It's a strategic issue. This is our unfinished work in developing countries. Without education, poverty cannot be overcome.

name: Bettina Vollath (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her (Start of speech when micro is switched off) ... that children are seen not only as future citizens with equal rights, but as people with their own rights. Precisely because they have special needs, a fundamental paradigm shift towards a society that respects and values the diversity of all its individuals is necessary. The foundation stone for this was laid 30 years ago with the UN Convention. I would like to thank all those who have already advocated this convention and invite those who have not done so so to become part of this children's rights lobby. Because the implementation of the convention is a drilling of hard boards. We need to focus on what the global challenges of the coming decades – such as digital technologies, environmental changes, long-standing violent conflicts, or intergenerational poverty – mean for children's lives and opportunities. And we need to act urgently. Within the EU alone, 28 million children live in poor families. Although we contribute 22.8% to global economic performance, one in four children in the EU is at risk of poverty with all risks. There is a lot going wrong with children's rights around the world: war, displacement, violence, genital mutilation, climate change, forced labour, forced marriage. Too often, children don't get a chance at all. I therefore want a Europe that will be a shining example of children's rights. As the English writer Charles Dickens said, children experience nothing as sharp and bitter as injustice. Let us save the children from sharpness and bitterness in their lives!

name: Dragoş Pîslaru (Renew).
text: – Madam President, 30 years ago world leaders met in the United Nations General Assembly and demonstrated a historic commitment to children everywhere by adopting the Convention on the Rights of the Child.  Although the Convention is the United Nations document ratified by most countries, the real situation does not give us so many reasons for celebration: one in four children of the European Union, and in Romania almost half of children, are at risk of poverty and social exclusion. 250,000 children are reported missing each year in the European Union, 30 000 children of migrants and refugees from the European continent most often become victims of human trafficking and social exploitation.  These are figures that should lead us to ask whether in three decades we have done enough to identify vulnerabilities and prevent them, whether we have paid due attention to those who do not have the voice to be able to speak for ourselves, and whether we need to invest more in guaranteeing and protecting fundamental rights of health care, education, decent living conditions , adequate nutrition.  For this reason, I personally have very high expectations of the children's guarantee and will work hard to ensure that it is properly implemented and produces viable results.

name: Tilly Metz (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, millions of children in Europe suffer from rare diseases, children who cannot or have difficulty moving to see, breathe, understand or whose immune system is weakened. Three quarters of rare diseases are pediatric diseases. However, within the European Union for these children and their families, it is always a journey for the combatant to obtain a diagnosis in a reasonable time and to have access to appropriate and reimbursed treatment. Also, in the field of research, rare diseases of children remain the poor parent. While we cannot just decline the results of adults on children, I therefore ask the Commission to hear the voices of these young patients and to ensure better information, better coordination, more effective exchanges and comprehensive care of these children and their families, as well as research support specifically focused on rare childhood diseases.

name: Christine Anderson (ID).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We are celebrating 30 years of the Convention on the Rights of the Child. They are designed to protect the survival, development, non-discrimination and interests of children. But we are not doing that. What is the use of parliamentary lip service when technologies are promoted and green ideologues dream of e-mobiles whose batteries have a longer life expectancy than the deplorable children who have to scrape the rare earths out of the ground for their production? What is the use of parliamentary lip service when children are disturbed, even traumatised, by disgusting sexual practices in kindergartens and schools in the name of tolerance and diversity? What is the use of parliamentary lip service when the well-sounding intention of protecting children's rights is nothing more than depriving parents of their natural right to care for, care and educate their children?  To all the ideologically blinded supporters of this beautiful new world gathered here in plenary, I say: hands off our children! Ceterum censeo: A parliament that hides only behind lip service and works like this must be abolished.

name: Elżbieta Rafalska (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The 30th anniversary of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child is a good thing to answer the question of whether we protect children better or protect lives better and whether we care enough to improve children's well-being. In Europe, a quarter of children are at risk of poverty; countries where one in two children is at risk of poverty. I can tell you how in my country we are trying to combat child poverty and exclusion effectively. It was thanks to our programs introduced by the Government of Law and Justice that poverty in Poland ceased to have a child's face. In 2015-2017, extreme child poverty fell from 9% to 4.7%. We have effectively reduced poverty in large families. This means that you can, that is, you have to want to put in place a comprehensive social policy that effectively reduces child poverty.

name: Ignazio Corrao (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to take this opportunity to denounce a particular and worrying situation that affects European children and parents in Japan: in the large Asian country, our important partner in many respects, around 150 000 children, many of them Europeans, are taken from one of their parents every year, preventing the other from ing any future contact with the child. The situation is very serious when we consider that, in Japanese law, there is no shared custody of children. The abduction of children by a parent is not considered a crime and there is in fact no legal consequence against the foster parent who does not comply with the sentences. All this is done in defiance of the rights guaranteed to children in the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, ratified by Japan in 1994, and in violation of the right of parents to maintain a link with their children. In the face of this violation, we cannot, and cannot remain silent, all the more so when it directly affects the citizens of Europe. Many parents, mostly Italians, Germans and French, expect the problem to be recognised and discussed, they expect concrete action, in short, they expect support and help from the European Union. This is the case, for example, with Vincent and Tommaso, holders of a right of access recognised in the judgment, who are struggling every day to be able to see their children again and who have contacted us in the hope of having answers. That is why I am calling today for a statement to a clear commitment from the European Commission. I hope that this case can be highlighted in the resolution to be voted on in Strasbourg and that the instrument of the recent trade agreement and strategic partnership between Japan and the European Union will be used to call on the Japanese authorities to restore the rule of law as soon as possible.

name: Karlo Ressler (PPE).
text: – Dear Vice President, children have always been the most vulnerable group of any society. Today, thirty years after the adoption of the Convention, but in one world of accelerated technological and social change, this may be particularly evident. And that is why society plays a special role in protecting the best interests of the child, but also in creating a positive environment in which every child will be able to develop as a complete person.  Therefore, and as a father, I recognize the important role of society in supporting parents. This includes additional investments in nursegers, kindergartens, schools, educational and health institutions, but the family environment largely determines the environment in which the child develops, and therefore it is primarily necessary to help parents, especially in the first most sensitive months and years of life.  In a modern democratic society, parents, not the state, bear the main role in raising children. It means responsibility, but so does entitlement. And in a world where digital innovation is an integral part of life, we must not forget the emotional, psychological and social aspect of a child's development because that is exactly what no technology can replace. We need to do a lot more here within the European Union to better protect children.

name: Javier Moreno Sánchez (S&D).
text: – Madam President, today's debate and the resolution we will vote on in Strasbourg cannot and should not be just an occasion to commemorate the 30th anniversary of the Convention on the Rights of the Child.  It is true that we have made progress in protecting minors over the past thirty years; child mortality has been reduced and the number of children without access to school has halved, but the rights of too many children are still being violated.  Ladies and gentlemen, in Europe 25 million children are at risk of poverty or social exclusion. We call for the european child guarantee for children at risk of poverty to be created as soon as possible and to be offered health care and free access to education and other social services.  Outside our borders, some 420 million children live in conflict-affected areas. Many of them flee poverty and war—alone or with their families—seeking refuge, asylum, and protection. We must commit ourselves to the protection of their rights, starting with the right to life and development of the child.  We want children's rights to be integrated into development cooperation policies and humanitarian aid and to ensure adequate funding of programmes dedicated to the protection of children, and we call for the reform of the Common European Asylum System to ensure the immediate protection of unaccompanied minors arriving in Europe.  Acting faster and more decisively is the best way to celebrate this anniversary.

name: Lucy Nethsingha (Renew).
text: – Madam President, I’m delighted that we are here celebrating the 30th anniversary of this Convention. I’m also delighted that the Commission and the Council have recognised the particular vulnerability of some groups of children, particularly those caught up in conflict, migrant children, Roma children and those with disabilities. We have a duty to ensure we do all we can to ensure that there are stable and usable routes for migrant and refugee children to be reunited with safe family members, in safe countries. And all Member States must recognise their responsibility to assist with protecting these especially vulnerable children. We also have a responsibility in this Parliament to take seriously the rights of children to be heard and at this time, there are children across the world who are raising their voices to be heard by politicians and policy-makers. The climate strikes, led by Greta Thunberg and involving millions of children, are the clearest example of children uniting to make their voices heard, and they are right. The challenges of climate change will have a huge impact on our children, and we in this Parliament have a duty to listen and to respond to their concerns, to do everything possible to ensure that they are not the generation who inherit a depleted and declining world. Finally, I want to touch on our obligation to protect children in the digital age. There are some very clear areas where the Internet and digital world put children at particular risk; issues of sexual exploitation being an obvious example. Protecting our children should include ensuring they have accurate and reliable information on many topics.

name: Ciarán Cuffe (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, the question I ask is: how can we more actively involve children in our work and in the laws that we shape? I’m pleased that the European Parliament has a coordinator on children’s rights, Ewa Kopacz. Previously we had two Irish women, Mary Banotti, and indeed your good self, Madam President, occupying that role. But I believe we can do more.  Article 24 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union says that the views of children ‘shall be taken into consideration on matters which concern them’. And the UN Convention’s Article 12 says the same. We must ensure that we actively seek the views of children in proposed laws that will affect them, because if the voice of the child is not heard, they are more likely to face discrimination. Most European children cannot vote and are particularly vulnerable. Refugees even more so. It’s no accident that, in my own country, almost 4 000 children are now living without a home in homeless accommodation, according to the Department of Housing statistics. So we need to ensure that children’s voices are heard. Finally, just to pay tribute to our national broadcaster, RTE, which has a hearing on climate change for children in our parliament this Friday. Let’s repeat that here.

name: Mathilde Androuët (ID).
text: Madam President, this anniversary of the Convention on the Rights of the Child is an opportunity for us to take stock of the situation. In Europe, 250,000 children are missing. In France, for the year 2017, out of 49,000 disappearances, 1,328 were considered worrying. Trafficking in children is a cruel reality for the European Union. Between 2014 and 2016, more than 10,000 migrant children disappeared after registering with a European administration. In Belgium, in 2017, 618 migrant children disappeared. In migrant centres in Greece, 40% of the population is made up of children. This is not due to chance: the opening of borders and the inability of the European administration to control the flow of migrants has caused a real catastrophe. Many minors find themselves completely isolated in Europe. These children are exposed to the worst networks: paedophile networks, organ trafficking, crime and burglary networks that are widespread in the suburbs of Ile-de-France, where I come from. As mayor and as a Member of Parliament, this date is important: it calls us not to forget that the ideology of mass uprooting advocated by the European Union and the United Nations is directly responsible... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Assita Kanko (ECR).
text: – Mr President, every child deserves a future and the freedom to choose what that future looks like. Everything we decide in this Parliament is helping to shape those choices. Our policy on the economy, the environment, the single market, trade and our engagement with third countries is building a framework for that future. Yet, often the best way to improve a child’s life is to listen to what they have to say. As policy-makers, we need to make sure we do this. We cannot always allow what is urgent to overtake what is important in the long run and throw out the concerns of the young. As we saw with the ECR Sakharov Prize nominees and finalists, the Restorers, these girls were determined to shape their own future by giving other girls of their age the freedom to choose what happens to their bodies and to their destinies. Let me share a WhatsApp message they sent me after their nomination. They said: ‘we are just back from class. Being able to be part of the people who are considered for the prize itself was a big win for the team and an affirmation that we are not alone’. So I would like to call for us to speak more with each other and achieve more of this kind of hope.

name: Peter Pollák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the Convention on the Rights of the Child was adopted 30 years ago, but even after 30 years, in fact in many countries, this right is not respected. There are still a large number of children whose rights are poorly protected. Among these children there are also a number of Roma children. Many children are still denied the right of access to quality and inclusive education. Education systems in some countries, such as Slovakia, are unable to educate Roma children so that they are subsequently qualified. These children go to special classes and schools that are designed for children with intellectual disabilities. However, these children have no mental disability. Their handicap is that they come from poor families. We can't afford to leave any child aside just because they come from poor backgrounds. These children are not only denied the right to education, but also the right to a dignified life, because without education they will not be able to fulfil their potential and apply to the labour market. The European Union cannot afford to waste this potential. The European Commission is currently conducting administrative proceedings against three countries. These proceedings concern discrimination against Roma children in education. Furthermore, Slovakia is threatened with an action before the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg if it does not submit a concrete plan to the European Commission within two months on how it intends to put an end to this situation. It is also our task and duty in the European Parliament to think about the well-being of these children and to remind governments such as mine in Slovakia that their responsibility is to create equal opportunities for all citizens, including children from Roma communities.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Mr President, next Wednesday, our Parliament will host a high-level conference to celebrate the 30th anniversary of the Convention on the Rights of the Child. It is undeniable that in thirty years progress has been made in many areas: access to health, education and legal protection. Yet, despite this progress, more than 1.5 million children worldwide are held in prison, in deplorable conditions, deprived of education, exposed to abuse and without contact with the outside world. However, all studies agree that no form of detention is in the best interests of the child. Thousands of children are still on migratory routes which, in the worst case, end in death, in the desert, in the seas, victims of trafficking. But often they also end in confinement, again without a guarantee of protection. Even the European Court of Justice considers this to be inhuman and degrading treatment. Also in Europe, 19% of children are at risk of poverty and deprived of basic rights. Colleagues, the right to the protection of the child is therefore a moral obligation that must be imposed on all, before any other consideration.

name: Mounir Satouri (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, one in four children under the age of 18 is still at risk of poverty or social exclusion in the European Union. This simple statement suffices to conclude that the Union and our Member States are not complying with the International Convention on the Rights of the Child. The right to food, health, education and housing, all rights guaranteed and yet violated by poverty and its effects. The physical and psychological suffering of poverty is a violation of equality of opportunity. We must understand that by undermining the future of the poorest, we are mistreating our democracies. Discrimination is further reinforced when vulnerable people, such as Roma or migrants, are mentioned. In addition to the trauma of exile, there is precariousness or exclusion for children. Recently in France, Samira, a ten-year-old Ivorian woman who lost her mother in the crossing, escaped a forced return to Italy under the pretext of respecting Dublin. I expect the Commission to present an ambitious plan for effective respect for the rights of all children... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Beata Szydło (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by My country Poland was the initiator of the Convention on the Rights of the Child. A lot of good things have happened in these 30 years of operation and the fate of millions of children has improved, but there is still a great deal of work to be done, and certainly such a pressing problem, which we should also look at here in the European Parliament, is the issue of exclusion and poverty. I am proud that the Polish Government, the government I headed, which I led, has put in place effective family-based programmes that have solved the problem of child poverty in Poland, such as the 500+ family programme.  I believe that here together we will also be able to reflect on such effective solutions, and it is worth mentioning in this debate the words of my great compatriot Saint John Paul II, who said that caring for a child is the first and fundamental test of man-to-man attitudes.

name: Cindy Franssen (PPE).
text: Mr President, exactly 30 years ago, we demonstrated great ambitions with the Convention on the Rights of the Child, which is based on three pillars: protection, provision and participation. But the work isn't finished.  Let's start with the protection. We must protect our children from all forms of violence and abuse. One in five children is still the victim of some form of sexual violence. This is unacceptable! Mental health is another important concern. Children should be able to grow up carefree, without a psychological backpack for any reason.  Then there are the provisions, the fundamental social rights, the right to education, reception, health care and relaxation. Those who do not bet on young children risk losing an entire generation. The European Children's Guarantee must respond to this and we will follow suit.  And finally, there is participation. Children have an opinion. They must be heard and have a voice in decisions that concern them. We must take this into account in the development of our policy. Every child must be the norm for our political action. A marriage of thirty years is called a "pearl marriage". We must treat every child as a precious pearl. Let us work together to make children's rights a reality for all children.

name: Raphaël Glucksmann (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are celebrating the thirtieth anniversary of the International Convention on the Rights of the Child, but I have absolutely no heart for the celebrations. Just yesterday morning, a group of parents of students from Rennes wrote to me this: "Mariam, classmate of our children, Mariam, awakened by the police at 6 a.m., Mariam driving to the airport instead of heading to school, Mariam, put on a plane, Mariam expelled and out of school." Just yesterday morning, at exactly 10:10 a.m., Samira, ten, should also have been on the plane and deported. In France, we mobilized hundreds of thousands of citizens and obtained the annulment of his expulsion. Hundreds of thousands of citizens to make the authorities give way on a child. In France and Europe, thousands of Mariam and Samira are thus out of school and expelled. So, ladies and gentlemen, instead of celebrating the thirty years of the convention with hollow phrases and complacency, let us defend its founding principle, the best interests of the child, of every child.... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker).

name: Francisco Guerreiro (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the Convention on the Rights of the Child states in Article 19 that States should take all measures to protect the child against all forms of physical, mental, offence or abuse, neglect or careless treatment, ill-treatment or exploitation, including sexual abuse. However, according to data from the 2018 report on human trafficking within the European Union, between 2015 and 2016 there were 20,532 victims, of whom 23% were children. We are talking about 4,723 children who have been exploited by human trafficking networks, more than half of which have been trafficked for sexual exploitation. And here we can not fail to stress that the female sex is the most affected. This data is really alarming. Although there is already a strategy to eradicate trafficking in human beings in Europe, we need to increase efforts to combat this scourge effectively in the Member States too, severely punishing their perpetrators, and above all by protecting their victims.

name: Raffaele Stancanelli (ECR).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in celebrating the anniversary of the Convention on the Rights of the Child, defending children's rights means preserving our most precious asset.  They are not only our future, but they are also the most vulnerable part of our communities. That is why we must promote at all levels a culture of life that puts the new generations at the centre of our institutional action.  Nowadays, children are increasingly the subject of ideological demands, the result of the selfishness of adults who risk subverting the natural order.  As also enshrined in the Convention, the European Union must make greater efforts to enhance the value of the family, the fundamental unity of society and the natural environment for the growth of children. Families must receive the protection and care they need.  We must defend the rights of children to have a father and a mother, not a parent 1 and a parent 2, and above all we must combat harmful practices such as teaching gender theory in schools.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am very happy that together today we are commemorating the anniversary of such an important document as the Convention on the Rights of the Child, and I am also proud that it was one of the first international treaties ratified by the Czech and Slovak Federal Republics just after the fall of communism in our country.  A child is the greatest gift to the family, but also to society. And family is the best environment for raising a child. The child needs the care of both parents. This is confirmed by the Convention on the Rights of the Child. The child has the right to the care of both parents. Nowadays, it's sometimes forgotten. Even today, we should stress much more the role of the family. Her responsibility. State care starts where families cannot, fail, or for some reason simply children are without families. The aim should be to support functional and functioning families, i.e. to support young families and families who have and must care for their children.  The Convention on the Rights of the Child is still an up-to-date and unbeated document after 30 years. Maybe more than ever. Every child has the right to their family, go to school and develop in a favorable environment. But unfortunately, there are now children on the territory of the European Union, refugee children who do not have this right. And we should help them.

name: David Lega (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Some of the obvious things are so obvious that they should not have to be said. As obvious as children's rights and freedoms may be, the world unfortunately does not work so that they are self-evident to everyone, always and in all contexts. But for the vast majority, it goes without saying that all children are equal, that all children have the right to play, develop and learn and that all children have the right to be children.  These rules are also regulated in international law, in the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child – the so-called Convention on the Rights of the Child. It is with pleasure that I note that all the EU Member States have ratified the Convention on the Rights of the Child, and in Sweden it is very much to the credit of the Christian Democrats that it will now become Swedish law in 2020.  As MEPs, it is our duty to always defend and promote children's rights and freedoms, both within and outside the EU's borders. At the same time, I am not willing to compromise swedish children's far-reaching rights and freedoms or Swedish legislation in this area, with other countries. For it is not through compromises with national legislation that we best safeguard the rights of all children.

name: Ljudmila Novak (PPE).
text: – Mr President, children often suffer from mistakes, delusions and adult violence. The Convention protects the child and the rights of the child, and that is right for all children, no matter where they come from. For no one in this world has an exclusive right to this world and to prosperity. First of all, it is the right of children who are not to blame for the problems of this world. The year of the convention's 800m(200) convention coincides with the year of the fall of the Berlin Wall. And the best we can do for our children is to keep peace in Europe, to work together to make it possible. And when we enable the well-being of our children, we can also help the children of the world who find themselves in poverty or at risk. I therefore ask my colleagues who are tearing down Europe whether you are aware of what you can do to your children.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, 20 November will be the 30th anniversary of the Convention on the Rights of the Child. This states that every child has the right to education, a right to participation and to be protected against all forms of discrimination, as well as all forms of violence. Sadly, there’s still a long way to go to ensure that this is achieved for each and every one of the 2.2 billion children in the world.  A UN study published this month showed that at least 1.5 million children are incarcerated across the world. Approximately 330 000 children in 77 countries, including in EU Member States, are held in immigration detention centres. This is unacceptable. We’ve seen the distressing images of children in cages on the US-Mexican border, separated from their parents because of Trump’s cruel anti-migrant policies. I myself regularly meet with unaccompanied minors on the streets of Macron’s Paris – cold, hungry and at risk of exploitation. We still have work to do and that’s why I’m proud to have co-founded, in 2014, the very first child rights intergroup.  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Dear Chairman, the challenges we face in our efforts to protect the children of the world and create an environment in which they will have a safe and carefree childhood have changed greatly in the last three decades. The Internet represents a revolution in interper-people communication, but also a threat to the safety and privacy of children and young people. I believe that we need to work harder to educate children and young people, but also their parents, and at the same time punish offenders more drastically. Smart devices with internet connection are part of our everyday life and new generations are practically born with them. But despite their usefulness, the growth of dependence on these devices, especially in children, is very worrying. We need to work harder on prevention and education and find a balance between health and technological progress.

name: Mick Wallace (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the Convention on the Rights of the Child lists the rights to shelter, nutrition and an adequate standard of living for children. Almost 25 million children under 18 are at risk of poverty or social exclusion in the EU. According to the latest figures in Ireland from the Department of Housing, there are 3 848 children living with homelessness. Over 10 000 people are living with homelessness in Ireland because of the failed neo-liberal, market-based approach that the government has towards housing. And the military and financial imperialism of the developed countries in the global north are destroying the lives of many children in the global south. It is long past time that this Parliament acknowledges the fact that neo-liberalism fails many children.

name: Λευτέρης Νικολάου-Αλαβάνος (NI).
text: Mr President, the evidence is relentless. In 2018, 250 000 000 children were working around the world. Up to 500 000 minors from third countries - many of them victims of sexual exploitation - were working illegally in Europe. In Greece there are tens of thousands of children working illegally while 2.8 million people, aged sixteen and over, have not completed compulsory education. Of the more than 3 000 refugee children stranded on the Greek islands, less than 15% attended school last year, lacking access to basic hygiene and care conditions. Invoking the Convention on the Fundamental Rights of the Child by those whose system is responsible for today's barbarity is a great hypocrisy. In a society of exploitation, which breeds discrimination, poverty, unemployment, wars, refugees and constant violations of fundamental rights of the people, children are no exception. The fight for full rights to work, education, social protection of motherhood, creative life, is the only way out today for a life without exploitation.

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I am convinced that thirty years ago this Convention on the Rights of the Child was an important thing and I can also understand the festive events of this day.  But beyond the festiveness of this situation we need to look very carefully and I ask you today to re-examine the policy on the rights of the child. Twenty-five million children on the poverty line, Commissioner Jourová, is a figure that worries us. And when we talk about the rights of the child, I'm going to remind you that there are four fundamental directions. Lack of access to education, lack of access to health, violence of any kind and exploitation of any kind should be fundamental problems.  I believe that we must, and I ask you today to reorient policies on children's rights, and as far as health is concerned, I am a doctor, I am an emergency doctor in Iaşi, Romania, at the "Nicolae Oblu" Emergency Clinical Hospital, I ask you today, honoured Commission, to develop a European standard of quality in health and to ensure that the health of children in Europe is ensured free of charge. I believe that it is possible, and if we really want to secure the future of Europe, these things must happen, and I assure you that you have all my support to make these things happen.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you, Mr Ciuhodaru. I ask for your indulgence: we have two and a half times as many requests to speak as we might think. (End of spontaneous speeches)

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members... (Cut off by Mr Patten trying to take the floor)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Excuse me, Commissioner.  Mr Patten: I called you first because I had actually called Mr Tennant. He wasn't there. Then I was the next speaker to mention Mr Nikolaou-Alavanos. He wasn't sitting in his seat, but he was there. And I intend to give the floor to only one Member from the non-attached member. That is what I have decided now.  Now Commissioner Jourov is speaking.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I think that this debate showed very clearly that protecting and promoting the rights of the child is, here in this House and in the Commission, not only a legal obligation but a moral imperative, too. And, as you rightly said on many occasions, this is a good reason for celebration, although we have to continue working towards a better implementation, not only of the Convention, but also of the related legislation which should guarantee the protection of the rights of children.  There is also an economic case because, according to many studies and many papers we work with, it is also one of the most valuable long-term investments our economies and societies can make. Children who are disadvantaged are less likely than their better-off peers to do well in school, enjoy good health and realise their full potential later in life.  The cost of responding to this in the future is much higher than investing in the wellbeing of children today. Promoting and protecting the rights of all children is at the core of our obligations. Let’s continue to work together to make the ambitious principles of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child a reality for all children in Europe and in the world.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child has undoubtedly contributed to the improvement in the lives of children across the globe and the progress achieved needs to be celebrated. I thank you for this very timely debate. It shows the commitment of the European Parliament. The 30th anniversary of the Convention is an opportunity to celebrate our common achievements.  However, a lot remains to be done – investing in children throughout their journey to adulthood is not only a moral duty but also an essential investment in a better future for all humanity. As we are celebrating the 30th anniversary of the UN Convention, one has to bear in mind that the world has indeed changed. It is very different to 30 years ago.  For instance, we had no Internet then and that is the new environment for our children in which they are living. Despite its possibilities, for instance in tackling loneliness or enabling online educational environments, it may also cause harmful addiction, or as MEP Nethsingha rightly said, it may increase the risk of sexual exploitation by ruthless predators or provide a platform for online bullying. We do enhance digitalisation but we also have to take this new challenge into account. And it’s not only parents who shall address this challenge, but also the EU, its institutions and the Member States. As the poem goes, ‘To [a child] we cannot say “tomorrow”, his name is “Today”.’

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place during the November II part-session. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – Today we are celebrating the 30th anniversary of the adoption of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. In 1989, the United Nations General Assembly adopted a key document guaranteeing the rights of the child and ensuring that all children in the world have a safe childhood. The Convention states that every child has the right to name and nationality, the right not to be judged on the basis of skin colour, gender, faith, nationality, health or property, has the right to treatment, education and education, rest, personal life, his or her opinion and the opportunity to express it, and the right to be protected from violence and poverty. Unfortunately, however, both globally and at European level, child poverty, child abuse, child sexual exploitation are still a difficult problem. I would like to remind you that in the EU alone we have about 20 million children at risk of poverty or its risk, which is unjustifiable in the context of modern prosperity. I call not only today, but also every day, to join forces and work together to ensure that our children are safe and equip and that the obligations defined in the Convention on the Rights of the Child turn into concrete actions.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. – It is gratifying that we are on the 30th anniversary of the signing of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. I would remind everyone that it is an obligation for the States which are signatories to the Convention to ensure that they are included in the Convention. It states that States Parties to the Convention undertake to provide the child with the protection and care necessary for his or her welfare and to take the necessary legislative and administrative measures to that end. In other words, there are tasks that the legal representative and the state must provide for the child together, such as education. Furthermore, the State must not only respect the rights of the child, but must also actively contribute to their edithion. I hope that Ukraine, which is a signatory to the Convention on the Rights of the Child, will also reach the point where it gives Hungarian children in the minority the same rights to free school choice and access to different levels of education as to the majority. As an associated country of the EU, it must also respect the principle of non-discrimination.

name: Milan Brglez (S&D)
text: Writing. – On 20 November, it will be 30 years since the Convention on the Rights of the Child was adopted, by which states have, in a legally binding manner, recognised the independent and full 'ownership' of human rights by states.  The convention includes both civil and political, as well as economic, social and cultural rights. Their enforcement creates legal and factual obligations on the part of the state and on the part of adults. This anniversary is an opportunity to renew and strengthen the commitment to fully enforce the rights of all children, with a particular focus on the weakest and most deprived. Poverty is in itself the cause and consequence of violations of children's rights, which unfortunately also leads to social exclusion in childhood and is most often passed down into adulthood.  According to Eurostat data for 2017, children are the age group with the highest risk of poverty or social exclusion. In view of all the above, it is essential that the new Commission concreteises and implements as soon as possible the commitment of the elected President to establish a child guarantee that would correct this frightening statistics and, above all, the lives of children. At the same time, a commitment to the children of the world would be a necessary commitment for the EU to ratify the Convention on the Rights of the Child and to play a more active role in promoting the implementation of this most widely accepted international human rights instrument.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. – On 20 November, the anniversary of the adoption of the UN International Convention on the Rights of the Child, we celebrate the International Day for the Rights of the Child. This year marks some 30 years since the adoption of the UN International Convention on the Rights of the Child, but unfortunately many children around the world are living under high-intensity global threats. Poverty and hunger, wars, natural disasters, social exclusion, mass movements of refugees and migrants, discrimination and deep inequalities are, unfortunately, just some of the phenomena of concern. We in the European Parliament stress that we will always vigorously defend the rights of the child as the most important thing. We will ensure that our legislative and non-legislative work respects, promotes and protects the rights of the child and ensures the progress of children's lives, both within the EU and in its relations with the outside world.

name: Klára Dobrev (S&D)
text: Writing. Next week is World Children's Rights Day. That is what we are debating in the European Parliament. Of course, here in the heart of Europe, there is a broad consensus on what we need to do, although there would be such a broad consensus at home, even in Hungary! All injustices are saddening. But there is nothing more stifling than when children are injustice. We live in a society that hangs weight on children's feet and then is angry at them for not being able to run faster. Such is the weight of poor and too soon-to-be-completed education, inadequate housing, unattainable health care.
