The purpose of children's rights is to take these heavy burdens off our children's shoulders. We want them to become liberated, smart, well-educated and self-confident tolerant adults. I fight for these rights for children in the European Parliament and I fight for them in Hungary. Because there's nothing more stifling than when children are injustice.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. – Child hunger in 21st century Europe is unacceptable, but unfortunately we are still talking about an existing phenomenon. It should be pointed out that, 30 years after the entry into force of the Convention on the Rights of the Child, child hunger still exists in some EU Member States! The fundamental aim of any European politician must be to eradicate it. This is why the children's food system for children in need by the Hungarian Government is an outstanding achievement. Today in Hungary, free breakfast and lunch are provided for all children in need in schools and kindergartens. Equally important help is the free textbook. We recommend these good solutions for follow-up across the EU.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. – On 20 November, we celebrate the 30th anniversary of the signing of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. Ensuring the safety, health and well-being of children is the primary obligation of all of us. In particular, the Convention recognises the right to protection and care necessary for the highest possible level of physical and mental development of children. An integral part of this is ensuring proper nutrition for children. There is plenty of work to be done in this area, as more than 200 million children worldwide currently lack access to high-quality food every day. The European Union must act unitedly to solve this problem, for which it is worth taking into account good practices in the Member States. Such a good example Hungary, which has almost tripled the resources spent on social children's meals over the past decade and has uniquely expanded the number of eligible persons. In this way, nine out of 10 children in the nursery and preschool age group now have children's meals.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Convention on the Rights of the Child is a historical document and a milestone in the approach to children, their protection and ensuring respect for their rights and subjectivity. In the 30 years since its adoption, the situation of children around the world, including on our continent, has changed for the better, but hunger, malnutrition and violence have not yet been fully eradicated and not all children have equal access to education and healthcare. This anniversary cannot therefore be just an opportunity to take stock of the achievements, but should also lead us to reflect on what to do to combat these negative phenomena once and for all. An important initiative in this area will, I hope, be the 'Guarantee for Children', which was created on the initiative of the European Parliament and has already been announced in the work programme of the new European Commission, chaired by Ursula Von Der Leyen.  I would also like to draw attention to our duty not only to the youngest citizens of the European Union, but also to express concern for children elsewhere in the world, whose situation is often incomparably worse. In its development and humanitarian assistance, the European Union should pay particular attention to ensuring the protection of the rights of the child and improving their safety and life situation.

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Children are among the most vulnerable members of our societies. For obvious reasons, they must be subject to special protection, which is why we are rightly celebrating the 30th anniversary of the adoption of the Convention on the Rights of the Child. Poland has a lot of achievements in this area, after all, it was my country that proposed the development of this instrument. This is not surprising in the case of the country of Janusz Korczak, a wonderful man who at the beginning of the last century abandoned a well-timed medical practice to devote himself to childcare. He wrote books for them, ran a house of orphans. Finally, when his wards were to be transported to the German extermination camp in Treblinka during World War II, he turned down an offer of rescue and stayed with his nearly 200 wards until the joint destruction in the gas chambers.

name: Łukasz Kohut (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – In today's debate, let me invoke Articles 28 and 29 of the Convention on the Rights of the Child: states ratifying the Convention recognise the rights of the child to free primary education and that the child's education will be aimed at preparing the child for a proper life in a free society, in a spirit of understanding, peace, tolerance, gender equality and friendship between all peoples, ethnic, national and religious groups and indigenous peoples. As Ślązak, I would like to call on the newly elected Polish parliamentarians and parliamentarians to take the Law on the Silesian Language seriously in the next parliamentary term of the Polish Parliament, so that Silesian children can learn it in schools and that they are not discriminated against by the Polish education system.

name: Janina Ochojska (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – It is 30 years since the Adoption of the Convention on the Rights of the Child. Unfortunately, despite numerous efforts by international organisations and the governments of some countries, many issues remain unresolved. The World Bank, together with UNICEF, estimates that around 385 million children worldwide live in extreme poverty, or less than $1.9 a day, and due to the high number of conflicts in different parts of the world, children are constantly exposed to violence, various forms of exploitation or trafficking in human beings. Almost 14% of all migrants are under the age of 15 and the number of unattended children remains high.  The United Nations Children's Fund estimates that around 93 million children with disabilities live worldwide. Many of them, including in the Member States of the European Union, cannot participate fully in society and cannot function in this environment without hindrance due to barriers resulting from lack or inadequate adaptation of infrastructure, problems in access to education or health services. Active action and commitment to level the playing field for underemployed children is of the importance. Action should be stepped up for children with disabilities, child poverty should be combated more effectively and their safety ensured. It is necessary to include both the European Parliament and national parliaments in these activities.

name: Rovana Plumb (S&D)
text: in writing. – Thirty years ago, nations joined to make an unprecedented promise to the children of the world. They pledged not only to proclaim children’s rights, but also to uphold them and be accountable for them. It has become the most widely ratified human rights treaty in history and has helped transform children’s lives around the world. Still, not every child gets to enjoy a full childhood. Millions of children around the world are hungry, sick or in danger. Others are suffering because of their religion, ethnicity or disability. Children in conflict zones may be subject to horrific sexual violence that causes long-term psychological and physical trauma. Most are trafficked for sexual exploitation, forced labour or recruited as child soldiers. More families are migrating than ever before, and child migrants are some of the most vulnerable people in the world. We need to strengthen our efforts to ensure all children are safe, healthy and able to achieve their dreams. It is up to our generation to put children first and to demand that leaders from governments, business and communities fulfil their commitments and take action to protect children’s rights now, once and for all.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. – Exactly 30 years ago, in 1989, the United Nations (UN) adopted a particularly important Convention on the Rights of the Child. On this occasion, it is worth recalling some of the important commitments made by the signatories of the Convention, which are being forgotten today in many countries of the Union. At the out) it was initially unequivocally recorded that the United Nations had declared that children have the right to special care and assistance. A family, as a key part of society and a natural environment for the development and kindness of all its members, and especially children, must be shrouded in basic protection and support in order to fully fulfil its obligations in society. A child must be cultivated in a family environment, in an atmosphere dominated by happiness, love and understanding, for the full and harmonious development of his personality. The need to envelop the child in special custody was expressed even earlier, in the Geneva Declaration of the Rights of the Child of 1924 and in the Declaration of the Rights of the Child, which was adopted by the Joint Assembly on 20 November 1959. As stated in the Declaration on the Rights of the Child, "a child, because of his physical and mental immaturity, requires special care and care, including adequate legal protection, as before, and after birth". This is a very important statement that obliges us to protect children, either before birth or from becoming pregnant, that is, the protection of unborn children. The importance of traditional and cultural values for the protection and harmonious development of each nation's child has also been emphasised. Let's remember that.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. – Next week marks the 30th anniversary of the Convention on the Rights of the Child. The document, which emphasises that children are personalities with all human rights, covers the widest range of human rights, including civil, cultural, economic, political and social rights. The document sets out the rights that all children should enjoy and sets basic standards for children's development at different ages and in different areas of their lives.  Children are the future of Europe at the same time. Our society has a duty to take care of children, to provide them with a safe environment for growth and development. In terms of demographic change and an ageing population, we must not overlook the role of the family and its contribution to our future. I am pleased that, in the space of demography, children's protection will also be given a special place at the European Commission.

text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission's statement on the EU steel industry: ways of protecting European workers and sectors (2019/2920(RSP)). name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, as requested, let me make a statement on behalf of the Commission on the subject of the EU steel sector. First, let me say a few words on the trade defence measures for steel. Over the three-year period from 2013-16, the European steel industry suffered truly severe losses. This was due to the trade spillovers from Chinese overcapacity. But our policy response was swift and comprehensive. In March 2016 we issued a communication laying out a number of measures encompassing, crucially, trade policy. Over the years 2014-18, the EU imposed a really unprecedented number – 25 new measures covering steel products. The aim was to remove the injurious effects of dumped and subsidised imports and restore fair trading conditions. These measures significantly reduced dumped and subsidised imports and protected 216 000 jobs.  The EU took a number of steps to better protect the steel industry in the trade defence domain through import surveillance and accelerated investigations. The opening of the investigations was based on threat of injury, where justified, or the application of definite duties retroactively, where audited. These steps had a significant impact. Steel imports of products covered by measures adopted in the years 2014-17 fell by more than 95% on average compared with the volume of imports before the measures were imposed.  Despite signs of recovery for the steel sector, in part due to the imposition of trade defence measures, the EU steel industry continued to be vulnerable, and in 2018 the industry was confronted with yet another important challenge: the risk of injury stemming from the US Section 232 measures on steel products and the risk of trade diversion. The Commission again reacted swiftly to this challenge by opening a safeguard investigation. Earlier this year, the Commission and EU Member States agreed to put in place definitive safeguard measures, considering the risk of redirecting substantial amounts of imports from other countries, previously destined to the US market, into Europe.  When imposing definite measures, the Commission committed to reassess the situation by July 2019. This was to ensure that their functioning remained adapted to steel market developments and to deal with unforeseen circumstances. The measures consist of a tariff rate quota which de facto limits imports from all countries of origin to the average level of the years 2015-2017. A 25% duty is imposed beyond this and this is a lower level than the high 2018. These measures, imposed until July 2021, allow for imports to continue at their non-injurious level and all of those were largely supported by Member States and industries.  The Commission continues to monitor imports and will consider the need for another review in the future, in the case of changed circumstances, for example, Brexit. The Commission is also tackling the root causes of overcapacity by actively participating in the G20 global forum on steel excess capacity.  In addition, the European partnership on clean steel and low carbon steel making has been proposed under Horizon Europe. This will put additional private and public research and innovation investment to support the development of breakthrough technologies for the production of clean steel. The EU is also supporting the development of clean steel technologies with their research fund for coal and steel.  Let me also mention that under the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), we’ll have Horizon Europe and investEU, both new sources for investment and research in the steel sector.  Through the Strategic Forum on important projects for common European interests, the Commission is identifying the business-critical strategic value chains and defining potential actions and investments from industry and public authorities. This strategic forum has prioritised six key strategic value chains, including the strategic value chain on low CO2 emission industries, and the final report has just been finalised on 6 November.  Finally, the Innovation Fund under the Emissions Trading System (ETS) post-2020 will support big demonstration projects employing breakthrough low carbon technologies and it will cover up to 60% of the relevant cost of the projects.  Let me now move to the labour market. The EU legal framework is there also to protect workers in case of industrial change and disruptions. Several EU directives set requirements for informing and consulting workers in cases of restructuring. It is the responsibility, of course, of the Member States’ authorities to ensure that the national legislation transposing EU directives is applied by the employers concerned. While the Commission has no power to interfere in specific company decisions regarding the restructuring plans, it urges companies to follow good practices on restructuring.  EU funding is also available to support workers. Let me mention, of course, the EU Social Fund, which is used to improve employment opportunities, promote education and lifelong learning and develop active inclusion policies. The very important tool that we have is the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) – a key instrument providing support to workers made redundant as a result of major structural changes. The first step to mobilise the EGF is for the Member States concerned to submit an application and the EGF regulation provides for a minimum of 500 redundancies in an enterprise as one of the eligibility criteria to trigger the intervention. In the case of the small labour market or in some exceptional circumstances, derogation from this criteria is always possible.  As you can see, the European Commission has, for a long time, taken a very clear stance to support the competitiveness of the EU’s steel sector. We issued a communication dedicated to the EU steel sector, the so-called Steel Action Plan. We took steps to strengthen EU defence against unfair trading practices. In conclusion, let me underline that in our renewed industrial policy strategy, we stressed that a robust industrial base is essential for Europe’s economic growth, preservation of sustainable jobs and EU competitiveness in the global market.

The safeguard measures identified are not sufficient. They are not enough and the results show this: Turkish steel in 2017 was at 16 % in our market, today it is at 33 %.  We must take action to prevent these drifts and, on the other hand, by monitoring countries that do not always show attention to manufacturing tradition. The case of Italy on Taranto is proof of this. Europe is re-negotiating with Italy to treat its industry well.

name: Carlo Calenda
text: Mr President, Madam Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I have been on the Trade Council in recent years, and the work that has been done, particularly with regard to steel, has certainly been an important task. It has arrived too late, however, and is still too weak.  I am very convinced that the review of the safeguard measures must be done immediately, immediately.  We have already mentioned the Turkish case and, as far as China is concerned, there is still a great deal to be done, many products come in with triangulations that need to be checked.  But there is one theme that has to do with the process of changing the steel industry within. We know that the state aid legislation is particularly stringent on steel. I believe that it is worth thinking not only about European research funds, but also about funds for the industrial transition, to enable companies to make their environmental investments, even at a time of great difficulty in the steel sector, and to this end to revise the state aid legislation.  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question, Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Mr President, I would like to ask you if you are noticing the link between the European Union's restrictive climate policy and the collapse of the steel industry? In your speech, you referred precisely to this current difficult situation of the steel industry on the European market. You will certainly see the increase in steel imports from Turkey, from Russia, from China to the European Union. Do you therefore think it makes sense to continue... (The President received the speaker's vote)

name: Carlo Calenda (S&D)
text: Answer to a blue card question. The answer is yes, I have it perfectly clear. That is why the Structural Funds must be used not only for research, but also for production transition processes. I, personally, as Minister for Economic Development in Italy, have reindustrialized both Ilva and Piombino, so I know the subject perfectly well. The important thing is that Europe, if it wants to accompany this transition of the steel industry, should put money on it because otherwise it is just words.

name: Christophe Grudler
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, we cannot allow Europe to be invaded by low-cost steel produced without respect for social and environmental standards, which do not comply with the Paris agreement. Today, it is not so much China, it is Brazil and other countries that are circumventing the European anti-dumping laws that the Commissioner mentioned earlier, because the anti-dumping laws are circumvented by the importation of so-called slabs, which are in fact blocks of steel. These are unfinished products, which are not subject to any tax when they enter the European Union. We really need to act on these unfinished products, we must put an end to them by taking new measures such as the border carbon tax, which will support the European steel sector, which is making great efforts under the Green deal: circular carbon energy, carbon capture and storage and even the production of iron from decarbonised hydrogen. All these efforts are being made by our European companies, it is absolutely necessary to support them.

name: Andrea Caroppo
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to agree with what Mrs Salini and Mr Calenda said, thanking the Commissioner, but I do not think I can do so and, above all, the workers in Krakow, who will no longer be working in the steel works in Poland in a few days' time, or the workers who may be British or the workers in a few days' time, would not agree. , maybe, even in Taranto.  We are responding to a resounding crisis – the United States is going with guns and putting up duties and putting in heavy tariffs – we are going with very weak safeguard measures. It is clear that the road is wrong.  If we add to this the irresponsibility or inability of governments such as the Italian government, with the incredible management made on the Ilva, it is clear that the picture is so gloomy that an immediate recovery is needed.  Therefore, we do not need crocodile tears, as Perhaps Mr Bonafè does, who tells us to safeguard the workers. The workers really do safeguard themselves by protecting a strategic and key sector such as steel for the whole of Europe.

name: Marc Botenga
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, first of all, I think it is time for the Commission to open its eyes. In Belgium, in the Liège steel industry, in the 1960s, there were 35,000 workers. Today, there are 1,400 jobs that are constantly under threat. These are families, entire cities that are at risk of falling into poverty, into misery. En als wij zo verdergaan, dan dreigen er straks ook in Gent bij ArcelorMittal duizenden jobs op de helling te komen.  What for? It is not the fault of others. It is your fault, it is the fault of all those here who have sanctified the market, who have given priority to competition. So today, it is really time to understand the social emergency and to set up a public hub for the steel industry in Belgium and Europe. We have the factories, we have the know-how, let's enjoy it! Let's take this into our own hands and allow the steel industry, in Belgium and Europe, to live! Please stop opposing it!

name: Rosa D'Amato (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we must, of course, reflect on what is happening to steel.  The request for this Commission statement from the ID group is related to the Taranto site. I am a tarantine and I know what it is like to live with the largest steel works in Europe next door, but certainly also the most polluting steel works in Europe.  We must therefore ask, as a Member of the European Parliament, that the Commission certainly not leave only the Italian Government and, above all, the citizens and workers of Taranto. To put in place all the European funds that you have quoted very well: the European Globalisation Fund, the European Social Fund, but also the Just Transition Fund, which must be used for decarbonisation in Germany, I am also thinking of Poland, but also in those sites that need to be converted industrially. Finally, I must make a final point to my colleagues here, including the Minister for Economic Development. There is talk of State aid, which must certainly be changed, but let me say that it must certainly not be changed to help a foreign industry, a multinational company which has signed a contract with you which it has not complied with at all, which has not spent a euro on restructuring. (The President withdrew the floor from the Speaker)

name: Antonio Tajani (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the largest steel site in Europe, taranto, is in danger of closing because of its inability to have an industrial policy, to have it in Italy, but also to have it throughout Europe.  The action plan which I had prepared on steel and which the Commission had approved has yet to be implemented. Despite Commissioner Bieńkowska's efforts, more needs to be done. We must have an impact in order to have a genuine industrial policy that allows our steel to be competitive both from the point of view of reducing CO2 emissions, so we must have less and less polluting steel production, but we must also have strong action to support domestic demand and foreign demand.  We are faced with unfair competition from China, from Turkey, from countries of the former Soviet Union. We therefore need strong economic diplomacy, but we also need to change the rules of competition in order to create steel champions, European steel champions, because without this choice we risk being overwhelmed by Chinese superpower.

name: Nicolás González Casares (S&D).
text: – Mr President, my country, Spain, is the fourth largest steel producer in the European Union, but production has fallen by 25% since 2007. That is why we are well aware of the problems facing the sector, arising from the overcapacity of countries such as China, or the dumping carried out by Turkey, to which trade tensions have added with the protectionist measures imposed by Trump, also to aluminum. In my region, Galicia, and also in neighboring Asturias, we have lived under the threat of the closure of alcoa aluminum plants and the dismissal of 700 workers. We cannot stand by when we lose industrial activity and employment. Parliament has insistently demanded a European industrial agenda worthy of such a name. We reiterate this call for an agenda that makes use of all available arsenal at its disposal to strengthen the European industrial base; taxation, with mechanisms such as border adjustment to be able to compete on an equal footing while advancing decarbonisation. It's time to move on to the facts.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, you have outlined here a complex of issues that the Commission is taking up, but during the implementation of this beautiful programme, for example, Huta Częstochowa has collapsed, there are threats to extinguish furnaces in Poland, czech and Slovak steel mills. From this it follows that you need to act immediately. It's just too slow.  I have undertaken to present the essence of the Joint Declaration of workers' representatives, trade union organisations and national metallurgical associations Polish, the Czech Republic and Slovakia. And you see what they write there? The European steel industry and its global competitiveness are affected by several negative factors: a slowdown in the economy, but also increasing volumes of imported steel from third countries, rising costs of emission allowances, rising energy costs, lack of sufficient investment, especially environmental ones, volatile commodity prices. In short, it is necessary to act immediately, and I ask for this on behalf of those who have addressed me to this letter.  (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))
