text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I would like to ask you if you share the view that emission trading rights are speculative? I would like to recall the sharp increase in the price of emission rights and the european Commission's failure to refer de facto to this fact. The steel industry is an energy-intensive industry, heavily burdened by these regulations. Do you also share the view that restrictive policies... (The President received the speaker's vote)

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Madam President, yes, it is speculative. And we know that prices just fluctuate. However, regardless of the fundamental objective of protecting the environment and the negative effects, we should be able to manage this sector, and I urge you to simply help. I do not encourage protectionism, but I urge protection. This is our duty, so will citizens judge us as well.

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I remind you that beyond the steel we are talking about people and the biggest loss of Romania since 1989 was this very deindustrialisation, because if before 1989 they worked in a single steel plant 50 000 people, now they work 12 000 in the entire Romanian steel industry.  Let us think about concrete things and stop being hypocrites, because the things you have said are just a congratulations on the situation. On the one hand, European development funds are needed for the entire European steel industry and a single policy at European level, and yes, I agree with the reassessment of that state aid legislation. And we cannot say that we allow access to the European market for a type of steel from other countries that does not comply with any rules and we pay on this price of ecology sums that make us destroy our industry and especially destroy our people. I'm asking for concrete action.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (Renew).
text: – Mr President, the Union must continue to deepen its commitment to sustainability and must make it a tool to protect its industry and its workers. Steelmaking is a good sector to turn these words into deeds.  Those who invest in cleaner productions must be protected and this effort encouraged to continue to create and maintain jobs.  The measures with which we have defended ourselves from the protectionism of the Trump administration or the overcapacity of Chinese industry or the monetary measures that have benefited Turkish or Chinese producers have proved useful. But we must go further: we must banish dirty steel from Europe, which is not produced by the demanding European environmental and social standards.  The Union's steelmaking has made an enormous technological, economic and training effort by its staff to gain in that sustainability. Let us support this effort with a new environmental and social tariff to protect our entire industry.

name: Anna Bonfrisco (ID).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Bieńkowska, it is bitter to have to record that the numbers on the European market are wrong to you, because the wrong representing those numbers is the wrong wrong of the policies of the European Union, which has allowed this steel market to become very fragile in Europe, allowing countries such as Turkey and China to enter our market by making unfair competition with our companies.  So jobs in Europe and the industrial system are not defended in words, deeds are needed. We need to understand who can be in the market fairly and who enters the market just to destroy the European market. We must defend the European future and that of the Member States, because we must defend the future of those workers, the future of our businesses. Prevent Turkey from entering Europe with its steel and defend its work!

name: Beata Kempa (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In all this politics, I lack space for an ordinary person who is primarily to have the dignity of work, of human work. In Krakow – in Nowa Huta – in Poland ArcelorMittal announced the extinction of the blast furnace in The Sendzimir Hut. About two thousand workers today land on the pavement. This is a tragedy for them and their families. This is the aftermath of a senseless, blind climate policy, unfortunately pursued by the Union. Today, many Member States cannot afford to continue to do so because of too much cost and human tragedies.  I would remind you – the Union was founded as a Community of Coal and Steel, and we recently celebrated another anniversary of its founding. Therefore, I think that in a short time, unfortunately, there will be neither coal nor steel. In my province in Wałbrzych, by such a policy, we lost mines working for steel works. To this day, the region has many problems, and people cannot rise from trauma – this is, above all, a warning against any future decisions of the Union.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, you have outlined to us the situation here how it is basically fine, but she is not fine. This is where jobs are closed, people are being thrown out, businesses in the strategic sector, which is the steel industry, are closing. The steel industry is the basis for engineering, automotive and other industries. And there is simply overproduction in the world, a fact that has its origins primarily in the fact that some non-European countries have unfair practices and consistently violate climate targets, climate standards, but also labour law, because there are no trade unions there.  How are you going to compete with these countries in the steel sector other than face it? This means that with the duties you introduce, you will force these countries to meet the standards that our steelworks meet. And our steelworks didn't have to close because these countries produce over-production, and it has one single effect. We will always support steel. We're just going to import it, our employees are going to suffer, and we're going to lose our strategic advantage.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I wish to thank the Members for their remarks. Firstly, I have not said that everything is fine. Secondly, I don’t need to defend this Commission with words because in my quite long opening speech at the beginning, I said, very concretely, what this Commission has done and what we are doing, very swiftly and quite effectively, in the steel sector in Europe. We reacted swiftly. We did our utmost in the three major areas: trade policy, industrial policy and employment policy. All of them are, or were, a part of our steel action plan and we are implementing them quite swiftly. In trade policy, we have tightened our instruments and we are using them very actively, as much as we can, to protect our industry, to protect it from unfair imports; I showed you the numbers. On industrial policy, we are working with our international partners to reduce global steel over-capacity; we are also putting a lot of money with the new instruments, under the new MFF, but also in the current one, to innovate and for our steel sector to become more sustainable. As many of you mentioned workers and our employment policy: here we have primarily the European Social Fund (ESF), the globalisation funds available to re-train and to re-skill our workforce; to accompany the many structural changes that are ongoing in the steel industry. Of course the work is not done. I cannot comment on the new Commission. But definitely, in the last years, starting from 2014, we took a number of very active working measures to protect our steel market and especially our workers. Let me also mention that the new Commission has announced the carbon border adjustment tax. This is a really important instrument for which the previous Parliament was calling, and I think it will be implemented soon.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – It is in a way tragic that a debate on the protection of European workers remains necessary today. The huge problems that continue to arise result from reliance over the years on uncoordinated national initiatives, misguided free market policies clumsily implemented and a lack of foresight. Meanwhile, producers elsewhere tooled up within protected markets to achieve output levels that enabled exports at cutthroat prices. Loss of competitivity, little cutting edge innovation, overcapacity, and less than adaptive labour systems resulted in Europe. The recognition that the steel industry is a strategic sector existed in word, not in deed. The future of steel should not have been left to the markets’ mercy. It needed to be tightly regulated and planned, on a national and European basis. Planning needed backing funds to enable subsidies and flexible work arrangements, protection flexibly managed, plus consolidation over a bottom line to ensure that basic output in significant volumes would remain located in Europe. Current computing power allows for such centralised planning to be carried out in conformity with the rest of the European economy still acting according to market forces while responding autonomously to them. Europe cannot tolerate the option of having to procure all its steel requirements from the outside.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on Turkey's drilling in EU waters in the Eastern Mediterranean (2019/2875 (RSP)." Again, I would like to say that in the debate, both traditional registration and the new system, which allows Members to register electronically, can be used to request spontaneous speeches and blue cards. I would therefore ask you to always bring your voting card to plenary. If you wish to request an impromptu request, you can do so now. So you do not have to wait until the end of the debate.  However, I would also like to add, on the part of the new Members, that blue cards are not allowed in the Commissioners' opinions.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, it is a timely debate in this Parliament. It gives me a good opportunity to debrief you on the work we have done, not only on the Commission’s side but also on the Council’s side. Actually, last Monday we adopted in the Foreign Affairs Council a framework for restrictive measures in response to Turkey’s drilling in the eastern Mediterranean. This decision makes it now possible to sanction individuals and entities that are responsible for unauthorised drilling activities in Cyprus’ territorial sea, exclusive economic zone or continental shelf. You will remember how we got there. In early May, Turkey sent a first drill ship inside Cyprus’ exclusive economic zone and then another one in June. From the very beginning there was a common united European Union position on the matter. We acted first and foremost in full solidarity with Cyprus, including at the highest level, at the level of the European Council with the European Union heads of state and government. Then, in July the Council decided on a first response suspending our high-level dialogues with Turkey, the negotiations on the Comprehensive Air Transport Agreement and endorsing the Commission’s proposal to reduce the pre-accession assistance to Turkey for 2020. In July the Council also asked the Commission and the External Action Service to work on further options for targeted measures in case Turkey continued its illegal drilling activities. We’ve been constantly in contact with our Turkish counterparts at all levels, passing messages to the Turkish side on the need to de-escalate. And yet Turkey decided to continue its activities and even to move further, to move to Block 7, which is an area where Cyprus has given licenses to a consortium of EU companies. And this is how we arrived to this week’s framework for restrictive measures. As always, we’re taking a gradual approach, a scalable approach, meaning that sanctions can be scaled up or down, depending on developments on the ground, in this case let me say rather developments at sea. And, as always, these are targeted measures so they will only target individuals or entities that are responsible for, or involved in, unauthorised drillings. Our goal remains to defuse tension and to make clear that Cyprus’ sovereignty and sovereign rights should be respected in accordance with international law. At the same time, it is urgent to resume substantive settlement talks aimed at the reunification of the island and aimed at the united Cyprus inside the European Union, based on a bi-communal bi-zonal federation. The European Union fully supports the work done by the two Cypriot leaders and the United Nations in this respect. We look forward to the meeting that the UN Secretary-General has convened in Berlin on 25 November as a crucial opportunity to agree on the next steps towards a solution for the Cypriot issue. The European Union has always been accompanying these efforts, these steps, different stages, and will continue to do so with all the energy and the resources it can mobilise. So hoping and working, rather accompanying the UN work for a settlement, making clear that Cyprus’ sovereignty and sovereign rights have to be respected and that the European Union will always react in a united manner to defend them, and always inviting our Turkish counterparts to de-escalate and work in a different kind of environment.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, a moment ago, here in the European Parliament, in the heart of Europe and the Republic, we celebrated, as it should and should, the fall of the Berlin Wall and the discharge of Europe from tyrannical regimes. But at the same time, Mr President, on European soil, for forty-five years, it has been systematically built by an arbitrary provocative occupying force, such as Turkey, another wall, another wall of shame, against which the European Union and all mankind must resist and begin to tear it down. It is truly a challenge and a disgrace for humanity and for the whole of Europe, in 2019, turkey to invade Syria undisturbed, Turkey to invade the exclusive economic zone of Cyprus undisturbed and to violate sovereign rights, Turkey to continue to hold European territory, Turkey to continue to provoke, blackmail and arbitrarily to the detriment of human rights enshrined in international and European law. I believe that the measures taken by the European Union are correct; we are proud because we are a member of this great European family; I firmly believe that the European Union has the power but also that it is time to escalate the measures towards Turkey and force it to really apply the rules of law and the principles of the European Union. Turkey does not understand words. Even if in 1939 humanity did not have time to prevent Hitler from blood-sucking, I believe that humanity today can stop Turkey from repeating history at the expense of the European Union and at the expense of humanity.

name: Tonino Picula
text: on behalf of the S&D. Club – Dear President, the actions of repeated drilling in the territorial waters of Cyprus do not only raise the issue of solidarity with the Member State and its territorial integrity that has not yet been realised.  This is primarily a matter of respect for international law, which these actions of Turkey clearly violate. I therefore support the economic framework for sanctions adopted by the Council this week. This will allow individuals or companies responsible or involved in unauthorised hydrocarbon drilling activities in the Eastern Mediterranean to be sanctioned. The sanctions are directed at anyone who directly implements this illegal decision, and even members of the Navy hired to oversee the entire operation. Also towards anyone found to be helping the whole process in any way.  These illegal acts have a negative impact on the full range of relations between the European Union and Turkey. Apart from the economic dimension, it is obvious that our political relations with Turkey are becoming more complex. As messages from President Erdogan and Trump meet, Russian patrols control the NATO border and Turkey announces the purchase of an S-400 missile system from Russia.  It is clear that traditional alliances are under increasingly serious pressures, which is why we need to think about redefining the role of the European Union on the global stage. This example represents just one reminder of how inevitable this is.

name: Nathalie Loiseau
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Madam High Representative, in 1974 the Turkish army invaded Northern Cyprus. Despite multiple international protests and efforts by the United Nations, the Turkish occupation continues; 30,000 Turkish soldiers are still stationed in Northern Cyprus. In 2004, Cyprus joined the European Union. Despite the efforts of all, a Member State of our Union is still divided today. In 2014, the European Council issued its first protest over Turkey's non-compliance with Cyprus' sovereignty over its territorial waters and its exclusive economic zone. I quote this date, 2014, because, at that time, Turkey has been conducting negotiations to join the European Union since 2005. Negotiations that we are told, and which we hope, bring the candidate countries closer to our priorities and values. What is the European Council doing in 2014, when a candidate state is demonstrating vividly that it does not recognise the sovereignty of a Member State? He expressed deep concern and then continued accession negotiations with Turkey. For years, we have lined up words, speeches, and Turkey has not taken us seriously. For years, we have failed to express effective solidarity with one of our Member States, Cyprus. And, until recently, another Member State, Mr Orbon's Hungary, has been more sensitive to Mr Erdogan's Turkey's arguments than to the duty of solidarity with Cyprus before, it seems, bowing down. On Monday, the Foreign Affairs Council finally agreed on a framework of sanctions. Finally! How long did it take? Fortunately, European countries, including France, are crossing off Cyprus, and I am proud that my country can express its solidarity in a concrete way... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Catherine Rowett
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Turkey’s illegal drilling operations off Cyprus have continued despite the European Union’s repeated calls to stop them. And, certainly, condemnation is right, as we have heard already from many speakers. But, dear colleagues, let us not also look like hypocrites when we challenge others even while continuing to extract or import gas and oil for ourselves – sometimes even authorising new mines. And this will continue so long as we go on listening to fossil fuel apologists. Here in this Parliament, Exxon Mobil are still licenced to lobby despite their proven climate change denial record. If we were serious about greening Europe, we’d surely have rid ourselves of that. Extraction of fossil fuels has to stop. Celebrating growth has to stop. Facilitating emissions-heavy travel has to stop. It’s up to us to do it, and to do it right here, not just in Turkey.

name: Anna Bonfrisco
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, just today we celebrated the thirty years since the fall of the Berlin Wall, mainly thanks to the strong will of Germany at the time. This shows that when you want no wall it is too high to be knocked down. Unfortunately, for over thirty years, however, the wall dividing Cyprus into the European Union has shown that the European Union is being held hostage by Turkey. Turkey is well aware that the European Union is geopolitically weak, divided within it and that European soft power no longer convinces anyone and, above all, is not exactly afraid of anyone.  The disproportion that emerges between the Turkish actions, be they illegal drilling or the invasion of northern Syria, and the European responses, made in paragraphs of condemnation in which the European Council, as President Loiseau pointed out very well earlier, regrets, complains, invites, hopes, shows that the European project is strategically inadequate, both regionally and globally, and that our response is too weak.  So someone needs to do something. Brave men and women face reality.  (The President withdrew the floor from the Speaker)

name: Εμμανουήλ Φράγκος
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, once again it is proving that the European Union is failing to effectively safeguard its sovereign rights. Turkey has invaded, plundered and illegally displaced the inhabitants of Cyprus and is now also threatening its European waters by illegally drilling. So what is Europe's reaction to the violation of its sovereign rights? We all know that false sanctions against natural and legal persons are only for the appearance and are not sufficient. Serious sanctions must be taken immediately against Turkey itself. All financial assistance and provision by the Union to it must be stopped. We understand that Europe has great economic interests in Turkey, but our honour and prestige are now at stake. Europe must defend its rights against such hostile, war-fighting actions by third countries. Today it must send a strong message to everyone that it is not being blackmailed and that it is not granting its rights, that it remains united and strong next to its members and next to Cyprus.

name: Γιώργος Γεωργίου
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I do not know, but Lucian, an old Syrian writer from 150 AD, could not have thought of today's Europe. More simply, I do not know if we can say that this 'Europe's blunder' towards Turkey and the provocative Erdoğan, which has been going on for years, is 'too bad for nothing'. If we liken it to a child, then the child that the European institutions gave birth to the day before yesterday, that is, the measures against Turkey, is a sick child and I wonder if with these sick measures we will scare Erdoğan, who is becoming increasingly harsh, more authoritarian, more provocative. We do not underestimate the measures taken at all, but we all feel and must admit that they are inferior to what had to be taken. The question is simple: do we want and can - in one day - stop selling arms to Erdoğan and paralyze his economy? The rest are pretexts to cover up our disrepute.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Mr President, it has been shown in practice that the verbal concerns and white sanctions of the United States and the European Union against Turkey not only do not stop, but rather encourage its aggression in the Cypriot EEZ and the Aegean, but also in relation to the invasion of Syria, since it seems, regardless of declarations, to have a green light from the United States, the European Union and NATO. The protection of the Cypriot EEZ from the interests of the major American, French and Italian energy groups is also unfounded. After all, all of them consider Turkey to be their strategic partner and are in constant haggling and competition that fuel the aggression of the Turkish bourgeoisie and its quest to create fait accompli with regard to the partition of Cyprus, the control of the Cypriot EEZ, the Aegean and the wider region.  These developments call for strengthening solidarity in peoples' struggle against Euro-Nato planning. No involvement of Greece! Shut down all bases! Cancel the dangerous agreements signed by the governments of both New Democracy and SYRIZA!

name: Michael Gahler (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which It is regrettable that, within two consecutive plenary weeks, we must criticise Turkey's activities, which are contrary to international law. Three weeks ago in Strasbourg we were talking about the invasion of northern Syria, now we are talking about illegal drilling in the exclusive economic zone of Cyprus. After all, we have now created a legal framework for restrictive measures against specific individuals and companies. However, this list is still empty after the decision and, to my knowledge,. My question to the High Representative is therefore: have we already been called by companies and managers in these companies or heads of government who have approved this? Perhaps the Cypriot authorities, who are closest to it, have also provided special names so that we can then slowly fill this list? Is there already something in the pipeline? Do we have any concrete ideas as to who we can put on this list?

name: Nacho Sánchez Amor (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the problem of Turkish drilling in waters in Cyprus' exclusive economic zone somehow bears a similarity to the Turkish military operation. It is a unilateral action, using force and outside the framework of international law, by displaying an alleged right that could obviously be discussed. The radically unacceptable thing about the situation is this unilateral action, in which warships have harassed European ships that had formal contracts to do so. Instead of sending Mr Erdogan a fleet of lawyers to the relevant international court that can decide whether there is a legal issue to digest, ships are sent, which they do is, in fact, expropriate a right to those companies and to Cyprus. The worst way to defend that right.  It is strange that Turkey is astonished that there have been sanctions in the end. Turkey exhibits its status as guarantor of the peace process, but what Turkey is doing is piercing the possibility that this conflict will end as it is trying to do, in a negotiated manner.

name: Lars Patrick Berg (ID).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Turkey's actions in the eastern Mediterranean must not be seen in isolation. The Turkish action in northern Syria, support for terrorism and extremism in the Middle East and Africa, the repression of political opponents in Turkey and elsewhere, and the threats to us to flood Europe with more migrants point to the true nature of the Erdogan government. Turkey's behaviour in natural gas exploration in Cypriot waters is just another expression of its total disregard for the rule of law and its contempt for the international community. The international community, both within Europe and beyond, must agree on Turkey's condemnation and its implausible justification for invading Cypriot waters.  That is why we must send a clear message to Turkey: we will not continue to tolerate the actions of this government. We should do everything necessary to protect ourselves from this very obvious further attempt to undermine our interests, our values and, above all, our security.

name: Андрей Слабаков  (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I am extremely disappointed by the total lack of adequate response from the European Union in relations with Turkey. We are witnessing a growing sense of impunity for Erdogan in his relations with Europe and this is the result of decades of impotent Europe's policy towards Turkey. The European Union has left Erdogan to believe that economic interests are more important than our European values. On our border we have an authoritarian, Islamist and neo-Islamist regime that does not respect the rules of the European Union. It's the second time I've said that because I said it last time in terms of attacks on the Kurds in northern Syria. Concrete measures must be taken as a matter of urgency – a complete cessation of financial flows to Turkey by the European Union, including the suspension of any state-owned investments by European countries. Don't, please, we're getting ridiculous.

name: Márton Gyöngyösi (NI).
text: – Mr President, on the face of it, this dispute is over economic and energy resources. But this is only a consequence of the long-lasting and deeply rooted conflict. The Council decision misses the point and doesn’t address the real issue of ethnic conflict on the island between Turkish and Greek Cypriots. The conflict should have been resolved over a decade ago, before Cyprus joined the European Union in 2004. This should have been a precondition for membership. And the framework for settlement was in place at the time, with the help of the UN, in the so-called ‘Annan Plan’. Responsibility for non-compliance lies with the two parties – the Greek Cypriots and the Turkish Cypriots – but also with the EU.  Yes, Cyprus has a right to its territorial integrity and to defend its rights to access economic resources on this territory, but it also has a responsibility to settle the ethnic conflict peacefully by granting and respecting the rights of the Turkish minority living on its territory.  Respecting the collective rights of minorities is a fundamental value within the European Union. A best practice has been developed in the EU to grant widespread autonomy to minorities. Look at the example of South Tyrol in Italy. It is high time to apply this best practice to every single Member State of the EU, which brings peace and stability. I believe this is in the best interests of both Greek and Turkish Cypriots and of the EU as well.

name: David McAllister (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the European Union has repeatedly called on Ankara to cease its illegal activities in the eastern Mediterranean, but Turkey has continued its drilling operations within Cypriot international waters. Let’s be very clear, these activities are illegal under international law. They reflect the regrettable change of Turkish foreign policy and they have a negative impact on Turkey-EU relations.  Madam High Representative, I welcome the adoption by the EU Foreign Affairs Council of a legal framework for possible sanctions against individuals and entities that are involved in the drilling activities, but as Mr Michael Gahler pointed out, now the names need to be added to the list. These sanctions are a necessary step to put pressure on Turkey to respect the sovereignty of Cyprus and therefore the integrity of our European Union territory.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D).
text: Mr President, measures against Turkey were rightly adopted by the Foreign Affairs Council as the first reaction to illegal drilling in the exclusive economic zone of Cyprus. However, these measures are sufficient in order for Turkey to be associated and to begin to respect international law, when it violates the human rights of its own inhabitants, when it invades Syria and makes ethnic cleansing against the Kurds, when it continues to own 38% of Cyprus, when it blackmails Europe with the refugee crisis, when it threatens Greece in the Aegean and when , finally, is it illegally invading a European exclusive economic zone? We have to be honest with each other. Unfortunately, Turkey does not understand either the calls or the dialogue. Turkey will only be mposed when it is subject to severe economic sanctions. Europe must respond to Turkey's daily challenges.

name: Antony Hook (Renew).
text: – Madam President, we welcome the Council’s decision to adopt sanctions in response to Turkey’s continued and illegal drilling in Cypriot territorial waters. Once again this Parliament must condemn Turkish actions. This latest infringement shows that the Turkish government is not respecting either the rule of law or the territory of other states. The EU will and must show solidarity with its Member State Cyprus, and following October’s Turkish military operations in northeast Syria, we called for action to be taken – strong action. How many more violations of international law must there be before we act? The European Parliament will show that our citizens will not condone either an illegal invasion or this illegal drilling. Let us send a clear message to Ankara and formally end Turkey’s status as an EU candidate country.

name: Paolo Borchia (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have recently been in this House dealing with debates in which Turkey is the protagonist on time, but the protagonist in the negative.  The decision taken by the Council to impose sanctions is certainly sacrosanct, but it is not enough to express solidarity with Cyprus or to prevent a few people involved in illegal drilling activities from travelling to Europe. Surely at the moment Erdogan will not be shaking. What is certain is that the scale and scale of the sanctions are not sufficient and are not proportionate to the damage suffered by the exclusive economic zone of Cyprus and to the aggressive behaviour of the Turks.  Ladies and gentlemen, we are faced with a reality, the Turkish one, which has never wanted to call into question its contradictions and which, above all, has always seen an ATM in the European Union and, unfortunately, this House has been complicit too many times.

name: Βαγγέλης Μεϊμαρακησ (PPE).
text: Madam President, today's debate reflects the obligation of all of us to protect our common borders, our common interests, the defence of the Cypriot EEZ as a European one and to impose an obligation of respect on all, as defined by the Law of the Sea and as European law requires. The European Union is an example of international legitimacy worldwide. This is because above all there are culture and respect, institutional structures and a just order. We have in many cases imposed sanctions, and last July we raised the issue of sanctions on Turkey as the EPP, with the well-known Council decision. But Turkey continues to challenge us. Over time it tramples on every rule, every acquis. It illegally occupies the northern part of Cyprus, violates Greek airspace and maritime space and uncontrollably encroachs on the European EEZ in the South-East Mediterranean, behaving as a regional major troublemaker. So can it be an important partner in the European Union, a friend and a good neighbour? We'd like to, too. Unfortunately, however, our neighbours with their attitude go beyond all limits and that is why we must consider redefining our relations with Turkey.

name: Evin Incir (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Erdoğan has become synonymous with violations of international law. Turkey, with the self-proclaimed 'paschan' Erdoğan, never manages to stop surprising us in its struggle to override fundamental rights and international law. Illegal gas drilling in the Economic Zone of Cyprus is one such example. Back in July, EU foreign ministers agreed on various types of sanctions against people profiting from illegal drilling, and on Monday they went a step further. But far from enough for Erdoğan to understand that enough is enough. Europe needs to be even more capable of action. Finally, today we celebrated the fall of the Berlin Wall 30 years ago. Now is the time to bring down another wall that divides one of our capitals – Nicosia. I believe that the only long-term way to move away from Turkey's constant aggression towards Cyprus is to put an end to the occupation. I therefore hope that all parties involved will welcome the new initiative for peace talks and the reunification of Cyprus taken by the UN Secretary-General, António Guterres. I hope that we will soon see a Cyprus free from occupation in which all its communities live together in peace and freedom.

name: Thierry Mariani (ID).
text: Madam President, the relationship between the European Union and Turkey is a toxic one: Turkey benefits from our assiduity and responds with contempt and provocation. I have the impression that this is a kind of sadomasochistic game where, finally, we protest and, finally, Turkey continues and makes fun of it. When the Turks invade northern Syria, the European Union protests. When President Erdogan threatens to exploit the refugees on his soil, in particular because of a civil war that he has continued to wage, we dare not say anything. The issue of Turkish drilling in the Cypriot sea must therefore be one provocation too. Turkey acts on this subject as on the subject of the Greek islands: it clearly attacks the sovereignty of a Member State. The European Union cannot be credible if it allows its members to be humiliated by states which it continues to fund elsewhere. His convictions, so far, are just words. No political action is taken. It is time to finally complete the accession process and renegotiate all agreements with Ankara. Today, Europe is complicit in Mr Erdogan's provocations by continuing to support him economically, when on the contrary it should support Greece and Cyprus, which are suffering from Mr Erdogan's provocations.

name: Λουκάς Φούρλας (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to reply to my colleague who said that this is an ethnic conflict. When a country invades your country, refugees two hundred thousand people, kills and, for 45 years, holds it, this is not ethnic conflict, it is a crime that must be punished. Cyprus is facing an unprecedented escalation of Turkey's ongoing illegal actions and the most serious violation of its sovereign rights to date. The third illegal drilling, in just five months, in the EEZ of the Republic of Cyprus, takes place on Plot 7 which was demarcated as early as 2003 between Cyprus and Egypt. In addition, Turkey encircles Cyprus, carrying out illegal activities with numerous warships. For too long Cyprus has been expecting not only verbal but also practical support from Europe. On 11 November, the Foreign Affairs Council adopted measures against Turkey. That's not an end in it. International law and the solidarity of our partners is, after all, what we have to oppose in Turkey's warships. When you defend Cyprus, you defend Europe, yourself.

name: Jérôme Rivière (ID).
text: Madam President, 1974 illegal occupation of Cyprus; 1983 proclamation of the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus; 2014 to 2018 Erdogan's Turkey maintains a dubious and complacent policy allowing oil sales from Daesh, which funds Islamist terrorism. It was at this time, four years ago, that the Bataclan attacks took place: 130 dead, 450 wounded. The attacks, which President Sassoli refused to honour the memory of the victims with a moment of silence this afternoon; 2019: Illegal drilling. Voices to denounce, that is what I can see tonight on all the benches, but no vote to act. Turkey cheats, Europe pays, Europe is in danger, but we are unable to draw the consequences. I will also ask the candidate Commissioner Oliver Vurhelyi tomorrow to find out when we will finally put an end to what my colleague Thierry Mariani called 'this sadomasochistic policy', which is the policy by which we continue to pay pre-accession credits to Turkey, when we know that it will never be a question of it ever being a member of the European Union.

name: Μανώλης Κεφαλογιάννης (PPE).
text: Madam President, the European Council adopts the framework for sanctions for Turkey's illegal drilling in the Eastern Mediterranean. It is a clear message of solidarity with Cyprus and the Cypriot people. Sanctions will be imposed against persons responsible for illegal drilling in the exclusive economic zone of Cyprus. They will be prohibited from going to the countries of the European Union. Their assets will be frozen. European Union persons will be prohibited from providing funds and funding to those illegally involved in drilling. The borders, Madam President, of the European Union are also the borders of Cyprus. The exclusive economic zone of the European Union is also the exclusive economic zone of the Republic of Cyprus. Strict sanctions should therefore be imposed on anyone who violates international law, the law of the sea, which is an integral part of the European acquis.

name: Ivan David (ID).
text: – Madam President, for almost two years now, the Turkish Navy has been carrying out armed attacks against ships and drilling platforms that have the consent of the Republic of Cyprus to exploratory wells. For example, the Italian companies Eni and the French company Total.  From February to July, Turkey carried out a naval blockade of the Republic of Cyprus. These are Turkey's acts of war against the Member States of the European Union under international law. In violation of international law, Turkish companies have started exploratory drilling in the sea shelf area, which falls under the sovereignty of the Republic of Cyprus.  Turkey has publicly claimed a number of Aegean islands, including Cyprus. When I started the Turkish attack on the Kurdish region of Rojava in northern Syria, I proposed possible effective measures on behalf of the ID faction. However, the Institutions of the European Union are completely paralysed by the lobbying of multinational corporations such as Philips or Siemens, which run factories together with AIOC owned by the Turkish army, which they help to arm. This is the European Union.

name: Στέλιος Κυμπουρόπουλος (PPE).
text: Madam President, what is our Europe? It is a place of stability and mutual respect based on rules. What rules do we want? First of all, Europe's peace is equal to peace in the application of the law. We must introduce the definition of Pax Europa. Pax Europa equals Pax Juris.  As long as we defend the law, we are Europe. We need the right means to implement this. We must move the Common Defence Policy forward quickly. Rapidly! Secondly, when it comes to the interest of a European partner that stems from the law, we must act together and immediately. Turkey has absolutely no right to violate territory or maritime zone of another sovereign state. The measures are in the right direction, but we also need trade sanctions. Turkey is with an army in three states and is also threatening us with the migrant convoy. We need robustness. He must know our answer to every additional threat. Europe you have self-respect, raise your head high!

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D).
text: – Madam President, and again we are talking about the double standard. I also wonder what infringement procedures would have been triggered, what voices would have risen through the Council of Europe, who and how they would have fought against the rule of law if these or less serious things had happened in an Eastern European state. And when we talk about flagrant violation of international law, are we just talking about penalties per natural or legal person?  To be clear: when it comes to some, the walls are maintained 30 years after the fall of Berlin, and when we talk about accession procedures and violations of international law, things can go on without any problems. To be even clearer? Northern Macedonia has been waiting for 15 years at the gates of the European Union, and Romania still wants to enter Schengen, and for some it can and for others not, just because there are economic conditionalities.  And speaking of which, Your Honor, we Romanians fulfil all the conditions. I ask you to enter Schengen.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, Turkey's illegalities in the waters of the European Union are not only an attack on Cyprus, they are essentially an attack on Europe and not only against our waters but also against the rules governing the existence of the European Union and impose full respect for international and European law. I'm sure you agree with me. So in the face of this neo-Ottoman expansionist Turkey, Cyprus is essentially judged on the credibility of the European Union, its ability to defend our very existence is judged. We can crush Erdogan's economy. We can impose a ban on the sale of weapons and many other things. That is why, Dear Mrs Mogherini, we thank you for what you have done so far, but we are investing in you for much more. Because I repeat: in Cyprus the credibility of the European Union and the values on which we all believe is judged, the existence of the Union is judged.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Dear Chairman, Turkey has no right to launch oil and gas search activities in an area declared by Cyprus as its exclusive economic zone. The EU has an obligation to help its member fight to preserve its resources and sovereignty. Despite this case causing new friction with Turkey, which is using the migrant crisis and its role in it to blackmail Europe, the principle of international law and law must be defended. I would recall this way that not all Members of the Union have declared exclusive economic zones and called on the Commission and the Council to encourage them to do so. To be able to effectively protect our resources and implement common policies, we need to have legal mechanisms to do so.

name: Mick Wallace (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, yes, Turkey doesn’t have any right to the resources of Cyprus, just the same as the Americans have no right to the resources of Syria.  The EU Council has called on Turkey to recognise the sovereignty and the sovereign rights of Cyprus. But does it mean anything? The EU has been complicit in Turkey’s behaviour, with all your arms dealings with them and with your 2016 refugee deal. You are so obsessed with Turkey helping you to keep the refugees out of Europe, you know what? Erdogan can do what he likes now. He’s shown it and proven it. He’s in Syria now! He invaded Syria last month. Not for the first time. He didn’t get a slap on the wrist for it – the sovereign territory of Syria!  And he is now in league with the free Syrian army, who were once described as ‘moderate rebels’ and were armed by western powers and now are complicit in killing Kurds.  You are complicit! Why don’t you stop?

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on Monday, the Council announced a framework of restrictive measures, which will allow Turkey to be penalised for illegal drilling in the eastern Mediterranean and in the waters of a Member State, Cyprus.  For the umpteenth time, Erdogan's response was a threat, a blackmail that is as blatant as it is unacceptable, that of not giving Europe jihadists belonging to Daesh.  For the umpteenth time, the statements and actions of the Turkish President openly challenge us, keeping us under blackmail, violating the most basic rights of its citizens on a daily basis, invading a neighbouring country, in which what can be called a genuine ethnic substitution is taking place and, finally, illegally entering the waters of a Member State of the Union, of which, at least on paper, it is taking place. , says he wants to be a part of it. How many more debates do it take to understand that Erdogan's Turkey should no longer be seen as a candidate for accession that must be closed, but rather a potentially fundamental partner, but certainly unreliable as it is ready for anything in order to gain more influence in the region? That is why we support these sanctions, which are necessary but not sufficient. That is why we are and will always stand shoulder to shoulder with the law and with our Cypriot friends.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I thank you all for, first of all, having expressed collectively what to me is the most important element, which is full solidarity with one of our Member States – Cyprus. This unity is needed because it is constantly tested from the outside and also, from time to time, from the inside. I believe it is a fundamental, key, vital element of our being together – the basic fact that if the rights, the sovereignty of one of our Member States is violated, as is the case in this moment with these Turkish drilling activities, the rest of the European Union has to come together and not only show solidarity but also act in solidarity with Cyprus. And this is why, for me, it has been key all over these months – I would say all over these years – to keep a constant contact and coordination with Cyprus itself, with one of our Member States, and design a way in which we could react and shape a common reaction together with Cyprus.  One question I would like to come back to, which is what next?  The framework is now established, which means that, now, Member States can – and I would expect that they would – present proposals for names, both of individuals and entities, that would then be analysed on the basis of a solid legal basis. You know that our sanction system is based on elements that need to resist the test of a court judgment in case they are appealed against. So Member States are now going to present proposals for names of individuals and entities, this is then going to be analysed by the Member States themselves through our Council procedures and, by unanimity, the Member States – the Council – is going to adopt further steps.  So this is what I would expect to happen next. This can go very fast or slower depending on different bodies and obviously also depending on the overall environment, because what I want to stress here is this – and I said it also in the beginning – sanctions, and the framework for introducing sanctions, is an instrument to put pressure and to try and provoke a change. The objective here is to change the attitude, stop the drillings and – I’m surprised that not many of you have underlined this – try to help the UN finding what would be the real solution, what would be the settlement of the Cyprus issue. A united Cyprus inside the European Union, this would be the game changer, not only for the drilling activities but also, and mainly, for Cyprus itself and for the European Union and for the entire region.  So this is why I referred to the upcoming meeting that Guterres has convened at the end of this month. It is, I believe, important for us to constantly stress this – the fact that, in this moment, the European Union is continuing to look at that solution, at that framework – at the UN framework – as the real solution for this issue and for the settlement as such, and that we are obviously ready to accompany this. We have discussed this with our Turkish counterparts several times, including in the recent months, including at my level – obviously this activity is going in the opposite direction, and this is an additional reason why we want to see them stopping. And first and foremost, let me stress it once again, to reaffirm that the European Union is united in defence of the sovereignty of one of our Member States.

name: Przewodnicząca. –
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Joachim Stanisław Brudziński (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – EU foreign ministers decided at the beginning of November this year on the possibility of introducing sanctions against Turkey for drilling around Cyprus. The legal framework provides for the possibility of imposing sanctions against individual persons or entities which are responsible for conducting wells the purpose of which is to obtain hydrocarbons without the consent of Cyprus in the territorial sea in the exclusive economic zone and on the mainland shelf of that country. The burdens that may be introduced relate to entities which engage in drilling in a financial, technical or material manner. Sanctions against persons, on the other hand, may consist of a ban on entry to the EU and a freezing of assets. This is not the first round of sledging activities. Previously, the EU decided to reduce aid funds and suspended air traffic negotiations. In the course of today's debate, it is necessary to call for a peaceful conclusion of the dispute in a spirit of negotiation. However, Cyprus' right to dispose of its territory must be fully and indisputably respected and Ankara should be called upon to put an end to illegal interference in its territory.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: in writing. – I agree with the EU Council decision to make sanctions against Turkey to try and stop their illegal drilling activities in Cyprus’ exclusive economic zone. The European Union is based on a strong legal framework, and that is why we must respect and enforce international law. If Turkey continues to violate international law set under the UN Convention on the Treaty of the Sea, then the EU has to take action against Turkey. Of course, in the long term we wish a peaceful settlement in Cyprus and eventually its reunification. But now it is our duty as countries of the EU to protect the sovereignty of our fellow Member States.
