name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, this is a critical moment for Bolivia, a moment when maximum restraint and the strongest possible sense of responsibility is needed, both inside and outside the country. Delicate moments like this require a firm rejection of violence and the highest level of statesmanship from all.  As you know, on 20 October, Bolivians voted in presidential elections that were marred by several irregularities. This has brought Bolivian citizens to the streets. It has led to violence and civil unrest across the country. Three people were killed, and more than 100 were injured. The current unrest follows months and years of tensions regarding the country’s political future.  As you all know, President Morales took the controversial decision to run for a fourth term in office, with the approval of the Constitutional Court but after failing to win a referendum to amend the Constitution itself. Tensions escalated around election day. When the polls closed, a preliminary results counting system showed that none of the candidates was likely to win enough votes in the first round and that a second round was the most plausible outcome. The system was then blocked for some 20 hours and, when it resumed, it registered a sharp change in the initial tendency. The Supreme Electoral Courts announced President Morales as the winner in the first round by a margin of just 0.5% of the votes. The Vice-President of the Court resigned during the counting process, in protest at the way the process was managed. As a consequence, demonstrations and violence broke out across the country. Five local election offices were set on fire and the most powerful civil society organisation called for a general strike. The Organisation of American States had deployed an election observation mission to Bolivia and it declared, in a preliminary report, that the best option would be for the two leading candidates to move on to the second round run-off. This assessment was endorsed by the European Union’s election expert mission that we had sent to the country, and by several EU Member States. We also expressed this position publicly on 24 October.  Given the widespread mistrust, the Bolivian government invited the Organisation of American States to carry out an electoral audit. The government agreed that the results of the audit would be binding. The audit was supported by some EU Member States with experts and also with some funding. The preliminary conclusions were announced last Monday. The audit identified a number of irregularities and concluded that the election results should be annulled and fresh elections should be held as soon as possible. In the following hours, the opposition asked President Morales to resign and so did the head of the Bolivian armed forces. President Morales, together with the Vice-President and a number of ministers, decided to step down and he has sought political asylum, as you know, in Mexico.  According to the Constitution, based on the absence and resignation of President, Vice-President and presidents and first vice-presidents of the Chambers, the Second Vice-President of the Senate would be next in line to assume the presidency in a caretaker role until new elections.  The European Union supports an institutional solution that allows for a caretaker interim leadership to prepare for new elections and to avoid a power vacuum which could have dire consequences for the entire country. In these very days and hours, we have been active – through our delegation in La Paz, whom I want to thank – in creating a space where government, opposition and civil society could meet and discuss a way out of this situation. We are actively supporting the mediation organised by the local Catholic church to help the Bolivian parties agree on a peaceful path that can lead to new elections. This mediation has already produced some first results in easing tensions partially and avoiding a worse escalation of violence.  At the Foreign Affairs Council last Monday, I updated the Foreign Ministers of the EU Member States on our work on the ground. We discussed how best to support Bolivia in preparation for the announced election. We are assessing the possibility of a new European Union mission to the country and of assistance in the election of a new Supreme Electoral Court.  Bolivia is a very important partner for the European Union. These years we have built a strong political cooperation and we have developed political dialogues where we discuss all issues, including those where we have disagreements or different views. We deployed an election expert mission to the country and we have several projects in support of Bolivia’s strong civil society.  In the last 14 years, Bolivia has certainly changed for the better. Poverty has dropped. Access to basic services has improved. Indigenous people have increasingly been included in the country’s public life. All these successes must be preserved, and this can only happen through a peaceful, political solution that respects the Constitution and the rule of law and that can bring the country to new, timely credible elections which faithfully reflect the will of the Bolivian people. Bolivia can come out of this crisis and consolidate its democratic institutions. It has all the potential to continue on a path of democracy, sustainable development and social inclusion. The coming weeks will be crucial. The European Union will continue to be at the side of the Bolivian people, as we have been throughout the years and, in particular, in this difficult moment in the country’s democratic life.

name: Pilar del Castillo Vera
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, I would like to begin by showing my concern about the very difficult situation in Bolivia. We cannot ignore that the trigger for what is happening has been the undisputed fraud in last October's presidential election in which Evo Morales proclaimed himself the winner.  A few days ago, we learned—as you yourself pointed out—the first conclusions of the electoral recount audit conducted by the Organization of American States and which shows that there was indeed fraud. The audit confirms, and intercomes, 'extremely serious irregularities': computer manipulations, forged acts, unacceptable incidents in the data chain of custody... Finally, so many and so relevant that it was impossible to validate the electoral process and, as a result, the OAS has urged new elections. In the face of such events, President Evo Morales' resignation was absolutely obligatory.  Bolivia's political fragility is certainly enormous and needs to be avoided. From the European Parliament, we must call on the Bolivian authorities and people to bring the political situation back through peaceful, democratic and constitutional channels. It is necessary that the new elections be carried out with all the guarantees, with all the transparency, and that there is also an international observation mission that is credible, competent and reliable.

name: Maria Manuel Leitão Marques
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Madam President, thank you, Mrs Mogherini for the information you have given us here. We Socialists and Democrats are very concerned about the political instability in Bolivia and the violence that followed the elections, after irregularities recognised by both the European Union and the Organization of American States have been detected. We want all Bolivian parties to take on their democratic responsibility and to organise new elections as soon as possible, ensuring adequate supervisory resources to this end so that the results are transparent, reliable and credible. We absolutely agree that the European Union must prepare itself, not only at this important transitional aid stage, as shown here, but to launch a new election observation mission in Bolivia, with which I am also pleased to know that it has already committed itself.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, thank you, Mrs Mogherini, for everything you have said. Bolivia needs to bring back the situation of violence and confrontation that characterizes its social and political life towards peace and to the word. Reset the situation. Heading for a civilized and democratic exit forces the closing of this crisis with new elections. The electoral fraud found by the Organization of American States definitively broke the public's trust in the system; a bankruptcy that began with the maneuver to foster a new mandate from President Evo Morales, clearly unconstitutional. That's why only new elections and a neutral and trustworthy referee can drive the situation.  These elections must be developed in peace. There are no expressions of violence against people, threats against the media, clashes or assaults on public office, which we reject altogether. And they need an independent and credible arbitrator to shield the process from any attempt at fraud. The armed forces and the police must refrain from influencing political processes and undergoing civilian control. The Inter-American Commission on Human Rights has just recalled this. This agency denounces and rejects violence as a means of political coertion, calls for eradicating hate speech and calls for respect for plurality, with particular attention to that represented by indigenous communities.  Finally, poverty, inequality and marginalization that still affect very important layers of the Bolivian population must continue to be fought. That is why we are committed to new elections with full guarantees and transparency, to which a European observation mission could contribute. A national dialogue for peace and reconciliation sponsored by the institutions should be promoted and plans and strategies that encourage sustainable, inclusive and inclusive development in the country must be accelerated. Mrs Mogherini, we look forward to the European Union's strong support for this strategy, as it has always done.

name: Benoît Biteau
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Madam Vice-President, as Mrs Mogherini well described, the organisation of the elections in Bolivia, doubts about the validity of the results and, finally, the forced departure of Evo Morales to Mexico have opened a period of uncertainty and tumult which we deplore. The European Union must act so that this country, which has experienced a period of historic stability for 14 years, can quickly return to the path of democracy, and we must not limit our attention to the only lithium deposits available on its territory. Madam Vice-President, we must therefore call for the restoration of democracy in Bolivia and we must contribute to this by supporting the rapid organisation of pluralistic elections. I propose to study, with the Organization of American States, what concrete measures we can propose to take action in this direction. Personally, I am in favour, as the Union has done on many occasions, of sending an observation mission to ensure the transparency of the electoral process. Calm and stability can only be restored if Bolivians are assured of the democratic legitimacy of their future president.

name: Markus Buchheit
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the way in which In Bolivia, at least, democracy seems to be on the rise again. The attempted electoral fraud by Evo Morales was stopped by the people. But instead of resenting, the left-wing governments in Latin America are panicking, and with them the local left-wing parties are falling into the clutches of the phrases and the tinkering. Instead of admitting defeat, they talk of a coup. However, this is simply not true. Morales' decline is the demise of a socialist who has failed in democracy. And there will be some people in the room who will fail in terms of democracy if they do not finally stop sand in people's eyes – as in your failed attempt to change the agenda item here tonight towards a coup d'état.  Dear colleagues from the GUE/NGL, you are not only running false prophets, you are false prophets. Ideology is more important to them than the facts. Morales was increasingly a usurper, and you should finally respect the bolivian people's firm will to get rid of him.

name: Hermann Tertsch
text: ECR Group. – Madam President, I think it is clear what is being tried on the part of the left: it is to try to protect a Morales who , this time, at last – has not done well for his electoral fraud.  He came... In fact, he only had one presidential legislature—legally, constitutionally. Then, through all sorts of operations, he has been prolonging his life as president of Bolivia—as a faithful ally of Chavez, first; Maduro, then—to launch the cocaine business, money laundering... And in the screening of the Sao Paulo Forum, which is responsible for the moment there is a huge project of destabilization throughout the continent.  Morales is part of it. The money he collected yesterday, with the plane, on Asunción, on his way to Mexico, is also proof of that.  We are facing a major destabilization operation in Latin America and one of the few good news is that Morales has finally had this fraud gone wrong. That's why he mourns the left, because he needs these for other blows: chile's—the one they're carrying out or trying—or Ecuador's, which they tried.

name: Manu Pineda
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, despite the speeches we have heard here this afternoon, what has happened in Bolivia has a name: coup d'am. When the military orders the president elected by the people at the ballot box to leave his responsibility, that's a coup d'e.e. When the opposition, supported by the police and the army, pursues the leaders and militants of the government party, which has just won the election, that's called a coup d'eta. Let us not forget that there is no debate about the victory of Evo Morales. The OAS, an organization not suspected of being Bolshevik or Bolivarian, has not called into question the victory of Evo Morales; what it has called into question is that it has achieved it by more than ten points difference.  Evo Morales assumed the recommendations of the OAS and called for new elections. However, far from reducing tension and seeking a peaceful way out, the coupist will of a racist and classist opposition is confirmed, to which what concerns him is not fraud, what he is concerned about is that the vote of an indigenous man is worth the same as that of a target. As persecutions have continued, looting of MAS leadership houses and repression of indigenous communities, and despite the resignation of President Evo Morales himself and all the senior officials of the country's most important institutions, trying to avoid a blood bath, we call on this Parliament to condemn the coup, call on the European Embassies to give refuge to the persecuted and join the request for free elections in which all the nominations that wish can take place and in which the decision of the Bolivian people is respected.

name: Ivan Vilibor Sinčić (NI).
text: – Dear Chairman, I will try to give a geopolitical view in my discussion of the situation in Bolivia. I want to say at the outset that I am against any foreign interventions and that we must, as in the case of Venezuela, give the people of Bolivia to solve this problem on its own and to find its own way.  Evo Morales has committed one mortal sin in his long-standing politics because he has ruled there since 2006, and that mortal sin is that he used, that is, he used the resources of his Bolivian state for the benefit of his Bolivian people. This is something that the imperialists, above all the American establishment who constantly, therefore, know what the U.S. policy towards Central and South America has been trying to undermine for decades. It is precisely in the service of this establishment that the jackals undermine sovereign states, these structures operate under the guise of democracy and will always have democracy, but they are not interested in democracy. They are interested in political influence and resource control. They use coups, invasions, sanctions, funding for radical groups.  However, it should be said why this is happening here and now, because of lithium. Litium is an element of the future. It is used in electronics, for batteries, for laptops, electric vehicles, etc. There is currently a struggle for dominance in the lithyne triangle. Thus, there is 50% of lithium production, 50-70% of the world's resources. The industrialization plan that Evo Morales had is to build fourteen factories by 2024, or forty by 2030. Whether it will be built now and who will get rich on the litia, whether it will be the Bolivian people, I doubt it.

name: Leopoldo López Gil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, evo Morales is solely responsible for the situation in Bolivia.  In 2016 Morales lost a referendum to support his third re-election; mocked the Constitution, which prevented him from introducing himself to new elections; obstructed the rule of law; called elections and tried to usurp the government. The OAS issued its audit of the electoral process on 20 October and declared the fraud invalidity.  To prevent reality from being distorted, we must call things by name. To say that there were only technical failures in the electoral system constitutes a lack of respect for Bolivian society: it was a planned action for the sole purpose of usurping power against sovereign will. There was no coup d'eer.  Bolivia seeks a constitutional and peaceful exit to its crisis. It needs guarantees and needs support for the appointment of acting President Jeanine Añez, who must lead the country to transparent elections.  The European Union is required to attend and collaborate with the sending of an election observation mission, as Mrs Mogherini rightly established last Monday.

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: – Madam President, High Representative, today the European Parliament talks about what is happening in Bolivia. Firstly, to express deep concern about the country's political and social facts and to send a clear and forceful message condemning violence. Violence that has also been political over the past few days. Clearly, and the OAS has said so, that serious irregularities were detected during bolivia's last electoral process. We not only take good note, but demand a democratic exit to the current situation, with free and fair elections, monitored by the international community and also by the European Union. But at a time like this, when there has been a serious institutional deterioration of the country ⸺not only during the last days, but also during the last months and years, as has been said⸺, it must be remembered that within the Constitution there are no shortcuts. There are no shortcuts and fewer shortcuts that are linked to violence. That is why we ask for elections, institutionality, peace and future for Bolivia.

name: José Ramón Bauzá Díaz (Renew).
text: – Madam President, shortly after learning of the possible fraud in the recent elections in Bolivia, we personally urge Mrs Mogherini to guarantee the entire electoral process with transparency and, above all, impartiality.  Time, unfortunately, has given us reason, as confirmed, in this case, by the last audit of the Organization of American States, which shows that Evo Morales manipulated the elections to secure a fourth electoral process in its favour. And that's a real coup d'am.  Popular pressure and international pressure on this situation have forced the resignation of Evo Morales. His flight from the country, to evade justice, has also prevented what was an electoral process, to become a major grievance with a constitutional crisis.  That is why, Mrs Mogherini, we ask you and we demand that you measure in this situation, that you measure between the parties to ensure that violence does not scale and that there be a repetition in the electoral process.  Mrs Mogherini of the European Union depends on Bolivia not becoming a new Venezuela.

name: Anna Cavazzini (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Latin America is in turmoil, and now Bolivia too. The country, which has been on the right track, at least for a time, is experiencing extreme, shocking violence. I believe that we should not now make Bolivia the scene of all these ideological debates – as the extreme right is trying to do – but we should act and find solutions.  The EU must do everything in its power to de-escalate this explosive situation. We must work to put an end to polarisation and violence. It is very important that the military withdraws and that the military and the police withdraw and stop using force. It is also important that Morales calls on his supporters to be peaceful, just as the opposition leaders must call on their people to show restraint.  The country must return to constitutionality as soon as possible. This includes immediate new elections under international observation. Of course, Evo Morales must be granted the right to return. For the future, it is quite clear that the increasingly authoritarian style of the last years of government has been a major problem and must definitely be overcome. But the social and social achievements of recent years must not be reversed under any circumstances.

name: Idoia Villanueva Ruiz (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, stabilization and democracy in Latin America are questioned whenever coups are fought, as in Honduras, or legal wars against leaders, as in Lula's case, at last free. Evo Morales agreed to an OAS audit, including an election replay. But the far right was never concerned about the electoral procedure, but about overthrowing Morales at all costs. The army has led to a coup d'eer, which we strongly condemn. A brutally racist opposition that cruelly attacks indigenous peoples. We are seeing a military uprising and a persecution against the leaders of the MAS, which has forced them to hide and seek asylum. Declare what Trump declares, which he seems to miss in 1973, the European Union cannot look the other way. We must ensure the physical integrity of the leaders and the safety of the people of Bolivia, condemn the coup, violence, promote asylum, prevent self-proclaiming and ensure that democracy is restored in Bolivia. Democracy that is at stake not only in Latin America, but also around the world and also in Europe.

name: José Manuel García-Margallo y Marfil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, High Representative, Morales's victory, three times with the same census as now, was historic: for the first time, an indigenous man came to the presidency of the Republic.  In the early years, he achieved undoubted successes that I will not deny; but then succumbed to the aphrodisiac of power.  He called a referendum so that he could be perpetuated in the presidency, lost it and presented himself: this is called "authoritarianism"; distorted the results: that, in Spanish, is called a "punch"; forced the electoral authorities controlled by him to lay them down: this is called "misappropriation"; he did not call a second round, which is what he should have done: that is called "disobedience to the Constitution"; and fled to Mexico, leaving his people abandoned: that's already called "desertion."  That is why it is now for the European Union to convene clean and transparent elections with electoral observation and participation.

name: Inma Rodríguez-Piñero (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we all know what situation Bolivia is now in. We know where Mr. Morales is, we know what the outcome of the audit of the Organization of American States— of the electoral audit — was, and we know that Mr. Morales recognized the need to call and convene new elections and appoint new members of the electoral tribunal. What is perhaps said less is that we have had the opportunity to see that Mr Morales' escape has also been clearly conditioned by the distortion caused by the armed forces and by the national police, facts which should not happen again, because the consequences of what was the previous regime are already being suffered.  It is therefore essential that the European Union makes available to Bolivia all the tools at its disposal to assist it and support it in achieving the development and recovery of the democratic situation, and that, of course, all political and social actors put an end to violence and restore democratic conditions. And allow me a second, Madam President, to say goodbye to Mrs Mogherini, because I may not have the opportunity to do so in the next House, and I would like to congratulate her on her intense and extensive work and wish her all the best in the new season.

name: Massimiliano Smeriglio (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, dear High Representative, morales is likely to have made mistakes, but we cannot fail to see that a violent military coup d'état is taking place in Bolivia which endangers the safety and lives of thousands of people and which we must stop immediately. The Morales government has had the historical merit of breaking with an apartheid regime towards the Aymara Indian communities and of increasing the well-being of the country. In these hours, by breaking down the rule of law, without the necessary quorum and outside democratic rules, we have witnessed the self-proclaimation of a President of the Republic.  Last Sunday, the Holy Father appealed for negotiations and called on all Bolivians to await in a constructive spirit the results of the process of revising the elections. Also on 10 November, Morales announced the decision to renew the members of the Electoral Commission and called new general elections. Nevertheless, the violence has not subsided, but has become systematic.  I therefore ask you to make every effort to contribute to the restoration of democratic dialectics and legality, in order to avoid further bloodshed.  Finally, if the situation so requires, I would ask you to call on all Member States to open embassies in order to guarantee asylum and shelter in case of need.

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D).
text: – Madam President, there are three things I could not have imagined in the 21st century: election fraud, military intervention in the electoral process, which means on the face a coup d'état and violence. I am a doctor, an emergency doctor in Iaşi, Romania, the "Nicolae Oblu" Emergency Clinical Hospital, and I believe that human rights must be respected, especially in this century when their problem becomes more and more current – from the right to health to the right to free choice and the right to be protected when expressing your political opinions.  And I congratulate you, Mrs Mogherini, for trying, through dialogue, to defuse a situation that is hard to imagine, and on the other hand, I am still asking myself the question of how such a situation can be managed when it comes to intervening at the level of another state. If things should be resolved, the healthy solution seems to me to be independent observers for new democratic elections, and if we are talking about violence I think that the same attitude should be felt every time, to condemn it, to talk about the army or to intervene in the electoral process, whether it is happening in Bolivia or in European countries and especially in the West and not only there.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I want to pay tribute to Patricia Arce, the indigenous mayor of Vinto, who was dragged from her office last week by a right-wing anti-government mob, who cut off her hair, covered her in red paint and paraded her barefoot on the streets, before forcing her to sign a resignation letter. The town hall was also torched and ransacked.  Under President Morales, the indigenous and poor of Bolivia have seen their rights and their standard of living increase. Inequality is the greatest scourge in our world today, but taking from the rich and giving to the poor always threatens the elite: the big businesses, the large corporations and in this case American interests. Jeanine Áñez has now declared herself interim President, endorsed by Bolivia’s Constitutional Court. Well, the country’s constitution states that when a new President comes without an electoral process, an election must be called within 90 days. So a new electoral court should be appointed, offering guarantees of transparent elections as well as ensuring election observers from across the world. Free, fair and peaceful elections are the only way to unite the country.

name: Sandra Pereira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, what has been going on in Bolivia after the elections on 20 October has only one name: a coup d'état. The will expressed by the people dictated the re-election of Evo Morales as president of the Plurinational Republic of Bolivia. Bolivian reactionary and undemocratic forces, with the complicit action of the police and military forces, supported by unacceptable external pressures and interference, did not accept the result and carried out a violent terrorist action against bolivian popular movements, their leaders and state leaders. The multiple calls for dialogue and political solution initiatives led by Evo Morales were of no use. It is a coup d'état that is part of the offensive of American imperialism in Latin America, with the real objective of defeating the process of sovereign affirmation of economic and social progress and emancipation that has been taking place in Bolivia since 2006. It is necessary to reject this coup d'état and to sympathize with the Bolivian people, defending their democracy, their sovereignty and their peace.

name: Mick Wallace (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I would like to address Ms Mogherini. You say that the Organization of American States (OAS) say there were severe irregularities in the 20 October election. Why didn’t they give us the evidence of it? You also said that Morales won by 0.5%. No, he won by 10.5%. He needed the 0.5% to get over the 10% mark. He is clearly the most favoured candidate in Bolivia at the moment. Your analysis of how the election went, how the quick vote was stopped – there was a very good explanation for it. If it’s over 80%, it’s normal to announce it then. The official vote started, and rather than having two votes running at the one time, they decided to run with the official one and only restarted the other one under pressure. Your arguments don’t hold water. The two boys who called for the removal – the head of police, General Kaliman, and the Police Commissioner, Calderón Mariscal – it’s interesting that both of them served as attachés in Washington. The US has not got clean hands here, and it beggars belief, Madame, that you will not call this what it is. This was a military coup. A good day for neoliberalism, but a bad day for the people of Bolivia.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I have listened carefully to all different interventions. Let me say that I see, obviously, some variety of opinion on the analysis of the situation, but overall I also see first of all the strong support for a European Union role and presence to accompany the country now. This is exactly what we have been doing, quietly but constantly, in these hours, in these days, and this is why I want to repeat here my thanks to our EU delegation staff on the ground that has done remarkable work in these weeks, in difficult circumstances, and we will continue to do so. I’ve seen also among Member States a certain convergence on the fact that we might be ready – we need to be ready – to accompany the process further, and again I think it is important for all of us to call on statesmanship and responsibility and restraint in these moments, because again we are talking about a country that has made a development trajectory of positive change over these years and has all the potential to consolidate democracy and inclusion and social development in the coming years. So they need to know – especially the Bolivian people need to know – we are there to accompany and to support this process, and I’m glad to see that the large majority of this Chamber is supporting this approach.

name: Przewodnicząca. –
text: I close the debate. Motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure will be published at a later date. The vote will take place during the second monthly session in November. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – In Bolivia there has been a coup d'état, which has pushed away the legitimate President Evo Morales and which deserves our strongest condemnation.  Bolivian reactionary and undemocratic forces, with the complicit action of the police and military forces, supported by external interference, after disrespecting the outcome of the elections, carried out a violent terrorist action against bolivian popular movements, their leaders and state leaders, despite the multiple calls for dialogue and political solution initiatives led by Evo Morales.  Contrary to what some hypocritically claim, the now consummated coup d'état has nothing to do with a so-like defense of democracy, which it violently disrespects, rather part of the ongoing offensive of American imperialism in Latin America, with the real objective of defeating the process of sovereign affirmation, economic and social progress and emancipation that has been taking place in Bolivia since 2006.  From here we reaffirm our solidarity with the popular, progressive and revolutionary forces of Bolivia, with the resistance and struggle of the bolivian workers and people against the violent coup repression and in defense of their sovereignty, democracy, economic and social progress, peace and cooperation.

name: Przewodnicząca. –
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Chile (2019/2916(RSP)). Before starting the debate, I would like to inform you that in order to apply for questions from the room and blue cards, you can both register as before and use the new electronic registration system. name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, over the past months, we have seen a sequence of quite dramatic events in Chile. The country has been shaken by a wave of protests and violent incidents. The government has declared curfews and a state of emergency. It deployed troops on the streets for the first time since Chile returned to democracy 30 years ago.  Both the curfews and the state of emergency were lifted; protests, mostly peaceful, continued throughout the country. On 25 October, they culminated in the biggest demonstration in Chile’s history, with over one million people marching to request profound social and economic changes. The mobilisation continues up to date and it has brought support from across all sectors of society.  The toll of the crisis is high. The National Institute for Human Rights, which is an independent state institution, has reported 22 deaths. Five of them have been directly attributed to the security forces. Two thousand people have been injured, over 5 000 have been detained, almost 300 judicial actions have been presented, including for homicides, sexual violence and cruel treatment. Human rights violations have mobilised constant demonstrations calling for justice over the abuses, while in the margins of peaceful protests, serious acts of violence occur. We call once again for a swift investigation of all crimes and human rights violations from all sides.  This is an important moment for Chile’s democracy, a strong democracy built after decades of dictatorship, a democracy that now needs a new social contract with a stronger focus on the fight against inequalities and on social inclusion.  The government has started to respond to protests with a series of important measures – the announcement of a social agenda, a cabinet reshuffle, the launching of a national citizens’ dialogue. Chile has announced that it will not host the APEC and COP summits, in order to focus on the domestic priorities, and last Monday a process leading to a new constitution was launched, addressing a long—standing aspiration of many Chileans as the current constitution still dates back to the times of the dictatorship.  We also highly appreciate the government’s invitation to the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights and to other human rights organisations to send experts.  It is essential to keep listening to the requests that are coming from the people of Chile and to address them. During these weeks, over 3.5 million Chileans have demonstrated peacefully in town hall meetings and local assemblies. They are showing their determination to build a society that is more inclusive and more just. Such a vibrant society is the foundation of the functioning of a strong democracy and this request for justice and equality must not, and, I believe, cannot, be overshadowed by the acts of violence committed by a minority in the margins of the demonstrations. In fact, the large majority of the citizens and all political parties have condemned violence as unacceptable from all sides.  Chile’s human rights institutions are playing a critical role in coordinating with the government, monitoring the rights of Chileans and working tirelessly to protect those rights. These institutions have all been shaped by the last 30 years of democracy and they now play a critical role in the protection of that same democracy. It is also important that the economic players and the private sector in its majority have affirmed they are ready to do their part in support of a new inclusive social pact.  We have condemned from the very beginning all acts of violence and called for respect for human rights and the due investigation of all violations. Our delegation in Santiago and the 19 Member States’ Ambassadors resident in Chile have passed exactly the same message, in a coordinated manner, at all levels and all our interlocutors in the government have expressed their absolute, irrevocable and irreversible commitment to respect for human rights in all circumstances.  We want to reconfirm our readiness to support the country and its people in this moment of transition. First of all, we have decided to maintain our cooperation programmes that were dedicated to COP25, to support Chile in its Presidency beyond the summit that will now be held in Spain. To address the protesters’ demand for social justice, it is also essential to tackle the impact of climate change and to make the green transition more sustainable.  But there is much more. The European Union is Chile’s third largest trade partner and its first foreign investor. Chile is the European Union’s oldest partner in Latin America and we are now negotiating the modernisation of our Association Agreements. Our countries have solid ties. Both Europe and Chile have experienced the tragedy of dictatorship and the return to freedom.  In the darkest moments of Chile’s history, we opened our doors to our brothers and sisters fleeing from persecution. I come myself from a country that experienced that, very closely. We are more than just friends, we are family and today we share the Chilean people’s aspiration to greater social justice and a more inclusive democracy. These values are at the core of our new Association Agreements which focus exactly on sustainable development, human rights and climate action.  Europe is ready to accompany Chile in this delicate moment of its history towards a new and a more inclusive social contract. We have full confidence that Chile’s democracy is strong enough to address its people’s demands and to use this moment as a step to grow even stronger and more inclusive.

name: Leopoldo López Gil
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, it is undeniable that the situation chile is currently in is a social crisis. I think it is indecent of us that this issue should be compared to the situation in Bolivia. This perception, completely removed from reality, is what we give to the international community when both issues are discussed at the same time in this Parliament. This issue was already dealt with at the Delegation's meeting in the Joint Parliamentary Committee, attended by the Chilean ambassador to account for current developments.  First, on 18 October, numerous protests began in Chile, mostly peacefully, denouncing social inequalities. Along with these demonstrations, a coordinated series of attacks on metro stations and shops broke out, shattering that rose to no less than nearly $2 billion, to which the Government had to resort to the state of emergency for ten days. At the same time, in the face of allegations of excessive use of force by the police, the Government expressly asked the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights to send a mission to Chile to investigate this. Mr Piñera's Government is currently negotiating urgent social measures. Days earlier, the minimum wage was increased. He agreed to reduce the working day. Work is under way to achieve pension, health and education agreements. In addition, the Government is negotiating the possible amendment of the Constitution. This is the action of a democratic and responsible government, in order to find a solution to the crisis. This is the action of a country that is a privileged partner of the European Union – with which we have an Association Agreement – and one of the most stable democracies in the region, to which we are treating poorly compared it to Bolivia in this House. We must accompany the return of peace in Chile, maintaining all support programmes.

name: Inma Rodríguez-Piñero
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, thank you, Mrs Mogherini, for your presentation.  As Chair of the Delegation to the EU-Chile Joint Parliamentary Committee, I would like to begin by transferring the condolences of all Members of this European Parliament to the relatives and relatives of the victims and to those wounded by the violence that has occurred in Chile and, of course, to move and express the total revulsion of violence, wherever it comes from.  I would also like to point out that Chile is a reliable and very important partner for the European Union; it is a country with which we are joined by deep ties, a great country that enjoys a consolidated democracy, committed to human rights and an advocate of multilateralism, well-regulated fair trade and the environment.  However, as we all know, since mid-October Chile has been attending an unprecedented escalation of social protests since the democratic transition of the 1990s. A crisis whose causes, of course, are complex—very complex—and have undoubtedly been managed over decades.  Chile has achieved, it is true, an intense reduction in extreme poverty, but at the same time, a huge - huge - middle class has grown, highly precarious and accumulates growing discontent, which has been fuelled by inequality and lower-than-expected economic growth and which had been Mr Piñera's electoral promise. There is therefore a great deal of frustration for a large part of the population and, moreover, this is accompanied by a loss of confidence, which is not from now on, in the institutions, in the Constitution and, of course, also, unfortunately, in political parties.  We therefore recognize the frustrations and legitimate demands of the millions of peaceful Chileans and demand respect for human rights and this process of renewal, reforms of a social contract that renews the democracy and hope of the Chilean people.

name: Jordi Cañas
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, everything that happens in Latin America, in Latin America, affects Europe, matters to Europe. Everything that happens in Chile affects and matters to Europe and this Parliament. But what we are discussing today in this House is the political situation in Chile. A political situation arising from a problem, a social outburst, the result of a political context to which Europe is no stranger. In Europe we also have problems of inequality. We also have problems of growing inequality because of an unfair and inefficient distribution. It is also true that there are demands for solving social problems, there are health problems, there are educational problems, there are pension problems, there is fear of the future.  And then why do we bring this debate here? Because this House is not a space where Chile's legitimate ideological and political debate is cloned or replicated. Why are you bringing him here? Well, I don't know, but there seems to be a strange collusion between the Socialists and the Eurochavistas, who are defenders of the human rights and democratic procedures of all those countries that are not led by the satrapies, of which they are partners and friends. So human rights do matter, so it does matter democratic procedures and elections, the cleanliness of elections. But, however, when they're friends, then we care less. We don't even want to debate.  Chile has problems to which Europe is no stranger. We've lived them in our countries. We remember the yellow vests in France and the different movements that have taken place in different European countries. Then Europe has to be next to Chile, it is true, because its problems, I repeat, are no strangers to us. And it may be a good scenario where measures can be implemented that can serve to strengthen trust between citizens and their politicians. But we do not have to do so from a kind of false paternalism and disrespecting an ally and a partner who has been a guarantee of stability in the region and which some want to destabilize with spurous debates at a time of instability through the area as a whole.  Finally, I believe that from the European Parliament we have to send a message of fraternity to be at the side of Chilean society, its rulers and its leaders to correct their problems, because their problems, as I said, are also ours.

name: Martin Häusling
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her For the first time since the Pinochet dictatorship, the streets of Santiago are once again in the streets of Santiago, and the President is seemingly hopelessly overwhelmed to start a dialogue because he refuses to tackle the real causes of this crisis. It is not just the constitutional issue, it is the question of extreme social inequality in this country. I myself have been a member of the delegation to the EU-Chile Joint Parliamentary Committee for ten years and I have seen this myself. These differences in society are so stark that 50% of the population owns only 2.1% of the national wealth. This leads to inequality, and that leads to rebellion. The other is that no country has privatized as much as Chile – from water to education, to pensions to health care. All this affects the poor in this society. Here, too, Chile must take a different path. The European Union has always maintained good trade relations. But perhaps we should also take some care of the human rights situation. Perhaps we should also devote ourselves to conflicts such as those with the Mapuche in order to really be taken seriously in a country where this social history is in fact the greatest factor of unrest. We cannot now continue as before and negotiate agreements, but Europe must take on the role of mediator. That is the appeal to you, Mrs Mogherini.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, despite the repression of the Chilean people, the right of this Parliament has tried to block us from talking about Chile. Why? Because Chile is the Latin American laboratory of neoliberal policies since Pinochet; because it's not 30 pesos, but it's 30 years of wild neoliberalism that people are rising up against on the street.  And when the people have said "enough is enough", the response has been military on the street and a repression of the dictatorship itself, because, in Chile, the transition to democracy was marked by the impunity of the dictatorship. That's why what's going on now is allowed.  And the European Union cannot continue to look the other way. We must suspend trade agreements with Chile until human rights are respected. Is it possible that human rights are respected with a president who has declared war on his people? The answer is no. A president who declares war on his people only deserves to end up in the dumpster of history.  From here, all our support for people fighting in Chile.

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Madam High Representative, we , who are talking about Chile today, because we are talking about what is happening in the international community as a whole, and this is also the turn of this Parliament — want to send, I believe, two humble messages.  One: a listening message. Willing to listen to the Chilean people, who in recent weeks have starred in the largest mobilizations in their history as a country. And secondly, a message of support and accompaniment, of willingness to help, not only to the Chilean people, but to the institutions and political system of the country, which have sent, as a whole, a message also of willingness to address the situation and face reforms. Reforms how? Because it turns out that millions of Chileans, over the past few weeks, have expressed a willingness to demand greater social justice, more inclusive economic growth and better access to public services.  We would also like to remind each other that these demonstrations have not been partisan, ideologicalized, that people and citizens have called for transversality when these changes were being called for; remember that demands and demonstrations must always be peaceful, and have not always been peaceful in Chile; condemn violence; regret, unfortunately, the deaths. And finally, we want to remember that Chile is a friend, Chile is an ally. It will continue to be, of the people and their institutions. And that inequality today, in Europe and around the world, is not only a social threat, but a threat to the stability of our institutions.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, for weeks in Chile, the government has been violently suppressing protests against President Piñera. There are deaths, thousands of injuries, violence, arbitrary arrests, even rape and torture in barracks, up to systematic mutilation in the eyes, we have read about that too. We need a thorough investigation into political and criminal responsibilities. The European Union cannot continue with its association agreement without investing more in respect for human rights. We need a new Constitution that will take the country all the way out of the dictatorship period. We need an end to the special guarantees granted to the military, some at the centre of corruption.  After these demonstrations and these events, things cannot remain that way. As in other countries, the government, I think, must resign, open a new phase for a new Constitution, for a new social phase, for more justice for the Chilean people. I think many of us will continue to be by his side.

name: Juozas Olekas (S&D).
text: – Dear President, indeed, first of all, we must express our condolences to the relatives of the people who died in Chile. As you said, Chile is our trading partner with a long history. But we cannot allow civilians to die in Chile today. People who have gone out to demand their rights, demand social guarantees, demand constitutional amendments, demand ecological things. It is therefore our duty in the European Parliament and our European Commission to monitor the situation and influence the protection of the lives of these people and their demands. We really support people who defend their rights by democratic methods by taking to the streets and making provisions. I therefore call on the honourable High Representative to continue to monitor the situation and to express a united European position so that civilians are not killed.

name: Hermann Tertsch (ECR).
text: – Madam President, we are talking about Chile. I sometimes, when I hear about violence and human rights violations, I think we are talking about Cuba, or that we are talking about Venezuela. They talk over there about landfills... In landfills are the rubbish that Venezuelans eat after these twenty years of 21st century socialism.  Chile is the most prosperous and inclusive country in South America—the one that most—that they wanted to get into communism in the early 1970s and which, however, has been growing for thirty years, creating that middle class they have now talked about; a country that really is an example and that's why they want to take it down.  What we're talking about is bringing down a government of a president who was elected in 2017 with ten points of advantage over those who now want to take him down on the street.  No one has died in Chile for saying their opinion or peacefully protesting; in Chile there have been brutal clashes with the police, which have been wanted to burn alive, against which attacks have been created of an absolutely unusual violence, which have a lot to do with the mobilization against democracies that is being generated from Cuba and Venezuela. That's what's happening in Chile: that real dissatisfaction is being helped by interventions and interference from outside, and they are communist interference.

name: Pernando Barrena Arza (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Chile has for years been the laboratory of neoliberal policies imposed by the IMF and the World Bank and has applied a brutal model that is depleting the population, which has been forced to protest in the streets for the practical disappearance of the most sensitive social coverages. And these protests have been confronted by the Government of Piñera through brutal repressive methods that violate the most basic rights and link directly with the darkest memories of Pinochet's dictatorship.  In the previous point we have just addressed the issue of Bolivia, and let me say that what is happening in Bolivia is no stranger to Chile. We could say that there is a widespread neoliberal response, a new "Monroe doctrine" that aims to bring order in the backyard of the United States at a time when there is an uptick in left-wing movements in the Southern Cone.  I wanted to say that, in my opinion, not only the future of Chile is at stake, but the future of Latin America in the coming years. And the Union, Mrs Mogherini, cannot remain hesitant: it must urge the cessation of repression by the Government of Piñera and accompany the Chilean people, who demand a constituent assembly and redirect Chile's course towards a fairer and more inclusive social democracy.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, as I know that we are running late, I will only take a few minutes to say, first of all, that most of the views that were expressed on this point will obviously guide our action in the coming weeks and months, and those of the next Commission, I’m sure. Be sure that what happens in Chile will always be at the centre of our attention because of the ties that are there – not only economic ties, but as I said, social ties, even family ties. It’s a country that, because of history and culture, is very close to Europe, and this is why we will continue to be at the side of Chile in this delicate moment. Let me also conclude by expressing my thanks for the work that Parliament has been doing and is doing in its relations with Chile. I want to conclude with that, in particular on Chile, but also on other situations. The work that you do with parliamentary diplomacy is vital to the work of European Union diplomacy, and I want to thank you for that. Representing the vibrant European democracy with a variety of views – it is extremely important, your engagement, your constant work with the parliaments around the world, but also with civil society, human rights activists and the private sector. I believe this is an integral part of our work, and I would like to use this opportunity to thank you also for the work you’re doing to keep the ties between the European people and the people in Chile through parliamentary diplomacy work.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Sandra Pereira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Millions of people have gone out in Chile and have resisted the violent repression of the police and military forces at the behest of President Piñera's government. This is how the recurrent fallacy of the Chilean 'exemplary economic model', a 'model' that was implemented since 1973, was implemented in two weeks with the imposition of a brutal and bloody fascist dictatorship in Chile, whose neoliberal policies are reflected, among other serious aspects, in a brutal intensification of exploitation and the destruction of the central role of the State in ensuring democratic (social) rights , economic and cultural), in particular by privatising virtually all spheres of economic life, public services (health, education, transport) and social security, handing them over to large monopolistic groups.  Chile has become, in recent decades, one of the countries with the highest social inequality in the world and the Chilean people are on the streets demanding a change of policy and the end of the constitutional regime that supports it. They therefore deserve all our solidarity.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statement on International day to end impunity for crimes against journalists (2019/2878(RSP)). Before I open the debate, I would like to inform you that, in order to request catch-the-eye and blue cards, it will be possible to use both the standard registration and the new system allowing Members to register electronically. Therefore, I invite you to always bring your voting cards. Should you wish to register for catch-the-eye, I invite you to do so starting from now, without waiting for the end of the debate.  Having said this, I open the debate. I am happy to welcome the Presidency and I would like to give the floor immediately to Ms Tuppurainen.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members of Parliament, the International Day to End Impunity for Crimes against Journalists was established in memory of the death of Ghislaine Dupont and Claude Verlon, two French journalists killed while reporting in Mali on 2 November 2013. Media freedom is an indispensable pillar of our democratic societies. Journalists are among the guardians of properly-functioning democracies. They act as public watchdogs, helping to inform and empower citizens. Where there is no freedom of speech there is no democracy. For this reason, freedom of expression, media freedom and pluralism are guaranteed in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. Yet across the globe, journalists face risks and attacks simply for carrying out their work. Too often investigations into violence or threats of violence against journalists and media outlets are slow, incomplete and fail to bring the offenders to justice. 31 journalists have been killed worldwide in 2019 alone; more than 800 in the last decade. In 9 out of 10 cases, the killers go unpunished. Impunity is the key obstacle to ensuring journalists’ safety, resulting in self-censorship and a chilling effect on the exercise of freedom of expression. The investigations and judicial proceedings following the horrific and unacceptable killings of Maltese journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia and Slovak journalist Ján Kuciak have to this day not been concluded. These crimes have shocked European public opinion. The European Parliament has made clear in its resolutions on media pluralism and media freedom in the European Union that we have a duty to guarantee the freedom of expression and of the press, including the safety and security of journalists. We note the call of this assembly on Member State authorities to ensure the protection of investigative journalists from any form of intimidation, defamation charges, threats or physical attacks, as well as to create a permanent financial scheme in support of independent investigative journalism. On behalf of the Council, I can say that we are aware of the responsibility our governments have to protect journalists and different media freedom. We will continue with all appropriate means possible to respect and protect freedom of expression. The Council held a dialogue on Media Pluralism and the Rule of Law in the Digital Age in November 2017. The related Presidency conclusions reflected the importance of the issue and repeated the commitment by the Council and the Member States to secure a safe working environment for journalists as part of their duty to uphold fundamental rights, democracy and the rule of law.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, this is an important opportunity to recall and mark this day, to recall its origins that have just been set out, and to underline what it stands for. We believe freedom of expression is a fundamental human right that should apply for everyone, everywhere. An environment where journalists are free to report on any topic, on all platforms, without censoring themselves, is the key to media freedom. But today, journalists’ safety is not guaranteed, even – as we just heard – in Europe, as far too often journalists and media workers find themselves attacked, persecuted, harassed or intimidated for carrying out their work. Again, we’ve just heard some striking figures: in 2018 alone, 94 journalists and media staff were killed across the globe in work-related incidents, as reported by the International Federation of Journalists. Hundreds more have been subjected to arbitrary arrest or detention without ever having been tried in court. According to UNESCO, only 10% of the 930 cases of killings of journalists from 2006 to 2016 worldwide have as yet been resolved. Impunity for these crimes – getting away with these crimes – multiplies their impact. It erodes democratic societies by fuelling fear, mistrust and anxiety. So what are we trying to do about this? Respect for freedom of expression is integrated in all our policies and our development programmes. The EU provides support and legal assistance via the mechanism for human rights defenders, a network that delivers fast response for human rights defenders under threat, including covering journalists. The EU also supports the European Centre for Press and Media Freedom and the Media Pluralism Monitor. In 2019 a series of pilot projects will foster cooperation between journalists and self-regulatory bodies, fund cross-border investigative journalism and increase support for journalists who find themselves under threat. The Commission has proposed to include a dedicated budget in the next MFF as part of the Creative Europe programme. The Commission has also spearheaded work to counter online incitement to violence and hatred by means of the Code of Conduct on Combating Illegal Hate Speech. On this too, the EU is currently transposing new legislative provisions in the Directive on Audiovisual Media Services. In these and other ways, we consistently stand up for the themes symbolised by this day, and we oppose, in bilateral contacts with third countries, as well as in multilateral and regional discussions, any legislation, regulation or political pressure that does not respect international human rights standards on freedom of expression. Simply proclaiming the right to freedom of expression is not enough – it is not sufficient. States must also fulfil their obligation to protect freedom of expression and the safety of journalists by providing an enabling legal environment, by taking criminal threats against journalists seriously, and by vigorously prosecuting actual attacks. As has just been recalled, the recent assassinations of investigative journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia and Ján Kuciak, and indeed of the Saudi national, Jamal Khashoggi, show, sadly, that no part of the world is immune to such crimes. The Commission recently highlighted the fundamental role of journalists and free and pluralistic media in promoting and upholding the rule of law in its Communication on strengthening the rule of law within the Union of July this year. And again, on the actual International Day, on 2 November, in her declaration, the High Representative paid tribute to all those who lost their lives and suffered attacks in the exercise of their freedom of expression online and offline. The EU firmly condemns the increase in crimes against journalists, both offline and online in cyberspace. The Commission, on the particular case that's already been raised, has called on the Maltese authorities, in the case of Mrs Caruana Galizia, to ensure that justice is done. After all, a functioning democracy cannot thrive without free, diverse and independent media. Madam President, honourable Members, thank you for the opportunity to discuss this very important theme today.

name: Roberta Metsola
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, the defence of a free media is not something that can or will lose significance today, or ever. Without an unshackled media we would only have the illusion of a proper democracy, a mockery of how the rule of law should function. The media is the gatekeeper, the body that separates fact from fiction.  So when shadowy multinationals, illicit banks and unscrupulous politicians implicated in serious money-laundering and corruption activities start to abuse the courts to go after our journalists, the attack is serious. When journalists are assassinated it is an attack on all of us. And it would be impossible, as we have just heard, to speak today without paying tribute to the courage and resolve of Daphne Caruana Galizia. Daphne was assassinated two years ago.  The masterminds behind her assassination remain at large. The subjects of her investigations remain protected from investigation at the highest political levels. It is not acceptable. This is outrageous! And specifically, we need to protect journalists – not only from physical harm, but from vexatious lawsuits. We need an EU anti-SLAPP law and we need to make EU funds available to media houses so that they can fight their corner. Media freedom is a cornerstone of our European societies and more than a fundamental right, it is a fundamental rule of the way we are governed. It is as important as an independent judiciary and should be seen as such. And this Saturday, in Valletta, Malta and Gozo will be out in the streets demanding better.

name: Maria Arena
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Madam President, when journalists are targeted, society as a whole pays the price. It is not me who is saying this, it is Guterres, on the occasion of the International Day of the End of Impunity for Crimes Against Journalists on 2 November. Over the past 12 years, more than 1,000 journalists have been murdered for simply practising their profession. This represents an average of one death every four days. In 2018 alone, the International Federation of Journalists counts 94 murders of journalists or people working in the media. These people were murdered for exercising a fundamental freedom guaranteed by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, Article 19. While the European Union has also seen its own territory on its territory, the murder of journalists, it has been said, of Maltese, Slovak and Bulgarian journalists. What is the European Union's action plan to combat these crimes? Europe must also defend its values more vigorously abroad: what response has Europe given to Saudi Arabia, following the assassination of Mr Khashoggi? Finally, how can we combat the media, which become propaganda organs, as we know, when these media, which become propaganda organs, either held by the government or held by financial forces and powers, are impossible for self-employed workers and independent journalists to carry out their work in exactly the freedom. Again, what work can the European Union do to support and guarantee the independence of the media both on its territory and outside its territory?

name: Ramona Strugariu
text: on behalf of the Renew group. – Madam President, on 2 November we celebrated the International Day of Stopping the impunity of crimes against journalists. Last year, indeed, 94 journalists lost their lives because they had the courage to write about corruption and abuses of power. Last February, Slovak journalist Ján Kuciak was murdered in mafia style with his partner, and last month we commemorated two years since the death of Daphne Caruana Galizia, two years in which the judiciary failed to identify those who ordered this assassination.  These crimes took place in the European Union, here, where we claim to guarantee the freedom and safety of journalists. I had Daphne's son Matthew Caruana Galizia, right here in the European Parliament, with 40 other journalists from Europe, at that memorial, and I tell you that it was hard for me to look him in the eye, as a politician, because all of us here have done a little bit to stop the crimes against journalists.  Criminals remain at large, and uncomfortable journalists are constantly harassed with long and expensive lawsuits built by professional law firms. Daphne's family inherited nearly 30 such defamation lawsuits against her because she dared to tell the truth. We need to do much more for journalists, we need to support them with the anti-SLAPP law, with funding and rapid response mechanisms in case of threats or pressure.  Yes, journalists investigate politicians, but those who have no concern looking back into their past support freedom of the press and understand the importance of the right to information and protection of those who speak the truth with dignity, courage and honesty, independent journalists. Commissioner King, you mention those pilot projects about financing independent investigative journalists. As a technocrat, I wrote one of those projects myself and it got an A from the Commission. It needs to be a permanent fund for investigative journalists and we need anti-SLAPP legislation.

name: Alice Kuhnke
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Journalists who no longer dare to scrutinise us politicians and other powers because the price is too high are as sad as a clear sign that our democracy is being fundamentally shaken. It is a shame that there are politicians in this Assembly too who threaten journalists and question their scrutiny. All democrats must act now. That is why we Greens want a common EU strategy to be developed and to be aimed at strengthening the protection of journalists and strengthening media freedom. We want it to include the creation of an independent hotline to which journalists who are subjected to harassment and intimidation can turn to and get help. We want it to include an action plan to strengthen media freedom in europe. And we want it to include a mandate for the Commission to monitor the situation of journalists in all Member States and to introduce country-by-country reporting with recommendations.

name: Marco Dreosto
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like once again to stress the need to defend the freedom of all journalists, so that they can practise their profession without being subjected to violence or intimidation.  Too often we see cases where politically non-aligned journalists are threatened or discriminated against for their opinions, in the silence of the media and politics. It has also just happened in Italy, when the journalist Fausto Biloslavo, of the Giornale, who is critical of illegal immigration and the role of NGOs in the Mediterranean, was tempted to gag. First he was prevented from having access to the University of Trento by a group of students and militants of the Italian far left, and then there was the attempt to boycott his conference with the throwing of objects, slaps and even punches. All this in the almost indifference of the highest Italian media. And then, ladies and gentlemen, if Europe had any coherence, it should remember that the largest prison in the world for journalists is in Turkey, in that Turkey that still some in this Parliament would like to bring into Europe.

name: Anna Fotyga
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I pay tribute to journalists all over the world, in particular those reporting from conflict areas, as well as investigative ones challenging autocratic or corrupt regimes. Without their secure work we face chaos and disinformation and therefore, in commemorating the International Day, we have to remember those perishing, according to UNESCO, predominantly in Arab countries, in Latin America, in Asia, in Africa but, unfortunately, also in Europe, in the European Union – Daphne Galizia and Ján Kuciak. I call for our increased efforts, use of every possible tool to eradicate impunity. There is almost 90% of impunity now for all crimes against journalists.

name: Clare Daly
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, we have on the International Day to End Impunity for Crimes against Journalists, a journalist who has been found by the United Nations Human Rights Council to have been arbitrarily detained for seven years in an EU Member State by the actions of two other EU Member States, and we say nothing. We have a United Nations Special Rapporteur report on torture which investigates this case and says that this journalist is showing symptoms of prolonged exposure to psychological torture, and we say nothing. I am, of course, talking about the case of Julian Assange; the words are those of Nils Melzer, the UN rapporteur who will be joining us tomorrow morning to discuss this case because it is, of course, not about the life of one man, although that man’s life is in danger. This is the defining press freedom case of our age: the attempts of the US authorities to extradite, under the Espionage Act, and facing potentially 175 years in prison, Julian Assange for exposing war crimes in 2010, including the crime of murdering two Iraqi journalists exposed in the ‘collateral murder’ video.  We talk an awful lot in here about the rule of law and human rights. Anybody who cares about these issues has to be on the side of Julian Assange in the impending battle of his extradition case, which is opening in Britain in February.

name: Dino Giarrusso (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, just today we mentioned the collapse of the Berlin Wall, but I believe that there are still walls in Europe that are as difficult to break down as the one that stifles genuine freedom of the press.  Psychological, economic and physical violence in a trail of blood that counts martyrs such as Giovanni Spampinato, Peppino Impastato, Mario French, Pippo Fava, Giancarlo Siani and more recently Ján Kuciak, Victoria Marinova and Daphne Caruana Galizia. Their inquiries were useful to the people but uncomfortable for the organised crime that killed them for it. It is an unacceptable horror, just as it is unacceptable that journalists such as Paolo Borrometi should today be deprived of full personal freedom and forced to live under escort. Unacceptable to fear for the fate of Julian Assange. It is unacceptable for many journalists today to be paid a few euros for working hours and to be conditioned by the interests of too many unclean publishers.  Ladies and gentlemen, Europe must do much, much more. We have a duty to create a cultural climate in which absolute freedom to inform and to be informed is universally regarded as a priority right. A cultural climate in which those who peddle fake news are punished, in which those publishers who have interests that condition their journalists and limit their freedom and in which, therefore, any kind of psychological, economic and physical violence against free journalism must be condemned today and made impossible tomorrow.  Only then will we really have torn down the walls that restrict our genuine freedom.

name: Peter Pollák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, attacks on journalists directly threaten democracy. The case of the murdered Ján Kuciak even shows that journalists are in danger of both health and life. The man suspected of ordering Kuciak's murder reached the top officials of Slovakia, prosecutors, judges or politicians. He used the entire state apparatus, including the police, to lure journalists to know all the information about them, even to find out where their children go to school or who they meet. There were dozens of journalists, one of whom, unfortunately with the help of a hit by the state forces, was viciously killed. Thanks also to Europol and public pressure after the murder of Ján Kuciak and his girlfriend, the most people have taken to the streets in Slovakia since the Velvet Revolution. Thanks to this public pressure, we have murder suspects behind bars, but we have not yet won. Journalists in Slovakia continue to be the target of attacks. Before his death, Kuciak wrote that the mafia was in control of the entire state, police officers, prosecutors, judges and politicians alike. The judges handled their sentences, with politicians, with police officers and prosecutors investigating their own cases. The investigation into the murder case so far confirms that Kuciak was right. Ordinary people in Slovakia who today read how easily the mafia asserted their interests through the state apparatus are desperate, they have stopped believing in the rule of law. Slovakia is awaiting important parliamentary elections in a few months' time, which will decide whether to return to the path of democracy, where journalists will also feel safe, or follow in the footsteps of the mafia, which has been showing us for several months that it can also cooperate with fascists. We must all side with the journalists. They must not be threatened with their work in any country. It is our duty to stand by them, even when we are criticised as politicians.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
