text: - Madam President, Finnish Presidency, Commissioner King, as Chairman of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, I join the concern expressed by my colleagues in this debate about how to end impunity for crimes against journalists, in accordance with the Resolution adopted by the United Nations, which points out on 2 November as an occasion to speak out loud that freedom of expression , information pluralism and, above all, the fight against misinformation and hate speech do not take place in remote whereabouts or other latitudes, but also in the European Union and its Member States; and that any form of attack, harassment, intimidation, physical or moral violence against journalists, or pointing them out as alleged enemies of the enraged mass, or preventing them from accessing press conferences, discriminating against them depending on the issue to report on, is also a frontal attack on freedom of expression and the dignity of journalists.  This impunity must also be put to an end in the European Union.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa (Renew).
text: – Madam President, we all pay the price when journalists are afraid, when they are censored, when they self-censor or when they are attacked. A friend of mine was murdered in 2001 and we had other friends who were persecuted. I know the situation.  And now we are talking about impunity, because even if we think of distant countries, what I have just told you happened in Spain, in northern Spain. And the murders of Dafne Caruana or Jan Kuciak have happened in Malta or Slovakia — we all pay for it - and so far these last two murders have gone unpunished.  We are also trying to censor journalists in our countries," Commissioner King said.  The report of Reporters Without Borders is less well known, which has reported that more than fifty attacks on journalists have occurred in Catalonia in the last year; who have made it fanatical secessionists trying to build an "identity state" because they cannot bear to show all the social plurality. Reporters Without Borders' report literally states that "from Korean slogans and inrepation we have moved on to insults, harassment and harassment and, finally, to physical aggression. It's a pattern that's always repeated in the spirals of hatred for the journalist."  Today we say in this Parliament enough! pressure and attacks on the media anywhere in the world. We also say enough! coercion of groups or governments seeking to gag journalists. Because it is a new and very serious threat to the democratic rule of law, in Europe and around the world.

name: Gwendoline Delbos-Corfield (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, in its report on the rule of law in Hungary, this Parliament raised freedom of the press among the twelve points. The concentration of media ownership in the hands of oligarchs continues to increase in Hungary, and a huge consortium was recently created to bring together nearly 500 private media, cable television, radio and websites as well as all the regional daily press. Independent media have become very rare. This is an extreme example of what is sometimes happening today in the European Union itself. But make no mistake: in all Member States, governments have the temptation to undermine freedom of expression and would often like to prevent disturbing investigations or words critical of them. The Reporters Without Borders ranking shows that no country is immune from crimes against journalists. At the other end of the scale, however, the fight against terrorism, a legitimate concern of states, is increasingly a pretext for the accumulation of illegitimate laws of censorship against freedom of expression. Finally, the digital world brings us new questions: how to punish hate speech, protect our children, prevent discriminatory speech, without ever entering an Orwell-like world of mass surveillance and censorship. It is all these questions that this Parliament, the Commission and the Council must ask themselves and it is with a firm commitment to protect press freedom that they can answer them. For a living democracy and a functional rule of law, freedom of the press, this fourth power, is an essential element.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ID).
text: Madam President, freedom of the press is a fundamental value of European civilisation. Unfortunately, it is threatened by two serious dangers. The first is the violence against investigative journalists, such as Ms Galizia, who was murdered in Malta in 2017 while investigating a corruption case. The second danger is more insidious, but must also be combated, I mean censorship that anesthetizes freedom of the press. In Italy, for example, the Val d'Aosta Order of Journalists suspended a journalist, Andrea Manfrin, for three months, whose only wrong is criticizing the presence of illegal aliens. This suspension is based on a text that prohibits journalists from using the word "clandestine". Foreigners in an illegal situation are, however, a reality that is futile to deny. The honour of journalism is to tell the truth, no matter what the price.

name: Jorge Buxadé Villalba (ECR).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it cannot be forgotten that the International Day to End Impunity for Crimes against Journalists has its origins precisely in commemoration of the murder of two French journalists in Mali at the hands of Al-Qaeda.  However, impunity continues and there are few effective measures for the protection of journalists, especially when it comes to political issues, here in the European Union, because it seems that there are journalists of one level and others of second level depending on their ideological position. This condemns the aggressions of journalists as a result of violent acts of the far left or totalitarian and anti-democratic separatist movements, such as those that happen in my country, Catalonia , in Spain, in my Catalonia region.  Recently, we have already been told, Reporters Without Borders reported more than fifty assaults on journalists in Catalonia by the separatists. The Federation of Journalists' Associations of Spain also issued a statement in this regard. These are terrorist organizations that storm the streets and attack precisely journalists.  On this point too, the European Parliament must be demanding, and it cannot be knew that, for ideological reasons, there are some good and some bad.

name: Javier Zarzalejos (PPE).
text: – Madam President, oblivion is also a form of impunity; and that is precisely why, as a Basque and as a Spaniard, I do not want to refer to the attacks, extortion and murders of journalists perpetrated by the terrorist gang ETA throughout its criminal career.  A journalist, José María Portell, was recently murdered in Bilbao. Then there was the murder thwarted in Pamplona of José Javier Uranga. Years later, in San Sebastián, Santiago Oleaga and, days later, the columnist of the newspaper El Mundo José Luis López de Lacalle.  Many other journalists were persecuted, wounded or maimed. Many editorials were assaulted or attacked. And all the informants disagreed, threatened and pointed out.  Documents in which ETA strategists asked the gang to attack journalists and pointed to those who had to be killed are public.  Well, while this House condemns the murders of journalists today, pays tribute to his memory and expresses the need to protect them, I must remember that not a single one of the murders and attacks I have mentioned has been condemned by ETA's political heirs. And, I add, ETA's political heirs are still represented in this House today.  I insist: forgetfulness is also a form of cruel impunity with victims. Therefore, we must not forget those who lost their lives to exercise freedom and it is our obligation to continue to point out those who, among us too, justified their murder and still justify it today.

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D).
text: –Madam President, whoever attacks a journalist attacks our right to expression and especially our right to information, and will never succeed. Today I adopt and have always adopted Voltaire's words: "I do not necessarily agree with everything you say, but I will always be the one to defend to the death your right to say it." And indeed, investigative journalism is increasingly difficult to do in Europe, in Europe, where we would not expect such abominable acts to be, and fallen journalists are proof of what they are saying today. Investigative journalists are economically harassed, they are legally harassed, and even physical assault is increasingly common.  I am, I told you, a doctor, an emergency doctor in Iasi Romania, and every time I look for concrete solutions. So I tabled, on the one hand, in the Romanian Parliament, a bill stating very clearly that two per cent of the damage recovered as a result of a journalistic investigation should be borne by the person making this investigation, because the economic pressure is extremely high and, often of an economic nature, cannot withstand it.  Secondly, we need to seek legal solutions, legal aid at European level, and I believe that that creative programme can be a solution so that journalists are no longer legally harassed. And if we are talking about aggression, let us think about it, it is a project that we proposed in the Romanian Parliament, it was about emergency doctors who are often assaulted, let us frame, let us give a new legal classification to the aggression of the journalist on the mission, that of outrage, if you want similar to the policeman or the gendarme, so that any such acts do not go unpunished. I welcome your presence today and I hope we do not just keep it empty, because unity in diversity also means the right to free expression.

name: Christophe Grudler (Renew).
text: Madam President, let us remember that this international day in honour of journalists who were victims of their duty was set up in memory of two French journalists, Ghislaine Dupont and Claude Verlon, who were murdered in Mali on 2 November 2013. In twelve years, 1,000 journalists have been killed simply for trying to inform. Today, there are at least 250 journalists imprisoned around the world. Half of it is in Egypt, China or Turkey. When journalists are targeted, democracy and freedom of thought are attacked. I will end with a special case of current events: the Turkish journalist and writer Ahmet Altan has just been arrested again, a week after being released and released from prison. I urge the Turkish authorities to release him immediately. Show the world your commitment to freedom of the press, show the world your will, not to isolate yourself, but to take a step towards a fairer world.

name: Hannah Neumann (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, information is the enemy of repression, and that is why repressive regimes target journalists first. They intimidate them; they block media outlets; they kill them. And when they get away with it, they move on. Social media is blocked; tweets can get you into prison. Next, the internet is shut down. But how can we actually know what is happening on the streets of Baghdad, Hong Kong, Santiago de Chile if no one is left to report? Tonight, I received a message from a friend in Iraq. ‘Every night at six,’ he said, ‘they shut down the internet and then they come and kill us and no one is there to watch.’ Sadly, this friend is right. Impunity of crimes against journalists just encourages another round of violence and repression. I want us to break this pattern here and elsewhere because there can never be freedom without freedom of the press.

name: Mathilde Androuët (ID).
text: Madam President, independent journalism is the essential tool of transparency and therefore an essential pillar for the construction of democratic conscience. Any attack on journalists must legitimately outrage us. However, I would like to recall the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi on 2 October 2018 at the Saudi consulate in Istanbul, Turkey. Such atrocities - in this case, we are talking about dismemberment! However, the many evidence of affection of our European leaders towards the culprits and accomplices have not slowed down. Moreover, while it is normal to condemn crimes against non-European journalists, I would like to hear the same thing when our journalists on European soil are subjected to death threats. Denouncing crimes is good; preventing them is even better. In France today, on the anniversary of the Bataclan attacks, Ms. Zineb El Rhazoui and Mr. Zemmour, both journalists and, for the first time, the victim of attacks, are subjected to death threats or violence, sometimes relayed or even encouraged on television sets. I would therefore like to hear here a firm and unanimous condemnation against all forms of violence against all journalists, without exception and without regard for their opinions. The denunciation of crimes is not based on words but on concrete political acts.

name: David Casa (PPE).
text: – Sinjura President, fil-maġġoranza tal-każi, l-atti kriminali kontra l-ġurnalisti jistgħu jsiru biss meta dawk li jkunu nkixfu jibqgħu fil-poter. Huwa proprju hawnhekk meta l-ġurnalisti jispi大大aw f'riskju. L-akbar eżempju huwa ta' Daphne Caruana Galizia naturalment. Hija kixfet dettalji gravi ta' kriminalità u korruzzjoni minn nies fil-poter u għadhom sal-ġurnata tal-lum imexxu l-Uffi大大ju tal-Prim Ministru f'Malta. U għadhom sal-lum imexxu l-Power Station li dwarha hemm suspetti kbar ta' korruzzjoni. Dawn huma nies korrotti u, wara dak li seħħ fil-Qorti din il-ġimgħa, nistgħu ngħiduha aktar bla tlaqliq. Keith Schembri, Chief of Staff tal-Prim Ministru ta' Malta, baqa' jinsiisti li ma jweġibx mistoqsijiet marbuta mal-investigazzjonijiet li kienet qiegħda tagħmel Daphne Caruana Galizia għax, fi kliemu, jinkrimina lilu nnifsu, u xorta baqa' jmexxi l-aktar uffiħ大ju b'saħħtu f'Malta! Uffi大大ju li għandu poteri kbar fuq il-Pulizija! Mhux ta' b'xejn il-Gvern Malti għadu ma jridx jisma' mill-Kunsill tal-Ewropa. Qiegħed jibqa' jinsisti l-Gvern ta' Malta li ma jagħmilx inkjesta pubblika indipendenti ta' vera dwar il-qtil ta' Daphne Caruana Galizia. Mhux ta' b'xejn illi, jekk b'miraklu l-Gvern jagħmel inkjesta indipendenti, iridu li r-rapport tal-inkjesta jibqa' moħbi mill-pubbliku. U rrid hawn qabel nagħlaq nirringrazzja, Sinjura President, flower-membri ta' din il-kamra, minn hawk aspett politiku ta' din il-kamra, li llum għadhom qegħdin jinsistu li l-istorja ta' Daphne għadha ħja f'din l-istituzzjoni tant importanti fl-Unjoni Ewropea u li m'aħniex ser nieqfu sakemm inkunu nafu l-verità dwar il qtil ta' Daphne u' Ján Kuciak.

name: Daniel Freund (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Daphne Galizia and Jon Kuciak are just two examples of journalists murdered in the middle of Europe. They were murdered for uncovering corruption. Their fates, however, are only the tip of the iceberg, because here in Europe, too, more and more journalists are coming under pressure, being harassed, fired, attacked or even murdered. Let me be very clear: there is no freedom of the press when research into corruption in the middle of Europe ends with death. But without journalists, without free, without diverse press, there is no democracy. Without journalists, there is no control of the powerful, where other institutions fail, and without journalists we open the door to corruption and nepotism. That is why protecting this important task, which journalists are performing, is one of the core tasks of our democracy. If our Member States, the Member States of the European Union, fail in this protection, do not protect fundamental rights here in the Union, then the EU must intervene and, if necessary, cut the funds for the Member States. For it must be our promise as the European Parliament to journalists that we do everything we can to protect this essential task.

name: Радан Кънев (PPE).
text: – Madam President, today we are discussing horrific crimes against journalists. But do we discuss why these crimes are committed? We discuss impunity, but do we discuss what our roots are, what is the way we come to this impunity? And these are, first of all, censorship in the media, secondly – the self-censorship of media owners who are ready to even fire their best journalists in order to protect themselves from persecution by the government and the mafia. The pressure of the power itself on the free media, the bribery of power, of the media, including the bribery of media with European Union money, concentration and monopolies in the media sphere – these are the foundations of impunity, this is why criminals are so brave in their attacks on the media. But all this – both censorship and self-censorship, and pressure, and bribery, and monopolies – are the real crimes against media freedom and against citizens' rights. These are crimes that do not happen one, two, three times a decade in individual countries. They happen every day in my homeland and in many more Member States of the European Union.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, a democratic society must protect and promote the independence of the media and journalists, including financial resources. We are seeing that, even in the countries of the European Union, journalists are under pressure. They're being blackmailed, restrained. Even murdered. Daphne Galizia, Ján Kuciak knew too much. That's why they had to die to be silenced forever. But I believe they didn't die in vain. Their message lives, and people have raised their voices against their killers.  The European Parliament also remembers them, as do dozens of others who have died in their homes or beyond Europe's borders. We call for their protection. And the first, crucial measure is that their murders are investigated and the killers punished. I believe we can achieve that.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Madam President, media and press freedom are cornerstones of civilised societies and it’s right that we pay tribute to those who have been killed in the course of reporting the news and investigating in the public interest.  But while we remember the more than 1 000 journalists killed globally in the past 12 years, we must be outspoken in defence of those subject to sustained harassment and abuse today. And I’d like to draw particular attention to the case of the staff of the BBC Persian service who’ve been subject to sustained persecution by the Iranian authorities, as have their families, inside Iran. These are mainly EU—Iranian dual nationals, mainly female journalists, and what’s particularly sinister in this case is the targeting via sexual defamation and harassment of these journalists.  We should recognise that this is a trend growing around the world. Female journalists are three times more likely to be subject to abuse than their male counterparts are. We can’t wring our hands about this any longer. We need action to protect our journalists from today.

name: Manon Aubry (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, during this debate on crimes against journalists, I too wanted to pay tribute to journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia, who was murdered just two years ago. Murdered for daring to expose corruption scandals involving prominent Maltese politicians; murdered for conducting outstanding investigative and public interest work; murdered because she had dared to do her job as a journalist. Pressure and intimidation of journalists who attack the powerful is a major democratic issue and the current trend is growing and not reassuring, including in France, where journalists covering demonstrations have been victims of police violence and where media investigating French arms sales in Yemen have been summoned by the intelligence services. How then can such pressures, such restrictions on press freedom, be tolerated? NGOs and citizens who raise the alarm need an independent press, which is not in the hands of a very limited number of actors and is able to inform the general public. I have seen this in the past in my work at Oxfam to combat tax evasion, journalists are often the last bulwark against total impunity. Finally, I wanted to quote Beaumarchais: "without the freedom to blame, there is no flattering praise". For taking this freedom, some like Daphne have paid a terrible price, so more than ever, let us protect this freedom without which our democracies would be nothing but fiction.

name: Carmen Avram (S&D).
text: – Madam President, as a former journalist, I very much cherish the International Day to end impunity for crimes against journalists around the world and I want to pay tribute to those who were killed while trying to find out the truth, and because of that. Journalists and their work are essential for any healthy democratic society. I want to take this opportunity to stress that their vital mission is not only hampered when journalists are killed or imprisoned but that also, very often now, their daily lives and work are being made difficult in many ways.  Reporters Without Borders published their flagship annual World Press Freedom Index in April this year, revealing that worldwide, authoritarian regimes continue to tighten their grip on the media. Europe itself, according to the document, has its share of incidents, with the work of investigative reporters being obstructed more and more. European journalists are subject to many forms of pressure, intimidation and, increasingly, to judicial harassment.  I myself, as a former journalist, as I said, know many cases and witnessed various obstacles, from threats to violence, in the daily work of my fellow colleagues from Romania, with basically none of these incidents being punished or even investigated. Therefore, we must never forget the importance of journalists, the increasingly dangerous environment they are working in and we must find an efficient way to protect them, because we need the truth.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for this debate. We very much agree that we should be very concerned about crimes against journalists and impunity for such crimes wherever that is taking place. But in particular, as many of you have underlined, we also have to focus on our own countries, the European Union, because these things do happen on our own doorstep and, as a number of you have underlined, a free media, a media where journalists can report on any topic, on all platforms, without needing to censor themselves is a cornerstone of our societies. Indeed, that journalistic freedom of expression is a key part of the values that we seek to defend in our European Union.  The points that you have raised, including some of the new, detailed, points that have been raised, are very important to us. I set out briefly some of the things that we are already doing and planning to do, but we will now study very closely some of the additional suggestions that you have raised. This subject will be a key subject for the new Commission, taken forward by my colleague Commissioner Jourová, who would have very much liked to be with you this evening. This is one of the subjects that she holds very close to her heart and you can count on her to pursue it vigorously.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you very much for your very important interventions.  Let me assure you, once again, that the Presidency and the Council as a whole is committed to the fight against impunity for crimes against journalists. The freedoms of expression and the press enshrined in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights need to be guaranteed in all Member States, and those who fall victim to crimes must receive justice. The killing of Daphne Caruana Galizia proves that no region of the world is immune to such crimes. We reiterate our commitment to combatting impunity for crimes against journalists and to continue using all appropriate means possible to respect and to protect freedom of expression and to ensure the safety of journalists and media workers. The EU already provides financial and expert support for human rights defenders and media monitoring in the EU. We, further, foster the protection of journalists, bloggers and media workers in many countries with financial and expert support. May I also remind you that media pluralism and the rights of journalists are also an important aspect of the rule of law, which is a high priority of the Finnish Council Presidency. We are tireless in protecting the respect of the rule of law. We will continue to watch very closely the relevant investigations and we will stand firmly behind journalists around the world. I can assure you that the Council has taken careful note of the views expressed here today on this very important issue. Thank you very much for this debate again.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. As the EDU Court states, the press plays a key role as a public watchdog, including in the fight against organised crime. As recognised by the judicial and police authorities, there are many journalistic investigations that have paved the way for significant investigative and judicial developments; The work of journalists is also one of the elements through which the cultural change necessary to meet the challenge posed by organised crime at European level must pass. The criminal organisations themselves are aware of this: dozens of journalists are under protection because they are victims of threats and aggression because of their investigative work, and unfortunately many have paid with their lives for this commitment. Free media, and therefore able to carry out its task, are one of the foundations of democratic society, guaranteeing the rule of law and fundamental values. In order to protect journalists, we must not only bring those responsible for crimes against their freedoms to justice, but also tackle on a common basis the phenomenon of organised crime, which is now transnational in scale, by harmonising national legislation, so that the differences between them no longer benefit criminal groups.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D)
text: Writing. – Behind every journalist who wins a Pulitzer Prize lies 100 journalists who have been killed and murdered in the course of their profession. However, it is impossible to count those journalists who are victims of censorship, gushing, pressures, dismissals that are imprisoned, tortured because they want to do their job well. These journalists are growing in the world because the pressure on capital owners, interest associations and politicians is growing. Regardless of where the pressures come from, and whatever country they are going, they must be harshly condemned, investigated and punished by offenders.  It is the duty of our governments, including slovenian governments, to create a situation in which journalists have an open door to the transmission of information. It is the duty of journalists to report impartially and without false news. Only then can we count on a well-informed and informed public.

name: Urmas Paet (Renew)
text: Writing. – A free and independent press contributes to a fair society and helps to ensure that governments, businesses and society are more accountable. Unfortunately, the work of journalists carries risks, and in recent years the number of attacks on journalists has increased. Last year, 94 journalists were killed. This year, Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi was brutally killed, while a few years ago journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia was killed in Malta , an EU member state. It continues to be the case that governments are unable, and often do not want, to protect journalists or prosecute those behind the killings and attacks of journalists. Attacks on female journalists are also on the rise. By failing to protect journalists and freedom of expression in society, we are seriously undermining our ability to be informed and to make informed choices and decisions on its soil. Member States must stand up to ensure a safe environment for journalists and for their attackers to be prosecuted.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the resurgence of Ebola in East Africa (2019/2897(RSP)). Before I open the debate, I would like to inform you that, in order to request catch-the-eye and blue cards, it will be possible to use both the standard registration and the new system allowing Members to register electronically. Therefore, I invite you to always bring your voting card. Should you wish to register for catch-the-eye, I invite you to do so starting from now without waiting for the end of the debate. Since we are running out of time, please also stick to the allocated time.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, dear colleagues, thank you so much for organising this discussion in Parliament.  I really believe that it is the right moment to talk about Ebola in East Africa for two specific reasons: first because Ebola has resurged in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). This is the tenth ever Ebola outbreak in the country. Its main characteristic is that it is happening in the most complex and fragile and insecure region of the eastern part of the DRC. The second reason is that despite the challenges on the ground, we have kept up the fight against Ebola. We are making steady steps of progress thanks to our relentless efforts with our partners in laboratories with experts and researchers, in meeting rooms with other donors and international organisations and on the ground together with patients, communities, local leaders and health workers. Since 1 August 2018, when the current outbreak started, more than 3 200 people were infected. More than 2 100 people have, unfortunately, lost their lives. At the same time, more than 1 000 lives were saved. When talking about Ebola, we should never forget the worst ever outbreak that hit West Africa five years ago. The European Union’s intervention at that time was critical in handling a situation which was completely out of control.  It was a very painful experience – including for me personally. I saw this first hand as soon as I took over my duties as European Commissioner and the EU Ebola coordinator in November 2014 when I visited, with my dear colleague Commissioner Andriukaitis, the three affected countries – Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea – at the peak of the crisis. I remember we talked a lot with my colleagues here and in Parliament and I always had your very crucial and very special support in this very difficult situation at that time.  But this crisis was also, five years ago, a milestone. It taught us important lessons that shape the way we responded to the Ebola epidemics that followed. The ninth Ebola outbreak in the DRC’s province of Équateur demonstrated that we took on board those lessons. That outbreak was declared in May and it ended in August 2018. We managed to contain the virus in three months. You can compare the situation with that of five years ago in West Africa.  I would like to mention four lessons that we learned and we now follow on the ground.  The first lesson and maybe the most important: act fast. Our response to the current outbreak in the eastern part of the DRC started on the same day the outbreak was declared. Already on day one, the European Union was transporting doctors and equipment to the affected areas.  The second lesson: be ready. This requires improved capacities. We are now able to do these things thanks to an excellent instrument – the European Medical Corps, which is part of the European Union civil protection mechanism. The European Medical Corps is Europe’s highly specialised medical teams ready to be deployed in health emergencies at very, very short notice. Our response capacities also include high-tech isolation units, in cooperation with Norway, and a mechanism for medical evacuation. I am talking about medevac: the medical evacuation of health and aid workers for treatment in the European Union, in cooperation with the World Health Organisation.  The third lesson, also extremely important: invest in prevention and cure – in vaccines, diagnostic tests and treatment. Since 2014, the European Union has invested more than EUR 231 million in vaccine development and research on Ebola treatments in diagnostic tests. One vaccine – with a second one in the pipeline – and two treatments are currently used in the DRC and in its neighbouring Uganda and Rwanda, and the results are very, very encouraging. On 31 October, as Commissioner, I announced together with my dear colleague, Commissioner Moedas, an additional EUR 6 million from the EU’s Horizon 2020 programme to support a new vaccination trial in the DRC. Thanks to Parliament’s support, we have managed to mobilise more than EUR 47 million since 2018 for the humanitarian response to Ebola in the DRC, together with another EUR 5 million for prevention and preparedness measures in the neighbouring countries most at risk: Uganda, South Sudan, Rwanda and Burundi.  Last but not least, the final lesson: strengthen the local footprint. We help to address the critical problem of chronically weak national and local health infrastructure. We have mobilised EUR 180 million from the 11th European Development Fund, 2014-2020, to support the health sector in the DRC, and the health sectors in Burundi and South Sudan also received European development funds.  The response in the DRC in 2019 is not the same as in West Africa five years ago, in 2014. We have made significant progress in how we respond to Ebola. Despite the many challenges on the ground, and thanks to the dedication of epidemiologists and health workers, as I have already mentioned, more than 1 000 patients have recovered and more than 240 000 persons have been vaccinated, but it is also true that the reality on the ground sets the rules of the game. We must not forget that we are responding in a zone of active conflict where, unfortunately, access to clean water, food, basic healthcare and education is really a big challenge, with hundreds of thousands of cases of measles, malaria and cholera. And we have to respond on multiple fronts. This complicates our job and slows down our efforts, but it does not lessen our determination to save lives and help make Ebola history.  Thank you, my dear colleagues, for your attention. I tried to describe the situation not only in the DRC but also to compare five years ago in West Africa, and I look forward to your interventions and a very fruitful discussion.

name: Lukas Mandl
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, thank you for what you have said. And since this may be the last opportunity for the debate here in plenary with you, Commissioner, I would like to say thank you for your service to the European Union. In addition to all the challenges that are naturally always present between Parliament and the Commission, it is valuable for someone to do a service. I would therefore like to thank you for your service as Commissioner in the european Commission, which is already in office. This is a service which is so important in this area in particular, because we need a Europe with strength to the outside world. In the humanitarian field in particular, Europe is particularly strong and can show strength to be taken seriously in the world and also to make a difference in this world within the framework of European values. Ebola is a terrible disease, a heinous disease and an insidious disease. In West Africa, 11,000 people have died of Ebola, and Ebola has re-emerged in eastern Congo and is already spreading to neighbouring countries. Africa is in our neighbourhood. Many people at home in Austria ask me: What is special about the relationship with Africa? For us Europeans, the people of Africa are immediate neighbours. Unlike the US or China or other parts of the world, we are in close proximity, and we have a responsibility to people in the neighborhood. So it is important that the new vaccine, which can now be brought into action against Ebola, can actually be effective by showing strength as the European Union and making it possible for this vaccine to be rolled out to the general public. This is in the interests of the people on the ground, and that is in our own interest.

name: Carlos Zorrinho
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Commissioner, the resurgence of Ebola in Congo is a serious public health problem, which requires local authorities and the international community to respond at the conjuncture and structurally. The Commissioner explained, moreover, well: we must maintain a rapid response force, prepared to act in difficult conditions, learning from previous experiences, improving the coordination of means and communicating better to gain the confidence of the people. And in this dimension, the European Union's effort deserves to be highlighted. It has combined EUR 47 million in direct support for Congo and EUR 4 million from neighbouring countries and has sent - as you have said - adequate experts and means of action to the field. It is also important to highlight the decision taken yesterday by the European Commission, through our European Medicines Agency, to grant authorisation for the introduction of an Ebola vaccine, as part of a wider programme that already includes clinical trials in congo of a vaccine scheme funded by Horizon 2020. We invest, but we have results. The effectiveness and readiness possible in these emergency responses is also an incentive to include long-term investment in health, education, poverty-fighting and sustainable development.   Next week, in the neighbouring capital of Rwanda, the ACP/European Union Joint Parliamentary Assembly holds its 38th plenary session. The issue of specific Ebola will not be up for debate, but issues and lines of action will be discussed which in the future could help prevent difficult-to-control epidemic situations. Therefore, Madam President, I end by saying that this is one more reason for the European Union to bet unreservedly on the post-Cotonou partnership, including its parliamentary dimension.

name: Martin Horwood
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, this extended Ebola outbreak is a disaster, not just because more than 2 000 people have lost their lives, but also because that number is still second only to that huge 2014—2016 outbreak in West Africa, and it is still rising. That shows that, as an interconnected world, we have so far failed to learn and act on important lessons from that earlier epidemic.  Now, it is fantastic that Europe more quickly mobilised more effective humanitarian effort in response – worth EUR 47 million – since the outbreak started last year and spent on healthcare, on infection control, on contact tracing, on support for survivors and on community engagement. It’s great that the EU is working with private companies to tackle the problem that it’s more profitable to sell headache cures to rich people than to treat rare diseases that mainly kill the poor. It’s also great that scientific and medical partnerships like Horizon 2020 and the Innovative Medicines Initiative mean that 236 000 people have been vaccinated with one Ebola vaccine – and we’ve now heard a second is on the way – and it breaks my heart that Brexit could jeopardise British participation in programmes like this. But the scale of this outbreak – like the last – is not down to inadequate humanitarian response. It is because of systemic failures: poor health education that means many local people dismiss outbreaks as hoaxes and even attack or sometimes kill healthcare workers; poor health infrastructure, funded by inadequate domestic resources, with millions often lost to tax avoidance or simply destroyed by conflict; a global health workforce crisis that is worst in poor countries, fragile states and conflict zones and in which rich countries poach health workers from poor countries.  I’m pleased, as the Commissioner commented, that the EU’s Directorate-General for International Cooperation and Development (DG DEVCO) is now investing in tackling some of these issues, but Europe needs to lead the world to do much more. European humanitarian aid is right and necessary, but if we are not to respond to yet more death in a few years’ time, we must also invest in public health, in health infrastructure, in local workforces, in domestic resources and in peace.

name: Petra De Sutter
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner too – because he stressed the link between the Ebola outbreak and the health system strengthening that my colleague was just referring to. Of course, the vaccines certainly are a step forward, but the many Ebola outbreaks over the past decades have shown that the biggest problem is not the lack of a vaccine but the lack of functioning health systems, and we need strong health systems to protect Congolese people and people anywhere else in the world against Ebola. We need strong health systems to counter the many other health challenges which do not make it to western newspaper headlines, including, for instance, high maternal and child mortality. Humanitarian organisations even warn us that the international Ebola response is taking away staff and financial support to address these other challenges. I therefore urge the EU to use the Ebola crisis as a means to strengthen the health systems in these countries and to make sure that Ebola activities are integrated within their health systems.

name: Joanna Kopcińska
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. In July this year, the World Health Organization declared the Ebola outbreak in the Democratic Republic of Congo an international public health emergency. The European Union, which has been actively involved in assistance for years, is active in many areas of cooperation this time. Yesterday, the European Commission, as we heard, approved the launch of the first Ebola vaccine, a breakthrough in the prevention of this deadly disease.  In my personal view, however, it is not just about financial resources, but about the lesson we need to learn in order to manage resources properly, while controlling a limited financial aspect. I fully support action to combat the disease, but regardless of the action rightly taken, I will be looking at the allocation process and will raise additional questions to the Commission if necessary, given that on 31 October the European Commission announced additional support of EUR 6 million for vaccination trials under Horizon 2020, and since 2014 alone more than EUR 230 million has been allocated for this purpose.

name: João Ferreira
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, the current Ebola outbreak is the second largest ever recorded after the epidemic that killed more than 11,000 people between 2013 and 2016 and has already been declared an international public health emergency by the World Health Organisation. Marketing authorisation for a new vaccine is a hope for people at risk of contracting this disease, but it is important to ensure that this advance reaches at-risk populations as soon as possible universally and free of charge. It is necessary to learn all the lessons of the previous epidemic, and not to forget that the fragile health infrastructure in many countries was decisive in the inability to face the progression of the epidemic. In addition to the urgent emergency aid, it is necessary to support the construction of universal and free public health systems and the training of specialized personnel. It is necessary to combat the hegemony of pharmaceutical companies in the development of new drugs, the dictatorship of patents. It is necessary to cancel the external debt of these countries and to end the IMF and World Bank programmes that perpetuate backwardness and dependence. The development of essential public services needs to be supported, particularly in areas such as water and sanitation.

name: Mónica Silvana González (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I believe that the right title is the resurgence of Ebola in Central Africa, since it is in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, in Central Africa, that these cases have arisen.  As the Commissioner said, it is an area with a humanitarian challenge of enormous magnitude, where more than thirteen million people need our humanitarian aid; more people have died from violence than from Ebola.  If our goal is to end this outbreak, we must take a more holistic approach. The development of the vaccine, supported and funded by the European Union, is an important step forward. However, we must not divert attention from preventive measures. We need to address the fears and concerns of the community, relying— as the Commissioner rightly said, on local organizations. This outbreak will only end when communities are engaged in this struggle and this is led by a local response, for example, in terms of safe and dignified burials—the burial of corpses. Work should also be focused on women, as they are the most affected by Ebola, as they are often the main caregivers at risk.  This new outbreak highlights, once again, that there is no substitute for long-term health investment. Health must continue to be high on the European Union's development agenda, which should support Congo's health sector. In short, a holistic approach is needed that goes beyond disease, covering joint work in development, not just humanitarian aid.

name: María Soraya Rodríguez Ramos (Renew).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the global emergency declaration in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, a year after a new outbreak entrenched this epidemic, has already left more than two thousand deaths and three thousand infections related to the virus. This shows the severity of this new outbreak.  I would like to congratulate you, Commissioner, because prevention against this terrible virus is a top priority and the authorisation on 11 November of the marketing of the Ebola vaccine , called Ervebo , I think is a fundamental step.  Tackling this epidemic in a conflict zone is a challenge, but we are now facing a little-known conflict: health workers face attacks and threats. In 2019 there have been more than two hundred attacks on hospitals, doctors and health workers with dozens of deaths precisely because of the fake news that is transmitted through WhatsApp saying that the virus does not exist and that it is a whole business for politicians to take money. The frequency, the lethality of attacks, which are affecting the fight against the epidemic and vaccination as the disease progresses is terrible.

name: Rory Palmer (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we’ve all clearly agreed with the scale of the challenge that is presented when terrible diseases like Ebola break out in places that already have pre—existing security and humanitarian challenges, where there is poor infrastructure and poor access to services for people. So we need to be clear in this debate not just about analysing the challenge of what is happening in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) at the moment, but about what we expect in the future, in the plan for Africa that the Commission President-designate has committed to. We need to be clear this evening in saying that we want health protection, prevention of disease and health security to be high—level strategic priorities in that plan, and if those things are not the top priorities in that plan, any such future plan for Africa presented by the Commission in the future should not command the support of this Parliament.

name: Véronique Trillet-Lenoir (Renew).
text: Madam President, the Ebola epidemic in the Democratic Republic of Congo is a global health emergency and poses a real danger to other countries, even if they are far away, because of imported cases. We welcome the recent introduction of the vaccine, which will protect the environment of sick people and also health professionals. We also welcome the strength of international and multidisciplinary cooperation, strongly supported by the European Commission, which has enabled this great technological advance. We draw the Commission's attention to several needs: strengthening precarious local health systems, coordinating stock management to avoid the risk of shortages, informing people and combating the risks of fake news that have already been mentioned above, and preparing European countries to respond to potential imported cases.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Madam President, it has been said that the current epidemic in the Democratic Republic of Congo is the second largest after the 2014 epidemic in West Africa, which killed 11,000 people. Unfortunately, the DRC also faces a so-called, rather cynical, "low-intensity" war. Low intensity that has claimed more than 6 million lives since 1994. It is in this same region of Kivu that Ebola is taking action and it is in this same region that armed groups are now destroying health centres, which effectively makes humanitarian work difficult. Of course, we need an emergency response, and I thank you for the humanitarian response you are doing. Information from the population, working with local communities, is important. Above all, however, there is a need to support a longer-term policy in the DRC, which makes access to health effective and accessible to all. As you know, we passed a conflict minerals law. Well! the corporate world has requested that this law be postponed to 2021, in terms of enforcement. What for? Because the corporate world doesn't want to pay for resources. Today, this country is a rich country and people are there, sitting on gold mines and at the same time they are dying. So when I hear that we need to treat Ebola because it is contagious to the world, I say: we have to treat Ebola because it is contagious in the DRC for Africans and that is where we have to act.

name: Tudor Ciuhodaru (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I am Tudor Ciuhodaru, doctor, emergency doctor in Iasi, Romania, Emergency Clinical Hospital "Nicolae Oblu", a city, a collective, a hospital where the exact time is given in emergency medicine. In 2015 I received the most beautiful birthday present, my volunteer offer against Ebola was accepted, being put on a short list after a selection of thousands of candidates, being considered one of the most suitable and well prepared people to intervene in emergency situations. At the time it was a tragic situation: 94 medical professionals had lost their lives and was only one doctor per hundred thousand inhabitants.  I believe that at the moment we need to ensure two essential things: on the one hand health education, because without those knowledge, skills, skills, and you know that Ebola also depends very much on compliance with hygiene rules and beyond, things will not be able to evolve favourably and that this health education should become a priority in schools in Europe , and on the other hand, the economic barrier for which you make considerable efforts. In addition, the human resource is not to be neglected and that medical body is an extremely important thing, because we do not live under a glass bell. And look, similar situations occur in Europe: recently there is an epidemiological alert on the northern border of Romania, in Ukraine, related to diphtheria.  So, once again, Commissioner, I offer once again, honoured the Commission, the willingness to volunteer in such situations, but consider that that European standard of quality in health must become mandatory.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, dear colleagues, thank you so much for your positive contribution in this very fruitful debate.  Through this debate, I once again realise that we all agree that the Ebola crisis in West Africa was a test for the international community and it taught us that we cannot be complacent about Ebola. Five years after the largest Ebola crisis in our history, we learned important lessons, we adapted our response, we redefined our approach and now we know better what to expect and how to respond. In fact, we are ready before the alarm goes off. More staff is on the ground, there are now vaccines and treatments with effective results, and the overall support is much more coordinated than five years ago. In the European Union as a whole, and for me personally, until the end of my mandate (nobody knows when that will be), we will continue to be in close contact with the national authorities and local authorities in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) and neighbouring countries, but at the same time, with the global coordinator, the World Health Organisation, and our partners on the ground, the UN agencies and other international organisations, just to make sure that our response is really sufficient and adequate.  We have to give an effective response to Ebola to finally break the cycle of the epidemics. We should also start charting the post-Ebola phase. I totally agree with many of you already focused on the problem of the healthcare systems in many African countries, especially in the DRC. We must strengthen the national health systems and their capacities to respond to epidemics. Of course in the DRC and in the neighbouring countries, and as you know – this is one of my favourite expressions – we have to see stronger humanitarian—development nexus, which needs to be put in place in order to see sustainable health systems in these countries. I completely agree with this approach, but as you know, this is a medium- and long-term approach. At the same time, we have to focus on urgent needs, and this is our role as humanitarian actors. At the same time, we have to continue to advocate with our international partners for enough resources.  Frankly speaking, in some cases in Africa, we Europeans saw ourselves as alone. This is the hard reality on the ground.  But, finally, we must not forget that the scale of Ebola in eastern DRC follows decades of violence, totally absent state institutions, constant displacement, poverty and the multiple humanitarian needs for millions of Congolese in the region. We, together, already realise the root causes of this problem, but with Parliament’s commitment, we have to manage to scale up our response to Ebola, and I really sincerely thank you for this support – because I can compare the situation five years ago and now. I know well the situation on the ground and, at the same time, I can say that it was very important because we show people in practice that the European Union cares outside of Europe. The European Union – yes – is a union of solidarity and we are determined to continue to do our best to fully control the current Ebola epidemic as we did before and I’m sure, together, we will win in this very demanding battle.  Thank you so much again for your attention and for your support.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Dominique Bilde (ID)
text: In writing. The Ebola crisis is currently at a turning point with the combined use of at least two vaccines - which had been at the heart of serious controversies in the Democratic Republic of Congo - and the discovery of treatments that could drastically reduce mortality. These advances should not lead us to relax our efforts in affected areas, where the epidemic often is compounded by chronic instability - as is the case in the region of North Kivu, torn apart by a deadly civil war. In these areas, the distrust of populations traumatized by years of armed conflict hinders the deployment of health teams, sometimes leading to fatal attacks on medical personnel. Beyond the financial aspect, genuine human support for health professionals seems essential. But let us not forget the safety of our own people. It would be curious if, while Japan, a country that has relatively little contact with the African continent, is strengthening its preparedness against the virus, the European Union is still waiting. This is all the more true since Ebola is added a second health threat: that of measles, which is already making its big comeback on our continent.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the one-minute speeches on matters of political importance (Rule 172). Colleagues, we are really running out of time so please stick to the allocated speaking time.

name: Traian Băsescu (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the other day, the President of a founding country of NATO and the European Union declared that NATO is an outdated organisation. I would recall that NATO has guaranteed collective security for 70 years, and today NATO is fully operational.  And then what role does the European army play? The European Union will not create a new army but will diminish NATO's military capabilities, reducing the credibility and deterrence of the organisation. Paradoxically, most NATO and EU member states do not contribute two per cent to the defence budget, instead they seem ready to build a new army with enormous spending. The truth is that you kind of see security when you have borders at the Atlantic and another when you have the borders on the Baltic And The Black Sea, where you're dealing with the unpredictable Putin. Personally, I believe that NATO is the organisation that guarantees us security, independence and freedom.

name: Carmen Avram (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we are increasingly talking about combating climate change, but we are not putting enough emphasis on the most important weapon we have in this fight, namely the forests of the European Union, those that seize most of the carbon dioxide emissions.  At the moment, although almost half of the Union's land is occupied by forests, 77% of it is left to its own, not yet subject to binding common legislation, as the European Commission itself recognises in the question I have recently asked it. And in these forests, wars are sometimes fought for life and death, literally. In Romania, for example, six rangers have been killed in recent years and another 650 have been injured in clashes with the wood mafia.  In this situation, how can we think of victory in the war on climate change? I think it is extremely important that in the future European Green Pact, the Commission and the Commissioner in charge of this portfolio think of an effective financing regime, a tough strategy and drastic systems for monitoring our forests, which will be mandatory in all the Member States of the European Union.

name: Klemen Grošelj (Renew).
text: – Honourable President-in-Office, the Western Balkans face many challenges, including the problem of illegal migration, in addition to the geopolitical competition of major powers.  Illegal migration, often organised by criminal groups, also leads to tragic deaths, as we have recently witnessed at the Schengen border between Slovenia and Croatia. However, the importance of the region's fate is as important as the stated need to maintain a European perspective for Serbia, which is approaching an important political and social turning point with future elections. These elections will decide not only the future of Serbia itself, but also the future of the whole region.  I therefore expect and call on the Commission to pay more attention to these issues than it has paid so far and to step up activities to preserve and, above all, strengthen the european perspective of both Serbia and the region.

name: Catherine Rowett (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, will the European children of tomorrow hear any birds singing in trees or bees humming in the flowers? According to more than 2 500 scientists in a recent letter to Ursula von der Leyen, intensive farming has caused a catastrophic decline in farmland birds and insects across Europe since 1980. The reformed common agricultural policy must change this. We must reverse the incentives, promote small-scale traditional farming and restore biodiversity. Yet it’s not just farming. Where I live, pointless roads are being subsidised from EU funds. They slice viciously through precious woodland, river valleys and wildlife sites hitherto immune from the plough and the spray. We must re-order our values; we must count the true costs of privileging private cars over nature’s green spaces. EU money needs to be green, not grey, and tomorrow is too late.

name: Silvia Sardone (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is a total failure on immigration.  In recent weeks I have felt particular emphasis on the Malta Agreement. It was supposed to be a revolution. It had to because in reality it is a total failure. In Italy, landings have increased and NGOs are now always arriving and helping, in fact, the smugglers. There is no rotation of ports, the one you promised so much.  France and Germany constantly say that redistribution is needed, but they say it only in words because then, in practice, redistribution does not. Obviously, therefore, all the landings we had in Italy are of people who then stayed there and stay there.  Only three countries have joined. The European Union is totally absent, but, in words, it speaks of a duty of acceptance, speaks of human necessity and then in the end they all land exclusively in Italy. That's how it suits you. It is convenient for you now in Italy to have the left in government and so that Italy is the refugee camp of Europe.  However, let me just say before I close, that at least finish it with these farce documents, such as the Malta Agreement, which are in fact only a mockery of European citizens.

name: Hermann Tertsch (ECR).
text: – Madam President, we would like to denounce and recall at this time the case of José Daniel Ferrer, who is the president of UNPACU , of the Patriotic Union of Cuba – who disappeared first, arrested and tortured at the moment in the castrist prisons of Cuba.  We must also say that we are very sorry that this complaint coincides with the journey of the kings who, organized by the Spanish Government of Pedro Sánchez and with the responsibility of Josep Borrell, have taken them to Cuba at a time when Cuba is torturing Ferrer; Cuba is participating in the destabilization of Ibero-America in various countries, as denounced by the Organization of American States itself; and Cuba is directing, with Venezuela, cocaine trafficking to launder money for the Sao Paulo Forum and organize this destabilization.  It is a scandal and it is very regrettable this journey which the Spanish government has organized, as I say, in excellent relations with the Cuban dictatorship. We're terribly sorry.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, concluding the Banking Union has thus become a kind of mantra that is being repeated by the right and by social democracy, above all to divert attention from the real meaning and consequences of this project. After expropriating the states from their monetary, exchange rate and budgetary sovereignty, they want to take control and supervision over their banking system, which is delivered on a platter to half a dozen large transnational financial groups. With the proposal now presented by Germany for the Third Pillar we perceive the deception better. In exchange for loans to national guarantee funds, certainly paid with a tongue, conditions are fixed that push the banks of the weakest countries into potentially devastating competition situations, further facilitating the monopolistic concentration of the sector in European megabanks. On the way, they want to leave even more helpless and unprotected countries like Portugal in the next tight corner of a new euro crisis. Only public control of banking, and the management and public property of banking, can break with this path and with these interests and put banking at the service of the common good and a sovereign development project.

name: Matthew Patten (NI).
text: – Madam President, European civilisation was built on water: our seas and rivers were the lifeblood of trade, food, community and culture. Yet today, many living in coastal communities have been left behind to struggle with poverty, crime, unemployment and health inequalities. I live in East Anglia, by the North Sea, close to Clacton, Walton, Jaywick, Lowestoft and Yarmouth. The benefits of globalisation have not washed up on our shores. These are the places that the EU has left behind. The life chances of young and old are reduced with poor education and overstretched health services. Broadband and commercial infrastructure is often non-existent. Fishing communities have been left behind and devastated. Coastal communities are left to pick up the pieces of the EU’s disastrous migrancy policy. It’s no surprising that our coastal communities have the largest Brexit vote in the UK. Next year, we are celebrating the 400th anniversary of the Mayflower, the ship built in the port of Harwich, seven miles from my home. It carried 102 pilgrims away from European religious repression to the New World and laid the foundations of modern—day America. Next year, 66 million UK citizens will be departing, this time to escape EU political repression. It’s time the EU woke up to the special needs of its coastal communities, otherwise they will be joining the UK on our journey to the free world.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to dedicate one minute to the issue of freedom, because that is the fundamental value of democracy, and we are celebrating the 30th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall and the fall of communism. I think there's something to celebrate. The Iron Curtain divided Europe for four decades, and totalitarian regimes fell because they collapsed, they were not competitive. For 30 years, we have been removing the borders between us, we have joined virtually across the continent and we are purposefully removing the obstacles that have been between Member States. Cooperation, compromise, these are our values, the values of our community. What challenges do we face? The Union is strong, even if Brexit weakens the entire continent. The challenges before us are to accept the Balkan states, to give them a future, not to separate, but to unite, to guarantee safety and prosperity and, of course, a favourable environment for citizens. Of course, we must also not forget solidarity as a fundamental European value and respect freedom.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Madam President, working together, trade unions across Europe have won many rights for workers that are now enshrined in European law: from paid holiday for all, to new protections for precarious workers. Brexit poses a direct threat. Since 2010, the Tories have rolled back everything else, but they couldn’t touch these rights. Johnson’s withdrawal agreement scraps the commitment to a level playing field, removing that last obstacle to full exploitation and they’re not shy about it. Dominic Raab and Priti Patel have been explicit that rights at work are red tape that need cutting, and look at the Tories’ new bedfellows: Farage famously took aim at increased maternity protection when it was voted on in this House. Farage and Johnson are in this together and be in no doubt that they’re coming after your rights at work. Don’t let them near the scissors.

name: Valter Flego (Renew).
text: – Dear President, I come from Istria and know how important international cooperation, cross-border cooperation in an area is. Of course I'm not just talking about projects and events, I'm talking about infrastructure. When I talk about infrastructure, we have great examples at the level of the European Union, the Interreg programme from which more than sixty very valuable projects were financed. When it comes to Istria, we have a great example of cooperation and connection between two waterworks: istrian waterworks from the Croatian part of Istria and rižana waterworks from the Slovenian part of Istria. What we need now is road connections, connecting the Istrian Y on one side to the Slovenian motorway network in order to reduce congestion during the tourist season. That is why I ask that cohesion policy not be cut, and that is why I ask that there be exactly such an item in the budget, 21 and 27, so that we can reduce crowds during the tourist season, and allow our people living in Istria a more comfortable and simpler life and work.

name: Clare Daly (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I am ashamed to be Irish and to have to stand up here to talk about 78-year-old Tarak Kauff and 82-year-old Ken Myers, two US army Veterans for Peace who came to Ireland on St Patrick’s Day eight months ago to search US warplanes and expose the lie that these warplanes from the United States transiting through a civilian airport in neutral Ireland do not have arms. These men know that they have arms and, like myself and my colleague, when we were members of the Irish Parliament, attempted to search those planes. Unlike us, these two elderly men have had their passports taken from them in a very vindictive move. They’ve been effectively interned in Ireland for eight months, unable to go home, reliant on the charity of others and separated from their families at this part of their lives. This is a denial of their human rights. There’s no question they’re not going to turn up for their trial. This is why they did the action in the first place: to talk about their experiences when they were in the military and to expose the lies going on. I’m really appealing to the European Parliament and European institutions, on humanitarian grounds, to say to the Irish state not to stand in the way of their request for the bail conditions to be lifted, for their passports to be given back, so they can spend Christmas at home with their families.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR).
text: – Dear President, according to open door, there are currently around 100 million Christians, mainly in Islamic countries and North Korea, victims of persecution. Recently, we have been hearing reports of the increasing persecution of Christians in China: churches are being destroyed, crosses are being removed, believers are being arrested, many priests are still in prison. Three weeks ago, the authorities destroyed another church there. Unfortunately, we have also received bad news from France, where a bill has been tabled in parliament on the initiative of President Macron's party, which drastically reduced the freedom of clergy to speak on morals and criticise LGBT ideology. These would be gross violations of freedom of expression and democracy. In this place, I would like to remind my colleagues of the words of the Community father, the founder Robert Schuman: EU democracy will be either Christian or non-existous.

name: Sabrina Pignedoli (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the flooding that is taking place in Venice is extremely serious.  Venice is a World Heritage Site, we cannot afford to lose it. The Venetians, to whom all our solidarity goes, the Venetians and the Italians will roll up their sleeves, but I am here to ask for the solidarity and practical help of all European citizens. Venice needs us. Once the damage has been estimated, we must ensure that the appropriations from the European Union Solidarity Fund arrive as quickly as possible. To save Venice and its priceless artistic heritage, it is necessary to reduce the time of the disbursement of the fund, which today is about a year from the submission of the application. The 5-Star Movement will make its voice heard on this and I am sure that I will find the cooperation of the entire European Parliament.  The tragedy in Venice must be a warning to all of us. Climate change threatens our future. That is why we need to change the register. Europe must courageously take unprecedented concrete measures to protect the environment.

name: Peter Pollák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, several in this period are commemorating the Velvet Revolution, the moments when Communism fell in Czechoslovakia. Under Communism, we didn't even realize what we were losing. We didn't know what was behind the Iron Curtain. We did not know freedom, we lived in isolation and dictatorship. Thirty years ago, at the time of the Velvet Revolution, I was seventeen years old and I was one of the students who was struding with the keys in the square. Many of us didn't know how it would end up at the time. However, the desire for freedom and democracy was much greater than fear. We can't dictate to people how to live. We can't ban them from going to church, we can't trust them, we can't shut people's mouths. Freedom is one of the most important values that we must protect. Thirty years ago, young people opened the way to democracy. We took down their communist dictatorship. However, we must constantly protect democracy. The dictation can come back. Fascist and extremist parties are gaining strength again. They abuse the freedom of speech that democracy brings them to dig into it, break it and replace it with totalitarianism. The extremists changed from uniforms to suits and swapped military shoes for moccasins. Those who have even attached to their sacs cross spread hatred and command fascism. Democracy is under threat in many countries today. Fascists re-proclaim ideology about the superior race. If Hitler had won the war, I wouldn't be here today because I'm Roma. If I do not want to lose democracy, we cannot forget our history.

name: Rory Palmer (S&D).
text: – Madam President, this year we’ve seen football at its best: a fantastic Women’s World Cup and fantastic European and domestic competitions, but we’re also seeing football at its ugly worst in places at the moment because, sadly, we again see headlines of racism in football. In recent weeks and months, awful scenes and incidents have taken place at international matches, at club level, in domestic leagues, at grassroots level, and unbelievably – incredibly – at junior level as well. The nature of what we see at the moment demands more of those running football, of our national associations, of UEFA and of FIFA. We must make sure that the institutions here in the European Union, alongside our national parliaments and governments, make sure that UEFA and FIFA and national associations do act, and do so decisively and that, together, we get racism, hate, abuse and bigotry out of football, once and for all.

name: Jessica Stegrud (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I'll start with some facts. Sweden currently has among the highest unemployment rates in Europe. We have among the longest care queues. We have the most poor pensioners in relative terms. We have for many years received the most migrants per capita. We also top the sad statistics on the number of bombings, car fires and rapes. In addition, Swedish taxpayers already pay the most per person to the EU today.  I am here to defend Swedish interests and, as far as I can judge, Belgium is a very rich and well-functioning country, and I therefore see no reason whatsoever for Swedish taxpayers to be involved in paying for the conversion of 400 carrefour employees. Belgium can do that on its own.  I therefore firmly reject the withdrawal of money from the common European Globalisation Fund for precisely this purpose.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, what do today's students think of the fall of communism 30 years ago? The work of 30 students who entered a literary competition in the Zlín Region showed their knowledge of facts and understanding of the values that were at the time and today. Judge for yourself from an excerpt of the winning work of Adela Zábojníková from the gymnasium in Uherský Brod: "At this time, we are going to celebrate that it has succeeded. I think everyone should stop and give a brief memory of the people who had to sacrifice themselves so that we would have a happy life full of joy. Who knows what will be born of this year's memory. Whether it's a small act or a great deed, it will fit into a mosaic that has been saying for 30 years, "Thanks for being able to!" Autumn walks through the landscape as it did then. The leaves are dyed, the sun sets over the horizon, and the whole world seems to be on fire. Like my heart, it burns with love, love for my family, friends and the whole country. I close my eyes and have one wish: "May peace continue with this land." I have a bundle of keys ringing in my pocket with every step, and that's a clear symbol for me. A symbol that says, "Thank you for the opportunity, thank you for your freedom." And I thank Adele.

name: Cristina Maestre Martín De Almagro (S&D).
text: – Madam President, it is my intention, at this given minute, to draw attention to the calamitous situation that has been going through the Daimiel Tables National Park, which has been in a situation of extreme vulnerability for decades. At the moment it is because of the drought, which, although by cycles, becomes more and more persistent, and because of the excessive extraction of water from aquifer 23.  Today, of the three thousand hectares of Daimiel Tables National Park, only sixty are flooded.  The future of the Tables depends on the iron will of each and every one of us in each of our responsibilities. Europe has to get wet, too. We need to work to ensure compliance with the Habitats and Water Directives, as well as to promote real sustainable development and curb climate change.  But it's not all legislation, ladies and gentlemen, it's also investment. Europe has already helped my country save the Tables at a difficult time: after the drought and the fire that took place in 2009. At that time, along with rains and water derivations, came investments. There was an effective land acquisition policy to expand the protected area and water rights were acquired to curb the water deficit. This investment paid off and the Tables recovered and sprouted again.  That is why I want to take this minute to ask Europe to continue to bet on it. It was made possible by the european Commission's momentum and again we need, among all, to save the Tables.

name: Sylwia Spurek (S&D).
text: – Madam President, two weeks ago, the tragic conditions of ten tigers were detected at the Polish-Belarussian border. The tigers were transported from Italy to Russia through Europe, without any care, water or feeding. They were detected at an external EU border only because of the lack of proper entry—visa documents of the truck driver. Not all of them survived. The ones which did were saved by a zoo in my constituency in Poznań. This case shows a lack of efficient regulations. We need to adopt and implement regulations to monitor animal welfare in transport properly, and to stop punishing the people and institutions helping wild animals, such as Poznań Zoo, when transport is suspended or the animals are taken away from the animal owner.

name: John Howarth (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the situation in Kashmir is a growing threat to regional peace in South Asia. Since the Indian Government’s revocation of the special status of Jammu and Kashmir on 5 August, much of the state has been effectively cut off from the outside world. The Indian Government contends that this is solely an internal matter. Yet the reality is, since 1947, Jammu and Kashmir has been a disputed territory, and reports of systematic abuse of human rights continue. In European Union trade agreements, we increasingly insist that respect for human rights must be included. We must apply those same standards to any agreement with the Republic of India and we must urgently demand that international observers be allowed freely into Kashmir. In this House, we should aspire to be the friends of India, and also to be the friends of Pakistan, and we must also recognise that the best route to lasting peace would be to enable Kashmiris to determine their own future.

name: President. –
text: That concludes the item.
